(b)  The building inspector may require details, computations, stress diagrams, and other data necessary to describe the construction and basis of calculations and they shall bear the signature of the person responsible for the design. 
(c)  All drawings, specifications and accompanying data shall bear the name and address of the designer. In the case of buildings or structures of Group A (Assembly), B (Business), and E (Educational), and all buildings or structures exceeding two (2) stories in height or five thousand (5,000) square feet in area and costing fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) or more except one- and two-family dwellings and farm buildings, such designer shall be an architect or engineer legally registered under the laws of this state regulating the practice of architecture or engineering and shall affix his official seal to said drawings, specifications and accompanying data. 
(Ord. No. 18-06, 6-21-2018) 
Sec. 6-47. - Fees. 
The fees to be charged for any permit issued under the provisions of this article shall be as established by the mayor and board of aldermen from time to time and on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 71-25, § 5-3(107.4), 7-6-71) 
Sec. 6-48. - Issuance. 
(a)  Applications for permits required by the provisions of this article shall be examined within a reasonable time after filing. If, after examination, no objection is found to the same and it appears that the proposed work will be in compliance with the laws and ordinances applicable thereto, the application shall be approved and a permit issued for the proposed work. If examination reveals otherwise, such application shall be rejected, and the applicant notified by a written report or otherwise. 
(b)  The issuance or granting of a permit or approval of plans and specifications shall not be construed to be a permit for, or an approval of any violation of any of the provisions of this chapter. No permit presuming to give authority to violate or cancel the provision of this code shall be valid, except insofar as the work or use which it authorizes is lawful. 
(c)  The issuance of a permit based on applications, plans and/or specifications shall not prevent the building inspector from thereafter requiring the correction of errors in said applications, plans and/or specifications or from preventing the work from being carried on thereunder when in violation of this Code of Ordinances or of other ordinances of this city. 
(d)  Each permit shall be assigned a number by the building official, and such number shall be posted plainly and conspicuously on the front of the property concerned throughout the period of work under such permit. 
(e)  Applications shall be approved or rejected not less than thirty (30) days after a complete application has been submitted. 
(Code 1964, § 5-3(106.7); Ord. No. 10-18, § 3, 11-4-2010) 
Sec. 6-49. - Conditions of permit. 
(a)  All work performed under a permit issued under the provisions of this article shall conform to the approved application and plans and all codes or ordinances governing the work or equipment for which permits were issued. All work shall be performed by an individual (contractor, firm or corporation) licensed to perform such work except when performed by an individual installing, altering or repairing plumbing, plumbing fixtures, air conditioning and heating, air conditioning and heating fixtures, or electrical services in a single-family dwelling owned and occupied by him. 
(b)  Individuals, contractors, firms or corporations licensed to perform work governed by this chapter shall register their license number with the building inspector before obtaining permits. 
Sec. 6-50. - Expiration. 
A permit under which no work is commenced within six (6) months after issuance, or where the work commenced is suspended or abandoned for six (6) months, shall expire by limitation, and fees paid shall be forfeited. The application, plans, and specifications shall be reviewed and a new permit required before work is started or resumed. 
Sec. 6-51. - Revocation of permits. 
The building official may revoke a permit or approval, issued under the provisions of this chapter, in case there has been any false statement or misrepresentation in the application or attachments thereto including plans, specifications, plot diagram, or in case any work is done contrary to the application with attachments or in case such permit was improperly issued or in case it is ascertained that the proposed work authorized under the permit does not comply with all ordinances, rules and regulations of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 5-3(103.3)) 
Sec. 6-52. - Certificate of occupancy—Required. 
No new building shall be occupied and no change in occupancy of a building or part of a building shall be made until after the building inspector shall have issued a certificate of occupancy therefor. In addition to the above certificate of occupancy, there is also required a state certificate of occupancy for appropriate buildings in accordance with the state safety fire law. 
Sec. 6-53. - Same—Contents. 
Upon completion of a building erected in accordance with approved plans, and after the final inspection therein referred to, and upon application therefor, the building inspector shall issue a certificate of occupancy stating the nature of the occupancy permitted, the number of persons for each floor when limited by law, the allowable load per square foot for each floor in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
Sec. 6-54. - Same—Temporary. 
A temporary certificate of occupancy may be issued for a portion or portions of a building which may safely be occupied prior to final completion of the building. 
Sec. 6-55. - Same—Existing buildings. 
A certificate of occupancy for any existing building may be obtained by applying to the building inspector and supplying the information and data necessary to determine compliance with this Code for the occupancy intended. Where necessary, in the opinion of the building inspector, two (2) sets of detailed drawings, or a general inspection, or both, may be required. When, upon examination and inspection, it is found that the building conforms to the provisions of this chapter for such occupancy, a certificate of occupancy shall be issued. 
Secs. 6-56—6-67. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 6-68. - Adopted. 
There is hereby adopted by the mayor and the city council, for the purpose of establishing stan-dards and procedures affecting the design, erection and construction of buildings and structures, the Standard Building Code, 1979 Edition, being particularly that code published by the International Building Code, of which code not less than one (1) copy has been and now is filed in the office of the city clerk; and the same is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein; and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the city. All subsequent changes or edition improvements shall be automatically adopted and incorporated for the City of Dublin upon publication by the International Building Code 
(Code 1964, § 5-2; Ord. No. 80-22, § 1, 9-4-80; Ord. No. 88-5, § 1, 2-18-88; Ord. No. 03-04, 3-6-2003) 
State Law reference— Authority to adopt state minimum standards codes, Ga. Code Ann., § 92A-1514. 
Sec. 6-68.1. - Amendments. 
The Southern Standard Building Code, 1979 Edition, is hereby amended by deleting section 107.5 in its entirety and inserting in lieu thereof the following new section: 
Section 107.5 Building Permit Valuations. 
The values and costs contained in the building valuation data guide and regional modifiers as listed in the Southern [Standard] Building Code will be used to determine construction cost for all buildings within the City of Dublin. 
(Ord. No. 86-7, § 1, 3-6-86) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 86-7, § 1, enacted Mar. 6, 1986, being not specifically amendatory of the Code, has been included herein as § 6-68.1, at the discretion of the editor. Said ordinance also provided that the "values" referred to in 6-68.1 "will be changed in the City of Dublin as they are changed in future editions of the Southern Building Code." 
Sec. 6-69. - Definitions. 
(a)  Wherever the term "building inspector" is used in the building code, it shall mean the person designated by the mayor and city council to administer and enforce the provisions of said code. 
(b)  Wherever the term "corporate counsel" is used in the building code, it shall mean the city attorney. 
(c)  Wherever the term "municipality" is used in the building code, it shall mean the City of Dublin, Georgia. 
Sec. 6-70. - Enforcement. 
The building code adopted by the provisions of this article shall be enforced by the chief building inspector. 
Sec. 6-71. - Penalties. 
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the building code or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder, shall, for each such failure or violation or noncompliance, be punished as provided in section 1-10 of the City's Code of Ordinances. 
Sec. 6-72. - Demolition, removed—Definition. 
For the purposes of sections 6-73 through 6-75, the word "structure" means any structure built for the support, shelter or enclosure of persons, animals, chattels or property of any kind which is over eight (8) feet in width. Specifically excluded are manufactured housing, mobile homes and prefabricated buildings being moved from one location to another which are regulated by the laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 74-32, 9-9-74; Ord. No. 06-15, § 11, 10-19-2006) 
Sec. 6-73. - Same—Permit, bond. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to demolish or relocate a building, house or similar structure without having first obtained from the city clerk a permit therefor and having paid to the clerk the required fee for the issuance of said permit. 
(b)  Upon the issuance of a permit, the holder thereof shall post a cash bond in the amount of two hundred dollars ($200.00) with the city clerk upon the following conditions: 
(1)  The bond shall be returned to the holder upon satisfactory completion of the project. Should the project remain unfinished, kept in an unsafe manner, or should the holder fail to clear the lot of all debris and materials within the time specified on the permit, the city manager or his designated agent shall have authority to notify the holder of the permit that the city shall complete the project in a satisfactory manner at the permit holder's expense. If the expense is less than the bond posted, the remainder shall be returned to the permit holder. If the cost is greater than the bond, such difference shall be due and payable to the city, and upon authorization by the city council, shall be assessed against the property. 
(2)  Each permit holder is hereby required to post a sign at the site where any building is being demolished before commencing demolition. The sign shall be at least four (4) square feet in area, which shall read in legible printing, with letters at least six (6) inches in height: "WARNING—BUILDING BEING DEMOLISHED—KEEP OUT." Said sign shall also contain the name and business address of the permit holder in letters at least three (3) inches in height. The permit for the demolition shall be firmly affixed to said sign. The building inspector shall have the authority to inspect the projects herein specified while the work is in progress and may notify the permit holder to take such additional safety procedures as he may deem necessary. 
(3)  Upon completion of the demolition of any building under the provisions of this section and the removal of all debris, the lot shall be graded to a level consistent with the adjacent terrain. 
(Ord. No. 74-5, § 5-4, 3-4-74; Ord. No. 87-22, 8-20-87) 
Sec. 6-74. - Same—Relocation requirements; application for permit. 
(1)  To be considered for relocation within the city limits, a structure shall meet the following requirements: 
(a)  The structure shall have a minimum of nine hundred (900) square feet of heated space. 
(b)  The structure shall contain kitchen and bath facilities. 
(c)  The structure shall be in compliance with all city codes. 
The building inspector shall examine the structure, at the owner's expense, both prior to and after relocation. If said structure is not in compliance, the owner will be obligated to bring structure up to the minimum housing code within three (3) months after relocation. Failure to comply therewith shall be punishable under section 1-10 of the city's Code of Ordinances. 
(2)  No structure shall be considered for approval to be relocated within the city limits unless the following is submitted as part of the application for the required permit: 
(a)  A picture of all sides of the structure to be moved. 
(b)  A plat prepared by a surveyor registered to practice in the state showing the dimensions of the lot, location of utilities and proposed location of the structure. 
(c)  A statement regarding the improvements proposed and existing on the lot upon which the structure is to be located. 
(d)  A single line drawing of floor plan of the proposed structure. 
(e)  A schedule for making improvements required by the building inspector to bring the structure up to the minimum housing code. 
(f)  Evidence of payment for utility disconnection and connection. 
(Ord. No. 74-32, 9-9-74; Ord. No. 86-5, § 1, 2-20-86) 
Sec. 6-74.1. - Same—Public hearing; fee. 
Before the issuance of a permit for the relocation of a structure, the mayor and city council shall hold a public hearing thereon. At least fifteen (15) days prior to the date scheduled for the public hearing, the building inspector shall cause to have posted in a conspicuous place on the property, proposed as the new location for the structure, one (1) or more signs, each of which shall not be less than four (4) square feet in area and each of which shall contain information as to the proposed relocation and the date, the place and time of public hearing and the name and number of the city official to call for information. 
An administrative fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) will be charged for handling the application. Additionally, the city shall be reimbursed by the applicant for any extra cost involved, as determined by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 77-8, § 1, 3-7-77; Ord. No. 77-18, § 1, 6-20-77; Ord. No. 86-5, § 1, 2-20-86; Ord. No. 87-22, 8-20-87) 
Sec. 6-75. - Same—Authority of police department. 
No structure shall be placed upon appropriate trailer apparatus to be moved from any point within, or upon any street, right-of-way or highway of the city unless the following has been secured: 
(a)  A permit to be issued by the police department at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to proposed move. Said permit shall contain evidence that interested public and private utility corporations have been notified, the route to be traveled, destination and statement of person responsible for any costs and damages which may occur. 
(b)  The police department shall have the authority to specify the time and route to be traveled. 
(c)  Upon determination by the police department that additional escort services are required due to the time, route or size of structure, the city clerk, be authorized, collect a fee in advance for extra manpower required to insure the safety of the move. 
(Ord. No. 74-32, 9-9-74) 
Secs. 6-76—6-86. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT OF ELECTRICAL, PLUMBING, HEATING AND AIR CONDITIONING, AND GAS CODES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 89-6, adopted Mar. 16, 1989, repealed former Ch. 6, Art. V, §§ 6-87—6-94 and 6-102—6-112; Art. VI, §§ 6-124—6-130 and 6-138—6-152; Art. VII, §§ 6-164—6-170; Art. VIII, §§ 6-181—6-184; and Art. IX, §§ 6-196—6-200 and 6-208—6-217; and enacted new Arts. V—X pertaining to similar subject matter to read as herein set out. The repealed provisions derived from the 1964 Code, §§ 7-4, 7-9—7-12, 7-14, 7-15, 7-17, 7-38, 7-41—7-44, 11-2—11-4, 11-10, 11-16, 11-17, 11-30—11-43, 14-1, 21-1, 21-2 and 21-21 and 21-24, and the following ordinances: 

 

Sec. 6-87. - Definitions. 
(a)  Wherever the term "electrical inspector," "plumbing inspector," "heating and air conditioning inspector" or "gas inspector" is used [in the respective codes], it shall mean the person designated by the city manager to administer and enforce the provisions of said code. 
(b)  Wherever the term "corporate counsel" is used in the electrical, plumbing, heating, air conditioning and gas codes, it shall mean the city attorney. 
(c)  Wherever the term "municipality" is used in the electrical, plumbing, heating, air conditioning and gas codes, it shall mean the City of Dublin. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-88. - Enforcement. 
The electrical, plumbing, heating, air conditioning and gas codes adopted by the provisions of this article shall be enforced by the chief building official. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-89. - Penalties. 
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the electrical, plumbing, heating, air conditioning and gas codes or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder, shall, for each such failure or violation or noncompliance, be punished as provided in section 1-10 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-90. - Competence of workers. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to do any work of electrical, plumbing, heating and air conditioning installation, construction, or repair work unless such work is done by or under the supervision of a certificate issued by the state licensing board as required by the building official. It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, install or repair any work pertaining to gas construction unless such work is done by or under the supervision of a certificate issued by the city's gas fitter's examining board. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-91. - Permit application to be made by person doing work; transfer of permits. 
The application or statement for any permit required by this chapter shall be made and submitted by the contractor who proposes to do the work specified in said application. Any permit issued under the terms of this chapter cannot be transferred to any other contractor except by first making application for transfer in writing, which shall be accompanied by a transfer fee of ten dollars ($10.00) which is in addition to the other fees specified by this chapter. No person shall do any such work under a permit issued to any other person unless such permit has first been transferred under the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-92. - Revocation of certificate of registration, permits; appeals. 
(a)  Any contractor certified by the state licensing board and holding a certificate of registration issued by the city, who violates any provisions of this chapter, or who certifies under oath to the building official that he has supervised the installation, construction or repair of any electrical, plumbing, heating, air conditioning and gas work when in fact he has not, shall be cited by the building official to appear before said appropriate board to show cause why his certificate of registration shall not be revoked. After such citation has been personally served upon said certified contractor, he shall have the right to appear before said board and offer such evidence in his behalf as he deems necessary. At the same time the evidence shall be considered by said board. The building official shall be qualified to testify. After hearing the evidence the board shall then by a majority vote find him guilty or not guilty as the evidence warrants. If found guilty, the board may revoke his certificate of registration or impose a suspension of his certificate for a period of up to ninety (90) days. If found not guilty, the charge shall be dropped. If said person cited to appear fails to appear at the specified time and place in the citation, his certificate of registration shall automatically be suspended by the board until such time as he does appear before the board to answer such charges. 
(b)  Any person found guilty under this section shall have the right to appeal such decision to the recorder's court of the city. Such appeal shall be in writing within five (5) days after the decision of judgement appealed from. The hearing before the judge shall be de novo, and if after hearing the evidence the judge finds the board correct, the decision of the board shall be affirmed. If he finds in favor of appellant, such decision shall reverse the decision of the board. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-93. - Certification required. 
No person shall do any electrical, plumbing, heating and air conditioning installation, constructing, or repairing within the city unless he holds a certificate from the state licensing board. It shall be unlawful for any person knowingly to employ another who does not hold a certificate from said board. Helpers under the direct supervision and direction of a person holding one (1) of said certificates and in his direct employment are excluded from the certificate of registration and certification requirements of this division; otherwise one who is a helper shall be included. No person shall construct, repair or make any gas installations unless he holds a competency card from the city's gas fitter's examining board and a certificate of registration issued by the city. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-94. - Business certificate of registration required. 
Every person desiring to engage in the business of electrical, plumbing, heating and air conditioning installation; construction or repairs within the city shall obtain a certificate of registration from the city clerk therefor. Said certificate of registration shall be issued only after presentation of certificate from the state licensing board. A certificate of registration shall be issued for gas construction, installation and repairs within the city after the presentation of a competency card from the city. A certificate of registration shall not be issued unless he has taken the gas fitter's examination and issued a competency card from the city's gas superintendent. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-95. - Due date, certificate of registration; transferability. 
All certificate of registration, occupation and professional taxes set and levied by this article shall be due and payable annually on January 1. In the event that any person commences business or commences practicing a profession subject to tax on any date after January 1 in any year, the tax shall be due and payable on the date of commencement of the business or of the business or the commencement of the practice of a profession subject to tax. The certificate of registration shall not be transferable and the full fee shall be charged for any year or fraction thereof. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-96. - Fraudulent use of contractor's name or certificate of registration. 
No contractor shall allow his name or certificate of registration to be used by any person whether directly or indirectly for the purpose of evading this Code or the ordinances of the city. In case this section is violated, both the contractor and the person using his certificate of registration shall be deemed equally guilty and the act shall be considered a violation of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Secs. 6-97—6-107. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ELECTRICAL CODE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Note— See the editor's note to Art. V of this chapter. 

Sec. 6-108. - Adoption of National Electrical Code. 
There is hereby adopted by the mayor and city council, for the purpose of establishing standards and procedures affecting the installation of electrical systems and electrical materials, the National Electrical Code, 1984 edition, being particularly that code published by the National Fire Protection Association, of which code not less than one (1) copy has been and now is filed in the office of the city clerk, and the same is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the city. All subsequent changes or edition improvements shall be adopted and incorporated for the city upon publication by the National Fire Protection Association. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-109. - Requirements for equipment and appliances. 
No electrical materials, devices or appliances shall be sold, used or installed in the city unless they are in conformity with the provisions of this article, the statutes of the state, the rules and regulations of the city, and the rules and regulations of the National Board of Fire Underwriters and are in conformity with the approved methods of construction for safety to life and property. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-110. - Equipment, appliances to be labeled. 
The maker's name, trademark or other identification symbol, along with the label of the Board of Underwriter's Laboratory, shall be placed on all electrical equipment, devices and appliances used or installed under this article. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove any said labels. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-111. - Temporary wiring and service. 
(a)  Permission required; purposes. Temporary wiring may be installed when written permission is secured from the building official for the following purposes: 
(1)  To be used to supply power for the purpose of hoisting materials used in buildings under construction or being remodeled, and for the purpose of lighting said building or structure used in connection with the construction of such buildings. 
(2)  For the purpose of lighting tents or buildings used for religious gatherings or shows where said tents or buildings will only be used for a period of fourteen (14) days, or for decorative purposes where wiring will only be used for a period of fourteen (14) days. 
(b)  Safety required. Temporary approvals may be used covering work as outlined in this section, when such work is installed in such manner as not to endanger life or property. 
(c)  Authorized for testing or to permit use of completed installations. Temporary approvals may be issued for the purpose of allowing current to be turned on certain parts of wiring installations which are safe to the satisfaction of the building official in order to allow the testing of certain electrical equipment and in order to allow tenants, lessees or owners the use of certain completed parts of buildings before the entire job is completed. 
(d)  Duration. No temporary approval shall be issued for a period of more than ninety (90) days. If it is necessary for temporary work to remain, request for an extension of the temporary approval shall be made in writing by the person holding the permit. 
(e)  Discontinuance upon expiration. Upon expiration of temporary approval such service shall be immediately discontinued, unless approval for an extension of time is obtained from the building official. 
(f)  Contents of application. The application for temporary service shall state the period of time the service is required and the necessity for same. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-112. - Alterations in wiring or load prohibited. 
No alterations shall be made in wiring of any building or structure for light, heat, or power, or increase in the rated load as fixed by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-113. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 18-06, adopted June 21, 2018, repealed § 6-113, which pertained to electrical board; appointment; term and derived from Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89. 
Sec. 6-114. - Permit fees. 
[Permit fees for work performed under this article shall be as follows:] 
For issuing each permit ..... $10.00 
(a)  Residential. Electrical, plumbing, heating and air conditioning values shall be based on one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) per square foot. Permit cost shall be determined on two (2) per cent of the total value. 
(b)  Commercial. Electrical, plumbing, heating and air conditioning permit fees shall be based on per centages, as follows: 
(1)  Up to one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00), the total permit fee shall be based on two (2) per cent of the total cost. 
(2)  More than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) but not exceeding five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00), the total permit fee shall be based on one and three-fourths (1¾) per cent of the total cost. 
(3)  More than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) but not exceeding one million dollars ($1,000,000.00), the total permit fee shall be based on one and one-half (1½) per cent of the total cost. 
(4)  More than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00), the total permit fee shall be based on one (1) per cent of the total cost. 
(Ord. No. 91-1, 1-3-91) 
Secs. 6-115—6-120. - Reserved.

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Note— See the editor's note to Art. V of this chapter.

Sec. 6-121. - Standard Plumbing Code—Adoption. 
There is hereby adopted by the mayor and city council, for the purpose of establishing standards and procedures affecting the installation of plumbing and plumbing materials, the Standard Plumbing Code, 1979 edition, being particularly that code published by the International Building Code, of which code not less than one (1) copy has been and now is filed in the office of the city clerk; and the same is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein; and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the city. All subsequent changes or edition improvements shall be automatically adopted and incorporated for the city upon publication by the International Building Code. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89; Ord. No. 03-04, 3-6-2003) 
Sec. 6-122. - Same—Amendments. 
The Standard Plumbing Code adopted by the provisions of this article is amended, altered, modified and changed in the following respects: 
Table 500. Table 500 of the plumbing code is amended as follows: 
(a)  To allow the use of schedule 40 plastic pipe for water service from the supply connection to the distribution system; and 
(b)  To allow the use of galvanized pipe except under concrete slab. 
Section 1209.1. Section 1209.1 of the plumbing code is amended as follows: that when the shutoff valve is located outside of building, a stop valve shall be required within eight (8) inches of the water meter between the meter and the building structure. 
Section 1210.1. Section 1210.1 of the plumbing code is amended as follows: 
Above ground: 
(1)  To allow the use of type L copper. 
(2)  To prohibit type M copper. 
Below ground: 
(1)  To require that only American-made type K copper may be used under concrete slab. 
Section 1301.4. Section 1301.4 of the plumbing code is amended as follows: to specify schedule 40 plastic pipe as the only type of plastic pipe allowed. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-123. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IX. - GAS CODE[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Note— See the editor's note to Art. V of this chapter. 
Cross reference— Gas, § 24-124 et seq. 

DIVISION I. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-141. - Adoption of Standard Gas Code. 
There is hereby adopted by the mayor and the city council, for the purpose of establishing standards and procedures affecting the installation of gas systems and gas materials, the Standard Gas Code, 1979 edition, being particularly that code published by the International Building Code, of which code not less than one (1) copy has been and now is filed in the office of the city clerk, and the same is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein; and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the city. All subsequent changes or edition improvements shall be automatically adopted and incorporated for the city upon publication by the International Building Code. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89; Ord. No. 03-04, 3-6-2003) 
Sec. 6-142. - Meter connection and location. 
(a)  The piping shall be extended to the meter location designated by the distributor of gas, and a swing joint provided for connecting piping to the meter outlet. 
(b)  No gas meter shall be installed or maintained under the floor of any building or structure. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-143. - Applicability to persons outside city using city gas. 
Any person having property, premises or buildings not within the corporate limits but within the gas service territory of the city, who desires or is required by law to use or connect with any gas main serving the city, shall conform to the laws and ordinances of the city regulating the installation of gas fitting, the securing of permits for, and the inspection of same, and shall abide by the gas regulations of the city. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-144. - Tampering with gas facilities. 
No one except the city natural gas system shall at any time turn on any valve or cock or in any way tamper or make any connection with any gas main, meter, meter connection or gas service pipe between the main and the meter. The user, however may turn off gas at the main jet in case of an emergency. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-145. - Permit fees. 
Permit fees for work performed under this article shall be as follows: 
For issuing each permit ..... $10.00 
Residential and commercial permits cost shall be determined on two (2) per cent of the total value of the work performed. 
(Ord. No. 97-3, 1-23-97) 
Secs. 6-146—6-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - GAS FITTERS 

Sec. 6-151. - Examining board created; membership; compensation; vote required; meetings. 
There is hereby established a gas fitter's examining board, to be appointed by the mayor and board of aldermen, consisting of the gas manager, building official, one (1) member of the board of aldermen, a person engaged in and thoroughly familiar with the gas appliance installation business in the city, together with the mayor, who shall be an ex officio member and chairman thereof. No member of the board shall receive any compensation for his services. A majority vote shall be necessary to determine any decision to be rendered by the board. Meetings of the board shall be held at such times and places as specified by the chairman of the board. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-152. - Examination required; application; fee; issuance of certificate of competency. 
It shall be the duty of the gas fitter's examining board to examine and pass upon the qualifications of every person who may apply for a gas fitter's certificate of competency to do work in the city or its gas service territory, upon forms provided by the city, and who shall have paid to the city clerk an examination fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00). Such applicant shall be examined upon the fundamentals of gas fitting, the laws of the city pertaining to gas installation, the theory and practice of gas installation and construction, and the experience and ability of the applicant in practical gas installation. If such applicant is found to possess an accurate knowledge of the fundamentals of gas fitting, a practical working knowledge of the theory and correct practice of gas installation and construction, a thorough knowledge of the laws of the city relating to gas installation and construction, and sufficient experience and ability in gas installation and construction to safely and competently apply his knowledge in practice, the board shall issue to him a certificate of competency. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-153. - Waiting period required after failing examination. 
If any applicant fails to pass the examination required by this chapter, at least six (6) months must elapse before he will be permitted to take it again. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-154. - Certificate of competency—Duration; renewal. 
Each certificate of competency, whether original or renewal, shall be valid only for the calendar year in which issued and dated, and shall be of no force or effect in any subsequent calendar year. Any holder of an unrevoked or unsuspended certificate for any particular calendar year, whether original or renewal, shall be entitled to a renewal certificate without examination for the next succeeding calendar year upon payment of a renewal fee of ten dollars ($10.00) to the city clerk, provided such holder shall have been actively engaged in the business of gas fitting for not less than three (3) months within a period of one (1) year next preceding application for such renewal. Each duplicate certificate issued by the city clerk for one (1) lost, stolen or otherwise not in the person's possession shall cost ten dollars ($10.00). 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-155. - Same—Not transferable. 
No gas fitter's certificate of competency under the provisions of this chapter shall be transferable or assignable. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-156. - Scope of certificate of registration provisions. 
The requirements of certificate of registration shall apply to all persons, resident or nonresident of the city, when doing work in the city. Provided, however, any person doing work outside the city in its gas service territory shall be issued a permit to do such work in lieu of a certificate of registration, upon the payment of a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) therefor, but in no event shall the requirements be lessened. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-157. - Permit issuance restricted. 
No permit shall be issued for such purpose of gas inspection [installation] except by [to] a gas fitter holding a certificate of competency from the city, to do such work in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Secs. 6-158—6-168. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - HOUSING CODE[8]

Sec. 6-169. - Adoption of Standard Housing Code. 
There is hereby adopted by the mayor and city council, for the purpose of establishing standards and procedures affecting the habitability and sanitary conditions of private premises and structures, the International Property Maintenance Code, 2012 edition, being particularly that code published by the International Code Council, of which code not less than one (1) copy has been and now is filed in the office of the city clerk; and the same is adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein; and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the city. All subsequent changes or edition improvements shall be automatically adopted and incorporated for the city upon publication by the International Code Council. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89; Ord. No. 03-04, 3-6-2003; Ord. No. 18-06, 6-21-2018) 
Sec. 6-170. - Definitions. 
(a)  Wherever the term "housing inspector" is used in the housing code, it shall mean the person designated by the mayor and board of aldermen to administer and enforce the provisions of said code. 
(b)  Wherever the term "corporate counsel" is used in the housing code, it shall mean the city attorney. 
(c)  Wherever the term "municipality" is used in the housing code, it shall mean the City of Dublin. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-171. - Enforcement. 
The housing code adopted herein shall be enforced by the chief building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Sec. 6-172. - Penalties. 
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of the housing code or fail to comply therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any order made thereunder, shall, for each such failure or violation or noncompliance, be punished as provided in section 1-10 of this Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 89-6, 3-16-89) 
Chapter 7 - CEMETERIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Cemeteries, Ga. Code Ann., Ch. 84-51. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - Authority to acquire, maintain. 
The mayor and the city council may acquire and maintain grounds in the city for use as cemeteries. 
(Code 1964, § 6-1) 
Sec. 7-2. - Authority to regulate. 
The mayor and the city council of the city reserve to themselves and their successors in office the right to alter, amend, modify or add to the rules, regulations, conditions and restrictions herein set forth at any time it is deemed advisable so to do, in order to carry out the purposes of this chapter. 
Sec. 7-3. - Management and supervision. 
There shall be a superintendent of municipal cemeteries appointed by the city manager. It shall be the responsibility of the superintendent to look after and take proper care of all municipal cemeteries, and to see that no cemetery property is used or occupied in violation of this chapter or any rule or regulation promulgated by the mayor and board of aldermen and to keep full and detailed accounts of all transactions involving cemetery property. 
Sec. 7-4. - Liability. 
There shall be no liability whatsoever, either tort or contractual, on the part of the city, or its officials or officers, or its agents or employees, to any purchasers of any lots in the cemetery, or to any person holding on to them, or to the family or relatives of any person buried in the cemetery, or to any person or the family of such person who has erected any monument or marker therein, by reason of any act or acts, thing or things, omission, negligence, or otherwise related to said cemetery. 
Sec. 7-5. - Rules for interment. 
No person shall be interred in any municipal cemetery until the superintendent of municipal cemeteries has determined: 
(a)  That the lot in which burial is to be made has been fully paid for; 
(b)  That the person arranging for such burial has the right to use such lot; 
(c)  That such lot is not used beyond its capacity; 
(d)  That proper record is made of the name and age of the deceased person and the exact location of the grave. 
Sec. 7-6. - Enclosures. 
No curbing, fencing or enclosures of any sort shall be erected on, in, or around any burial lot in the cemetery, but the city reserves the right to erect curbing along the walks and drives if it so desires. 
Sec. 7-7. - Plantings. 
The planting of flowers and shrubs or any other effort to improve or beautify any lot within a municipal cemetery shall be done only after the plans for such work have been submitted to the superintendent and approved thereby. Nothing herein contained shall be construed to prohibit the decoration or adornment of any gravesite with potted or cut flowers or plants. 
Sec. 7-8. - Stones and monuments. 
Owners of cemetery lot easements shall have the right to erect proper stones or monuments marking the burial site, except that no slab shall be set other than in a horizontal position and flush with the ground. 
Sec. 7-9. - Trees and shrubs. 
No tree or shrub shall be planted, removed, cut down, or destroyed within the borders of any burial lot, walks, or lawn spaces, without the consent of the superintendent of municipal cemeteries. 
(Code 1964, § 6-3) 
Sec. 7-10. - Injury to monuments. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, deface, or in any manner injure any monument, enclosure, or ornament thereof within any municipal cemetery. 
(Code 1964, § 6-3) 
Sec. 7-11. - Depositing offensive matter. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit on any part of any cemetery or any land adjoining it any dead carcass or any putrid or offensive matter whatever. 
(Code 1964, § 6-3) 
Sec. 7-12. - Advertisements. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to post any advertisement or sign, or to solicit any work in a municipal cemetery. 
Cross reference— Advertising generally, Ch. 3. 
Sec. 7-13. - Unauthorized interments. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to inter any dead body in any part of a municipal cemetery without the express authorization of the superintendent of municipal cemeteries. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to inter any dead body in any part of a municipal cemetery unless said dead body is enclosed in a sealed concrete crypt or vault. 
(Code 1964, § 6-4; Ord. No. 80-9, 4-17-80) 
Sec. 7-14. - Visiting hours. 
Visiting hours for the general public in public cemeteries in the city are hereby established to begin at 7:00 a.m. and to end sunset each evening. 
(Ord. No. 76-4, § I, 1-26-76) 
Secs. 7-15—7-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PURCHASE, CONVEYANCE OF LOTS 

Sec. 7-26. - Lot valuation. 
The city council shall consider and establish a value upon all existing, surveyed lots in the municipal cemetery and shall record such valuation on an official map plan of the cemetery, which map shall be kept on file, open to public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 79-8, 5-7-79; Ord. No. 86-1, 1-2-86; Ord. No. 07-03, 4-5-2007) 
Sec. 7-27. - Method of purchase. 
Any person desiring to purchase an easement in a particular lot or lots for the purpose for which it is intended, shall be permitted to do so upon payment of the price fixed for such lot. 
Sec. 7-28. - Manner of conveying. 
Conveyance of burial lots shall be executed in the name of the city by the mayor and city clerk and shall have affixed thereto the seal of the city. Such conveyances shall not convey fee simple title, but shall convey to the purchaser of each burial lot an easement for the exclusive right of interment and sepulcher in such lot; shall state the maximum number of graves allowed on each such burial lot as shown by the plat; and, by reference therein made, shall convey each lot subject to all the provisions of this chapter as fully as if set out in each such conveyance. 
Sec. 7-29. - Acceptance of provisions. 
In accepting any conveyance of any burial lot, each purchaser agrees that all provisions of this chapter are valid and that any such purchaser and the heirs and assigns thereof shall hold such lot subject to all the provisions of this chapter, and subject to all amendments made hereto by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
Sec. 7-30. - Records of ownership. 
The superintendent shall keep full and complete records of the ownership of all lot easements in the municipal cemeteries, of the burial capacity of each lot, of the location of each grave, of the names and ages of the persons buried in each grave, and the date of the burial of each. 
Sec. 7-31. - Sale or transfer by owner. 
Owners of lots shall not be permitted to sell or transfer lots without the written consent and approval of the superintendent. 
Chapter 8 - COURT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— City court, § 66 et seq. 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2; traffic, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference— Appeals from city court, Ga. Code Ann., Ch. 6-7; municipal courts, Ch. 24-21A et seq. 

Sec. 8-1. - Bailiff. 
(a)  A bailiff or bailiffs of the city court may be appointed by the city judge. 
(b)  The duties of bailiffs shall consist generally of seeing that the courtroom is in proper condition for sessions of court, of assisting in keeping order while court is in session, and of doing such other acts of assistance as may be required of them by the judge of the court and the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 81-22, § 1, 9-3-81) 
Sec. 8-2. - Record of cases. 
A record of all cases heard in the city court for violation of this Code or other municipal ordinances shall be kept in a suitable bound volume. Such record shall contain the name of the defendant, the nature of the offense charged, the final disposition of the case, and the date of final disposition. 
(Ord. No. 81-22, § 1, 9-3-81) 
Sec. 8-3. - Service of summons. 
Any person charged with an offense within the jurisdiction of the city court shall receive notice by service of a summons. Such summons may be issued by the city clerk, building inspector, a city marshal or a police officer of the city. The summons shall be directed to the accused and shall distinctly state the offense charged, the time and place, as far as practicable, of the offense charged, and the day, hour, and place of trial, requiring the accused to appear before the judge of the city court to answer the accusation made. Service of the summons shall be made either by serving the accused personally or by leaving a copy at his most notorious place of abode, except that in the case of a summons issued for violation of laws or ordinances relating to the parking of motor vehicles, such summons may be directed to an unknown person as owner of an automobile designated in the summons and may be served upon such person by leaving a copy in or attached to such automobile. 
(Ord. No. 81-22, § 1, 9-3-81) 
Sec. 8-4. - Subpoenas. 
Upon request, the city clerk of the city court shall issue subpoenas for the appearance of all witnesses for the prosecution or for the defense in any case pending before the city court. Subpoenas may be served in the same manner as a summons or by registered or certified mail. 
(Ord. No. 81-22, § 1, 9-3-81) 
Sec. 8-5. - Failure to obey summons or subpoena. 
Any person who fails to appear at the time and place set out in any summons or subpoena served upon him shall be guilty of contempt of court and upon conviction thereof shall be punished for same. 
Sec. 8-6. - Arrest and bond. 
When a police officer has arrested any person for violation of any provision of this Code or any municipal ordinance and a trial cannot be had immediately, the officer may take a cash bond not exceeding the maximum fine for the offense, or a bond with a good security, for the appearance of such person before the judge of the city court. If such person fails or refuses to give a bond, the officer may confine him or her in the city jail until a trial can be held, provided that the mayor, in his discretion, may release such person on his own recognizance without security. 
(Code 1964, §§ 24-12, 24-13) 
Charter reference— Appearance bonds, § 65. 
Sec. 8-7. - Forfeiture of bond. 
Upon the failure of a person to appear in the city court at the time and place fixed by the summons, the judge of said court shall enter a judgment of forfeiture on any cash bond, or, in the case of a security bond, shall pass a rule requiring the principal and surety on such bond to show cause on the date named therein, which date shall not be less than ten (10) days from the passage of such ruling, why they should not be required to pay the amount of said bond. If no sufficient cause is shown, the judge shall enter judgment against the principal and surety for the amount of the forfeited bond and shall direct the city clerk to issue execution thereon. 
(Code 1964, § 24-14) 
Sec. 8-8. - Surety may surrender principal. 
Any surety upon a bail bond of any person or persons charged with a violation of a provision of this Code or city ordinance may surrender his principal at any time to the marshal or other officer on duty, who shall confine such principal until discharged by order of the court or by giving other and good security. The delivery of the principal as aforesaid shall discharge the surety or sureties of all further liability upon such bond. Provided, that such delivery shall be before any judgment of forfeiture upon said bond shall have been entered; and provided all costs which accrued in any proceeding to forfeit said bond are paid. 
(Code 1964, § 24-15) 
Sec. 8-9. - Malicious prosecution. 
Whenever the judge of the city court, after a fair and full trial, is satisfied that any case was frivolously or maliciously prosecuted, he shall assess the prosecution with the court costs and such punitive damages as he deems appropriate. 
Sec. 8-10. - Collection of fines. 
When directed by the judge of the city court, the city clerk shall issue executions for fines imposed by said court, including the costs, which executions may be levied upon any goods or chattels, lands, or tenements of the person so fined. 
(Code 1964, § 24-4) 
Charter reference— Chain gang, § 125. 
Sec. 8-11. - Suspension of sentence. 
The city judge may suspend any sentence or portion of any sentence if he thinks it is to the interest of the city and for the public good. 
(Code 1964, § 24-3) 
Chapter 9 - ELECTIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Election of mayor and aldermen, § 42; conduct of elections, § 46. 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference— Municipal elections, Ga. Code Ann., Tit. 34A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Adoption of state rules, regulations. 
The rules and regulations promulgated by the state election board which pertain to municipal elections, together with the provisions of the Georgia Municipal Election Code contained in Title 34A of the Georgia Code annotated, are hereby adopted as the rules, regulations, and provisions that shall govern the conduct of municipal general and special elections in this city. 
State Law reference— Authority to adopt state rules, regulations, Ga. Code Ann., § 34A-201. 
Sec. 9-2. - Expenses. 
Such funds as are necessary for the conduct of elections and for the performance of the duties that are specified by this chapter shall be budgeted and appropriated by the mayor and board of aldermen annually, and from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 69-22, § 1-2, 10-20-69) 
State Law reference— Budget, appropriations required, Ga. Code Ann., § 34A-201. 
Secs. 9-3—9-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - REGISTRATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Voter eligibility and registration, §§ 47, 48. 

Sec. 9-16. - Registrars and deputy registrars. 
(a)  Appointment. Registrars and deputy registrars shall be appointed by the mayor and board of aldermen, as necessary, and shall serve at the pleasure of same. One such appointee shall be designated as chief registrar, and such person shall serve as the chief administrative officer of the board of registrars and shall generally supervise and direct the administration of the affairs of said board. All appointments shall be entered on the minutes of the county meeting at which they are made. 
(b)  Qualifications. Registrars and deputy registrars shall be electors of the municipality and shall be able to read, write, and speak the English language. Such appointees, while serving as registrars or deputy registrars or within a period of six (6) months after so serving, shall not be eligible to any nomination or office to be voted for at a primary or election. 
(c)  Oath. Prior to entering upon his duties, each registrar and deputy registrar shall swear to faithfully perform his duties, such oath to be administered by an officer authorized by law to administer the oath. 
(d)  Term of office. Persons appointed to the position of registrar or deputy registrar shall serve for a term of one year and until their successors are appointed and qualified, except in the event of resignation or removal as hereinafter provided. 
(e)  Powers. The registrars and deputy registrars shall exercise those powers and duties and shall be subject to such regulations as are set forth in the Georgia Municipal Election Code, Title 34A of the Code of Georgia of 1933, as amended. 
(f)  Resignation or removal. Any registrar or deputy registrar shall have the right to resign at any time by submitting a resignation to the mayor and board of aldermen. The mayor and board of aldermen shall have the right at any time to remove one or more of such registrars for cause after notice and hearing. If any registrar resigns or is removed for cause, his duties and authority as such shall terminate instanter. In the event of death, resignation, or removal of a registrar or deputy registrar, the mayor and board of aldermen shall appoint a successor who shall serve out the unexpired term. Each such appointment shall be entered on the minutes of the meeting at which the appointment is made. 
(Ord. No. 69-22, § 1-5, 10-20-69) 
Sec. 9-17. - Elector qualifications. 
Any person desiring to vote in any municipal general or special election must (1) register as an elector at least fifteen (15) days prior to the primary or election at which he desires to vote; (2) be a citizen of the state and of the United States; (3) be at least eighteen (18) years of age; and (4) be a resident of this municipality. 
(Ord. No. 69-22, § 1-4, 10-20-69) 
Sec. 9-18. - Registration lists and records. 
The city shall maintain its own registration system. The form of the registration cards shall conform to the provisions of Section 34-609 of the Georgia Code Annotated. The completed registration cards and other papers of the registrars shall be kept in the main office of the board of registrars in the city hall and shall be open to public inspection during usual business hours. 
(Ord. No. 69-22, § 1-4, 10-20-69) 
Sec. 9-19. - Challenge of registration list. 
Any elector of the municipality shall have the right to challenge the registration of any person whose name appears on the registration list in the manner set forth below. 
(a)  Appeal to registrar: Any challenge of a person's right to register shall be made in the first instance to the registrar, who shall upon hearing the evidence decide whether to affirm or reverse the original decision. 
(b)  Appeal to mayor and board of aldermen: Any person asserting a challenge under this section, or any person whose name was omitted from the registration list by the registrar, shall have the right to appeal from the decision of the registrar to the mayor and board of aldermen. If the mayor and board of aldermen should decide, after hearing the evidence of such person and that of the registrar, that the registrar erred in his decision, such body shall direct the registrar to correct the error. 
(Ord. No. 69-22, § 1-4, 10-20-69) 
State Law reference— Challenge of registration, Ga. Code Ann., § 34A-520. 
Sec. 9-20. - Permanency of registration. 
Registration of an elector will remain permanent if the elector votes in at least one election every three (3) years. If such person does not vote in at least one general or special election or primary in a three (3) year period and does not specially request continuation of his registration, then the elector's name will be removed from the registration list and he shall be required to reregister in the manner provided for original registration. 
Sec. 9-21. - Absentee registration. 
Absentee registration shall not be allowed in any municipal primary or general or special election held in the city. 
Secs. 9-22—9-33. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CANDIDATES 

Sec. 9-34. - Filing; notice of candidacy. 
Each candidate desiring to have his name placed on the ballot for an office to be filled in a municipal general or special election shall file personally, or by his agent, notice of his candidacy in the office of the municipal superintendent during the following time period: 
(a)  General election: Between the thirty-second (32nd) and twenty-second (22nd) day prior to the election. 
(b)  Special election: Between the twenty-fifth (25th) and fifteenth (15th) day prior to the election. 
Each filing shall be accompanied by the documents and information required by Section 34A-901 of the Georgia Code Annotated. 
(Ord. No. 75-18, § 1-6, 5-5-75; Ord. No. 80-24, § 1, 9-18-80) 
Sec. 9-35. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 81-21, adopted Sept. 3, 1981, repealed former § 9-35 which pertained to qualification fees and was derived from material included at the time of original codification. 
Sec. 9-36. - Campaign financing disclosure. 
All candidates for municipal public office shall keep all such records and file all such reports as are required by the Georgia Campaign and Financial Disclosure Act. 
Secs. 9-37—9-48. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - VOTING 

Sec. 9-49. - Election officials. 
(1)  Appointment: The following election officials shall be appointed by the mayor and board of aldermen and shall receive such compensation as is provided by same: 
(a)  Municipal election superintendent. 
(b)  Chief manager. 
(c)  Two (2) assistant managers. 
(d)  Clerks, as necessary. 
(2)  Qualifications and powers: The municipal election superintendent and all poll officers shall meet such qualifications and exercise all such powers and duties as are provided in Title 34A of the Georgia Code Annotated. 
(Ord. No. 69-22, § 1-1, 10-20-69) 
Sec. 9-50. - Write-in votes. 
Write-in votes shall be permitted in municipal elections, except that no write-in votes shall be counted in a primary, runoff primary, or runoff election. 
State Law reference— Write-in votes, Ga. Code Ann., §§ 2-1201a, 34A-1124. 
Sec. 9-51. - Absentee ballots. 
Absentee ballots shall be used in all municipal elections, and such use shall be governed by the provisions of Chapter 34A-13 of the Georgia Code Annotated. 
(Ord. No. 69-22, § 1-9, 10-20-69) 
Sec. 9-52. - Contested elections. 
(1)  Petition of contest: Any person wishing to contest the results of a primary or election shall file a petition with the city clerk within five (5) days after the results of the election are certified to the mayor and the board of aldermen, which petition shall set forth in writing one or more of the following grounds: 
(a)  Malconduct, fraud or irregularity by any election official sufficient to change or place in doubt the result; 
(b)  Ineligibility of the defendant for the office in dispute; 
(c)  Illegal votes received, or legal votes rejected, sufficient to change or place in doubt the result; 
(d)  An error in counting the votes or in declaring the result of an election, if such error would change the result; or 
(e)  Any other cause which shows that another was the person legally elected. 
(2)  Notice and hearing: Upon the filing of the contest petition, a hearing shall be set before the mayor and board of aldermen and written notice stating the time and place of the hearing and containing a copy of the contest petition shall be given to all affected candidates. The hearing will take place not less than ten (10) nor more than twenty (20) days after service of the notice upon the affected candidates, and shall be conducted in an informal manner. 
(3)  Determination: The mayor and board of aldermen shall examine the qualifications of electors concerning their right to vote, order a recount of ballots, examine the registration lists, and perform such acts and conduct such examinations as may be deemed necessary to determine the validity of a contest of an election, except that any member of the governing authority included in the contest shall disqualify himself from judging the contest. 
(4)  Appeal: The final determination of the mayor and board of aldermen may be appealed to the superior court of the county in the manner of appeal from a court of probate, except that such appeal shall be made within ten (10) days after determination of the contest by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 69-22, § 1-10, 10-20-69) 
Chapter 10 - FIRE PROTECTION AND PREVENTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Building and construction, Ch. 6; gas code, § 6-41, et seq.; planning and zoning, Ch. 17. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Using water from hydrants prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use water from any fire hydrant for any purpose other than for the extinguishment of fires, or lawful city purposes, except with permission of the city manager. 
(Code 1964, § 8-8) 
Sec. 10-2. - Tampering, interfering with hydrants. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper or interfere with any hydrant of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 8-9) 
Sec. 10-3. - Obstructing entrance to fire station. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct in any manner the entrance to any city fire station house. 
(Code 1964, § 8-10) 
Sec. 10-4. - Damaging fire equipment. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to injure or damage any vehicles, apparatus or other equipment of the fire department. 
(Code 1964, § 8-11) 
Sec. 10-5. - False alarms prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to give or cause to be given or to aid in the giving of any false alarm of fire with intent to deceive the fire department, or to pull the switch of any station or signal box with such intent. 
(Code 1964, § 8-12) 
Sec. 10-6. - Reward for arrest of persons making false alarms. 
The city manager is authorized to pay a reward of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for the arrest, with proof to convict, of any person maliciously sending in a false alarm of fire. 
(Code 1964 § 8-13) 
Sec. 10-7. - Riding on fire trucks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person except duly approved and accepted firemen to mount or ride upon any automobile, truck or other vehicle used in connection with the fire department. 
(Code 1964, § 8-14) 
Secs. 10-8—10-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Authority to fix and establish fire regulations, § 1.4(21); authority to organize and operate fire-fighting agency, § 1.4(37). 

Sec. 10-19. - Composition. 
The fire department of the city shall consist of a chief and such other firemen or assistants as may be named by the city manager. 
(Code 1964, § 8-1) 
Sec. 10-20. - Fire chief to supervise department; reports by city manager. 
The fire chief shall have general supervision over the men and equipment of the fire department. It shall be his duty to see that all trucks, hose, and other equipment are properly cared for and preserved. It shall be the duty of the city manager to report to the mayor and board of aldermen any and all matters or things touching the fire department that should be investigated or acted on by them. 
(Code 1964, § 8-3) 
Sec. 10-21. - Chief to supervise department at fires. 
The fire chief shall have sole direction of the operation and management of the fire department at fires, subject at all times to the orders of the city manager. 
(Code 1964, § 8-4) 
Sec. 10-22. - Assistant chief to act in absence of chief. 
In the absence or disability of the fire chief the next highest ranking officer in the department shall perform the duties of his office. 
(Code 1964, § 8-5) 
Sec. 10-23. - Firemen to obey orders of chief, regulations of department. 
It shall be the duty of the officers and members of the fire department to obey the orders of the chief of the department, and at all times to respect and obey the rules and regulations adopted for the government of the department, under penalty of suspension or expulsion. 
(Code 1964, § 8-6) 
Sec. 10-24. - Duties of fire chief, police at fires. 
It shall be the duty of the fire chief to attend in person or send some other member of the fire department in response to every fire call in the city. It shall be the duty of the chief of police or other policeman to attend all fires; to see that proper order is observed at said fires; to see that the members of the fire department are protected in the discharge of their duties; to see that all people in the vicinity of a fire are kept at a sufficient distance from the fire; to see that traffic in and around any fire or fires is properly regulated; to see that all official orders of the fire department are obeyed and to do any and every other thing that may be necessary for the safety and welfare of those attending said fire or fires. 
(Code 1964, § 8-7) 
Secs. 10-25—10-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 

Sec. 10-36. - Adopted. 
The Standard Fire Prevention Code, 1985 Edition, and any future updates, recommended by the International Building Code, and the Life Safety Code 101, 1985 Edition, and any future updates, recommended by the National Fire Prevention Association are hereby adopted, ordained and enacted and shall be in full force and effect in the city; and the same are hereby incorporated by reference herein and made a part of this Code. Failure to observe and abide by the said codes shall be punished as provided by section 1-10 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 67-30, 11-6-67; Ord. No. 88-12, 3-3-88; Ord. No. 03-04, 3-6-2003) 
State Law reference— Any and all fire safety laws that come under the authority of the state fire marshal must be met before any building permit or occupancy permit can be issued by the city, O.C.G.A. § 25-2. 
Sec. 10-37. - Fire chief to be fire marshal, chief of bureau of fire prevention. 
The chief of the fire department, subject to approval by the state safety fire commissioner, shall be fire marshal for the city. He shall also be chief of the bureau of fire prevention. 
(Code 1964, § 8-27) 
Sec. 10-38. - Burning grass, trash. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to set fire to and burn any grass, leaves or other trash, except with written permission of the fire chief. 
(Code 1964, § 8-32; Ord. No. 88-12, 3-3-88) 
Sec. 10-39. - Fence required at bulk plants; exception. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to have or maintain within the city bulk plant or bulk tank or tanks for the storage of gasoline or other petroleum products unless such bulk plant or such tank or tanks shall be completely enclosed and surrounded by a fence not less than seven (7) feet in height, topped by not less than three (3) strands of barb wire. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to retail service stations dispensing gasoline or other petroleum products on a retail basis only, but shall apply only to wholesale dealers and distributors and agents engaged in wholesale distribution of gasoline or other petroleum products and maintaining with the city a storage plant or storage tank or tanks for such products. 
(Code 1964, § 8-31) 
Sec. 10-40. - Rules and regulations for commercial buildings. 
The following code abbreviations are used in this section: 
IBC—International Building Code. 
NFPA—National Fire Protection Association. 
SFMO—State Fire Marshal's Office. 
(a)  Construction. All buildings must be constructed according to all applicable IBC regulations, 1985 Edition, and any future updates; and the NFPA Life Safety 101 Code, 1985 Edition, or any future updates. 
(1)  All commercial buildings must be fire-resistive construction, except noncombustible construction sprinklered according to NFPA 13. 
(2)  All buildings that are occupied on a twenty-four-hour basis (hospitals, nursing homes, personal care homes, etc.) must be fire-restrictive construction and sprinklered according to NFPA 13. 
(b)  Automatic smoke detection. All buildings must have totally interconnected automatic smoke detection systems installed according to current NFPA and IBC codes. 
(c)  Manual fire alarm and communication. All buildings must have a manual fire alarm and communication system installed according to current NFPA and IBC codes. All alarm systems must be interconnected with a centrally located annunciator panel located at the main entrance of the building and visible from the outside, unless manner twenty-four (24) hours continuously. 
(d)  Automatic sprinkler protection. All buildings occupied on a twenty-four-hour basis must be totally sprinklered according to NFPA 13 and maintained accordingly. 
(e)  Stairwells. All stairwells must be a minimum two-hour separation full masonry construction and sprinklered according to NFPA codes. Exits leading to stairwells must not exceed two hundred (200) feet apart with clearly marked paths of travel and appropriate exit and emergency lights installed according to NFPA codes. 
(f)  Corridors. All corridors in commercial buildings must be thirty-minute rated from floor to roof deck of each floor. Spacing under corridors, if used for open-air space, must be a minimum two-hour rated or sprinklered. All corridors in a building occupied on a twenty-four-hour basis must be one-hour rated from floor to roof deck of each floor. Spacing under corridors must be a minimum two-hour rated and sprinklered. 
(g)  Hose cabinets, standpipes and extinguishers. Hose cabinets, standpipes (2½" NST with 1½" NST reducing caps) and fire extinguishers (minimum 2A 40 BC rated) must be located just inside a building or the corridor next to the stairwells (location to be approved by the fire chief). Hose racks are to be filled with a minimum of two hundred (200) feet of 1½-inch hose, NST, coupled with fifty (50) sections, lined (single or double jacket) 600-pound test. One-and-one-half-inch nozzle needs to be a minimum 95 GPM ¼-turn valve (recommend spinning tooth nozzle). Nozzles must be approved by the fire chief. The hose, nozzle, cabinet, standpipe and fire extinguisher must meet NFPA and IBC codes. 
(h)  Elevator shafts. In commercial buildings, elevator shafts must be two-hour separation, full masonry construction. In buildings occupied on a twenty-four hour basis (hospitals, nursing homes, personal care homes, etc.), elevator shafts must be four-hour rated, full masonry construction. 
(Ord. No. 88-12, 3-3-88; Ord. No. 96-5, 3-7-96; Ord. No. 03-04, 3-6-2003) 
Chapter 10½ - FLOOD DAMAGE PREVENTION[1] 
ARTICLE I.  STATUTORY AUTHORIZATION, FINDINGS OF FACT, PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVES 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 10-13, adopted Aug. 5, 2010 amended ch. 10½ in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former ch. 10½, §§ 10½-1—10½-35, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from: Ord. No. 90-13, Arts. 1—6, adopted May 17, 1990. 

Sec. 10½-1. - Authorization. 
Article IX, Section II of the Constitution of the State of Georgia and O.C.G.A. § 36-35-3, have delegated the responsibility to local governmental units to adopt regulations designed to promote the public health, safety and general welfare of its citizenry. Therefore, the Mayor and Council of The City of Dublin, Georgia, has ordained the following. 
(Ord. No. 10-13, 8-5-2010) 
Sec. 10½-2. - Findings of fact. 
(a)  The flood hazard areas of Dublin, Georgia are subject to periodic inundation which results in loss of life and property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services, extraordinary public expenditures for flood relief and protection, and impairment of the tax base, all of which adversely affect the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(b)  These flood losses are caused by the occupancy in flood hazard areas of uses vulnerable to floods, which are inadequately elevated, floodproofed, or otherwise unprotected from flood damages, and by the cumulative effect of obstructions in floodplains causing increases in flood heights and velocities. 
(Ord. No. 10-13, 8-5-2010) 
Sec. 10½-3. - Statement of purpose. 
It is the purpose of this chapter to promote the public health, safety and general welfare and to minimize public and private losses due to flood conditions in specific areas by provisions designed to: 
(1)  Require that uses vulnerable to floods, including facilities, which serve such uses, be protected against flood damage at the time of initial construction; 
(2)  Restrict or prohibit uses which are dangerous to health, safety and property due to water or erosion hazards, or which increase flood heights, velocities, or erosion; 
(3)  Control filling, grading, dredging and other development which may increase flood damage or erosion; 
(4)  Prevent or regulate the construction of flood barriers which will unnaturally divert floodwaters or which may increase flood hazards to other lands; and 
(5)  Control the alteration of natural floodplains, stream channels, and natural protective barriers, which are involved in the accommodation of floodwaters. 
(Ord. No. 10-13, 8-5-2010) 
Sec. 10½-4. - Objectives. 
The objectives of this chapter are: 
(1)  To protect human life and health; 
(2)  To minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water and gas mains, electric, telephone and sewer lines, streets and bridges located in floodplains; 
(3)  To help maintain a stable tax base by providing for the sound use and development of flood-prone areas in such a manner as to minimize flood blight areas; 
(4)  To minimize expenditure of public money for costly flood control projects; 
(5)  To minimize the need for rescue and relief efforts associated with flooding and generally undertaken at the expense of the general public; 
(6)  To minimize prolonged business interruptions; and 
(7)  To insure that potential homebuyers are notified that property is in a flood area. 
(Ord. No. 10-13, 8-5-2010) 
Secs. 10½-5—10½-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 10½-31. - Lands to which this article applies. 
This article shall apply to all areas of special flood hazard within the jurisdiction of Dublin, Georgia. 
Sec. 10½-32. - Basis for area of special flood hazard. 
(a)  The areas of special flood hazard identified by the Federal Emergency Management Agency in its Flood Insurance Study (FIS), dated December 17, 2010, with accompanying maps and other supporting data and any revision thereto, are adopted by reference and declared a part of this chapter. 
(b)  For those land areas acquired by a municipality through annexation, the current effective FIS dated December 17, 2010, with accompanying maps and other supporting data and any revision thereto, for Laurens County, Georgia are hereby adopted by reference. 
(c)  Areas of special flood hazard may also include those areas known to have flooded historically or those that are defined through standard engineering analysis by governmental agencies or private parties but that are not yet incorporated in an FIS including: 
(1)  Any flood or flood-related study conducted by the United States Army Corps of Engineers, the United States Geological Survey or any other local, state or federal agency applicable to the City of Dublin; or 
(2)  Any base flood study authored by a registered professional engineer in the State of Georgia which has been prepared using FEMA-approved methodology as approved by the City of Dublin. 
(d)  The repository for public inspection of the flood insurance study (FIS), accompanying maps and other supporting data is in the Office of the City Engineer, 100 Church Street, Dublin, Georgia 31021. 
(Ord. No. 10-13, 8-5-2010) 
Sec. 10½-33. - Establishment of development permit. 
A development permit shall be required in conformance with the provisions of this article prior to the commencement of any development activities. 
(Ord. No. 10-13, 8-5-2010) 
Sec. 10½-34. - Compliance. 
No structure or land shall hereafter be located, extended, converted or altered without full compliance with the terms of this article and other applicable regulations. 
(Ord. No. 10-13, 8-5-2010) 
Sec. 10½-35. - Abrogation and greater restrictions. 
This article is not intended to repeal, abrogate, or impair any existing ordinance, easements, covenants or deed restrictions. However, where this article and another conflict or overlap, whichever imposes the more stringent restrictions shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 10-13, 8-5-2010) 
Sec. 10½-36. - Interpretation. 
In the interpretation and application of this article all provisions shall be: (1) considered as minimum requirements; (2) liberally construed in favor of the governing body; and (3) deemed neither to limit, nor repeal any other powers granted under state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 10-13, 8-5-2010) 
Sec. 10½-37. - Warning and disclaimer of liability. 
The degree of flood protection required by this article is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on scientific and engineering considerations. Larger floods can and will occur; flood heights may be increased by manmade or natural causes. This article does not imply that land outside the areas of special flood hazard or uses permitted within such areas will be free from flooding or flood damages. This article shall not create liability on the part of the City of Dublin, Georgia or by any officer or employee thereof, for any flood damages that result from reliance on this article or any administrative decision lawfully made hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 10-13, 8-5-2010) 
Sec. 10½-38. - Penalties for violation. 
Failure to comply with the provisions of this chapter or with any of its requirements, including conditions and safeguards established in connection with grants of variance or special exceptions shall constitute a violation.
