(g)  Scattering of refuse and littering prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(1)  Throw or deposit any refuse on any public or private street or to scatter such refuse or litter on any private or public property. 
(2)  Throw or deposit any refuse, trash, or debris in any marsh area, stream, drainage ditch, body of water or beach area. 
(3)  Dump, deposit, throw or leave, or cause or permit the dumping, deposition, placing, throwing or leaving of litter from a motor vehicle on the right-of-way of any public road or highway in the city unless: 
a.  Such right-of-way is designated by city for the disposal of such litter, and such person is authorized by the proper authority to use such right-of-way, or 
b.  Such litter is placed into a litter receptacle or container installed on such right-of-way. 
(4)  Whenever litter is thrown, deposited, dropped or dumped from any motor vehicle in violation of this section, it shall be prima facie evidence that the operator of said motor vehicle shall have violated this chapter. 
(h)  Use of streets. It shall be unlawful for any vehicle transporting loose materials on any street to transport same without suitable covers securely fastened to the vehicle. This section shall not apply to the transportation of poultry, livestock, silage or other feed grain used in the feeding of poultry or livestock. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-58. - Handbills and advertising matter. 
In addition to the activities declared to be in violation of this chapter as set forth in section 11-57, the following activities are hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a violation of this chapter. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to place in or on any automobile in the city any handbill, circular, pamphlet, poster, or other literature except with the express permission of the owner or the occupant of such automobile. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place on any private property any handbill, circular, pamphlet, poster, postcard, or other literature, except with the express permission of the owner of the property or intended recipient. This section shall not apply to multipage printed publications placed in mailbox or placed in a secure area of a building such as a door jam, screen door, etc. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to tack, post or nail any paper, metal, wood or other signs of any character on any telegraph, telephone or electric light pole, located in any public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-59. - Parking lots. 
(a)  All parking lots and establishments with parking lots shall provide refuse receptacles within the parking area. The director shall have the authority to determine the number and types of receptacles necessary to provide proper containerization. Such receptacles shall be weighted or attached to the ground as necessary to prevent spillage. It shall be the responsibility of the owner or his agent to collect the refuse and trash deposited in such containers and store this material in a location until collected by the city. 
(b)  It shall be the obligation of all persons using the parking areas to place any litter in receptacles or containers and it shall be unlawful for any person or persons to dump, scatter, or throw on any parking lot, any refuse, garbage or trash of any kind. Restaurants with drive-in facilities shall install receptacles with long necks at exit points. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-60. - Construction sites and demolition sites. 
All construction and demolition contractors shall provide on-site refuse receptacles, bulk containers, or detachable containers for loose debris, paper, building material waste, scrap building materials, and other trash produced by those working at the construction site. The site shall be kept in a litter-free condition. The number of refuse receptacles (not to exceed four (4)) or bulk containers, or detachable containers, shall be determined by the size of the job. Dirt, mud, construction materials or other debris upon any public or private property belonging to a person other than the owner of the construction site shall be removed by the contractor upon completion of the construction. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-61. - Holidays. 
Collections shall not be made on the following holidays, unless otherwise specified by the director: New Year's Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day, Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day and other holidays as specified by the city. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-62. - Industrial waste. 
Industrial waste shall be collected, removed and disposed of by any factory, plant or enterprise creating or causing said waste. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-63. - Building materials. 
The city shall not be responsible for the collecting or hauling of building material originating from private property preliminary to, during or subsequent to the construction of new building, alterations or additions to an existing building of whatever type or from demolition of existing structures. Such material shall be removed by the owner of the property or by the contractor. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-64. - Contagious disease refuse. 
The removal of clothing, bedding or other refuse from home or other places where highly infectious diseases have prevailed shall be decontaminated prior to removal under the supervision and direction of the Laurens County Health Department. Such refuse shall not be placed in receptacles or bulk containers for city collection until decontaminated. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-65. - Hypodermic instruments. 
No person shall dispose of or discard any hypodermic syringe, hypodermic needle or any instrument or device for making hypodermic injections before first breaking, disassembling, destroying or otherwise rendering inoperable and incapable of reuse, such hypodermic syringe, needle, instrument or device, and without safeguarding the disposal thereof, by wrapping or securing same in a suitable manner so as to avoid the possibility of causing injury to the collection personnel. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-66. - Collection and disposal. 
All persons who desire to haul refuse over roads which are a part of the city road system shall use a vehicle provided with a cover and operate it so as to prevent refuse from being dropped, blown, or spilled therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-67. - Maintenance of property. 
(a)  Generally. All owners or occupants of property shall maintain their property in a litter-free condition. 
(b)  Sweeping into sidewalks or street. No person shall sweep into or deposit in any street or sidewalk the accumulation of litter from any building or property. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-68. - Nuisances designated. 
Within the city, it shall be unlawful for any person to create a nuisance on his property or property occupied by him, or to allow a nuisance to remain on his property or property occupied by him as defined by chapter 13 of this code. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-68.1. - State law adopted regulating littering and enforcement thereof. 
(a)  Adoption by reference. Pursuant to Georgia Code, Section 16-7-43(b) of that title known as "Dumping, depositing, etc. litter on public or private property or waters" is hereby adopted with like effect as if recited herein. 
(b)  Enforcement. Unless expressly prohibited by other law, the enforcement provisions contained in Georgia Code, Section 16-7-45 is hereby adopted with like effect as if recited herein. 
(Ord. No. 85-7, §§ 1, 2, 2-20-85) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 85-7, §§ 1, 2, adopted Feb. 20, 1985, not expressly amendatory of the Code, has been included herein as § 11-68.1, at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 11-69. - Littering and noxious deposits prohibited. 
No person shall throw or deposit, or cause to be thrown or deposited upon the streets, sidewalks, lanes or alleys or to any storm sewer, catch basin or drainage ditch, any paper, garbage or other waste matter. No person shall deposit on or bury in, or cause to be deposited on or buried in, any of the land, public square, street, alley, lanes, vacant or unoccupied lot, or into any lake or watercourse, any noxious filth, odors or offensive liquid, solid material within the limits of the city except in standard approved garbage receptacles from which regular collections are made. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-70. - Littering prohibited generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, drop, cast or deposit upon any street, alley, sidewalk or any yard or premises, public or private, any filth of any kind, or cans, paper, trash, paper containers, rubbish, tree limbs, grass cuttings, bottles or any other form of litter or waste matter. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-71. - Duty of business owners, occupants. 
The owner or occupant of any store or other place of business situated within the city shall at all times keep his premises clean of wastepaper, wrapping paper, paper napkins, cartons, package containers and other used or waste materials thrown or left on such premises by its customers, and to prevent the same drifting or blowing to adjoining premises. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-72. - Collection personnel not to enter buildings or accept money. 
Garbage and collection personnel are not permitted to enter buildings for the collection of refuse nor shall they accept any money for their services from persons served. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-73. - Bulk refuse containers. 
(a)  The city manager is hereby granted full authority to designate the number and location of detachable bulk refuse containers. 
(b)  Owners of all multifamily dwelling units containing eight (8) or more units shall be required to have detachable bulk refuse containers located on the premises of such properties for the collection of trash and garbage unless expressly relieved of this requirement by the city manager. Relief from this provision may be granted due to certain characteristics of the terrain and buildings which would make it difficult to locate bulk containers on the premises or have bulk containers serviced by service vehicles. Owners of all duplex and multifamily dwelling units shall be required to make payment of the refuse collection and disposal fee directly to the city. The fee for all multifamily units containing less than eight (8) units or other multifamily units not receiving bulk container service shall be the minimum residential rate per family units as established in section 11-39 of this article. 
(c)  No vehicle shall be parked in such a manner that detachable containers are blocked to access by the collection truck during the hours designated for collection. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
ARTICLE II. - WEED AND OTHER REFUSE REMOVAL 

Sec. 11-74. - Lands to be kept free from certain weeds. 
All lands in the city shall be kept free from weeds of a height exceeding eighteen (18) inches. The word "weeds" as used in this section shall include all rank vegetable growth which emit obnoxious or unpleasant odors or which might be a source of disease or physical distress to human beings, and the word "weed" shall also be deemed to include all high and rank vegetable growth that may conceal pools of water, trash, filth or any other deposits which may be detrimental to health. The existence of any such weeds is declared to be a nuisance and shall be abated in accordance with Chapter 13 of this code. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-75. - Lands to be kept free from trash, filth, litter, etc. 
All lands in the city shall be kept free from any kind of trash, filth, or litter, including specifically but without limitation any broken tree limbs, leaves or branches, any uncontained garbage or refuse or any other type of material which might be otherwise detrimental to the health or safety of the inhabitants of the city. The existence of any such trash or filth is declared to be a nuisance and shall be abated in accordance with Chapter 13 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Secs. 11-76—11-87. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ABANDONED, WRECKED OR JUNKED VEHICLES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Abandoned property generally, § 13-19 et seq. 

Sec. 11-88. - Leaving on private property more than fifteen days; duty of owners of vehicle and premises. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to park, store or leave or permit parking or storing of any licensed or unlicensed motor vehicle of any kind or parts thereof, for a period of time in excess of fifteen (15) days, which is in rusted, wrecked, junked, partially dismantled, inoperative or abandoned condition, whether attended or not, upon any private property within the city, unless the same is completely enclosed within a building, or unless it is in connection with a business enterprise lawfully situated and licensed for the same. 
(b)  The accumulation and storage of one or more of such vehicles or parts thereof, as hereinbefore defined, on private property shall constitute a nuisance, detrimental to the health, safety and welfare of inhabitants of the city, and it shall be the duty of the registered owner of such vehicle or parts thereof, and it shall also be the duty of the owner of the private property, or lessee or the person in possession of private property upon which such vehicle or parts thereof is located, to remove the same from the city, or to have the same housed in a building where it will not be visible from the street. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-89. - Notice to owner of vehicle or land to remove vehicle. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the city manager or his designee to give written notice to the registered owner of any motor vehicle or parts thereof which is in violation of this article, or to give such notice to the owner or lessee of private land on which such motor vehicle or parts thereof is situated, giving notice that such vehicle or parts thereof violates this article, and demanding that such motor vehicle or parts thereof be removed from the city within fifteen (15) days or that within fifteen (15) days the same be housed in a building where it will not be visible from the street. Such notice may be given by personal service, or by certified mail, with a return receipt requested. 
(b)  Written notice required by this section shall be deemed to have been given, i.e., constructive notice, when the registered owner of the motor vehicle or parts thereof, or the owner, lessee or other person in possession of private property concerned herein, either; 
(1)  Refuses to accept the prepaid United States mail certified letter from the city and same is returned from the post office marked "refused"; or 
(2)  Such person to be notified is present in the city but the notification letter is returned marked "unclaimed" by the post office, in which event notice by the city may be made by affixing the letter in a conspicuous place at the main entrance or to the front door of the residence of such person. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-90. - Public notice when owners cannot be found. 
(a)  After diligent search and inquiry by the city manager or his designee, no written notice as above shall be required where the registered owner of such vehicle or parts thereof or the owner of the private property or lessee or other person in possession of private property upon which such vehicle or parts thereof is located cannot be found or determined, but instead a public notice shall be posted by the city clerk on the city hall bulletin board for five (5) consecutive days. 
(b)  Such public notice shall include among other information, "Public Notice; To Whom It May Concern," date, legal description of the situs, address of same, a full description of the motor vehicle or parts thereof; when available, the last known owner of the vehicle or owner of the realty or both or the last known person in possession of the situs, and the date from or approximate period of time during which such nuisance has existed. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-91. - Removal of vehicle by city; costs of removal. 
In the event that any of the persons described in subsection 11-88(b), whether an individual, firm or corporation, fail, neglect or refuse to remove the abandoned, wrecked or junked vehicle or parts thereof, the city or its agent or contractor may remove the abandoned, wrecked or junked vehicle or parts thereof at a cost not to exceed twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and a minimum cost of five dollars ($5.00), as determined by the city; which cost, if in the best interests of the city, as determined by the city manager, may be collected from the registered owner of such vehicle or parts thereof or the owner of the private property or lessee or other person in possession of private property upon which such vehicle or parts thereof is located. Ownership of any vehicle or parts thereof removed by the city, its agent or contractor shall, upon such removal, be vested in the city, its agent or contractor, as applicable. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-92. - Penalty; execution of sales agreement in lieu of costs or penalty. 
Any person who shall violate the provisions of section 11-88 shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided in sections 1-10 and 1-11 provided that, if the person receiving the notice provided for in section 11-89 or section 11-90 executes a sales agreement in a form similar to that below, the city, its agent or contractor will remove the vehicle or parts thereof at no cost to the person receiving such notice, and no warrant for arrest will be issued. 
Sales Agreement
KNOW ALL MEN by these presents, that in consideration of an offer by the City of Dublin, Georgia, or its agent or contractor _______ whose address is _______ to remove at either no cost to the undersigned or at a cost of $_______ (dollars) to the undersigned the hereinafter described abandoned, wrecked or junked vehicle or parts thereof from certain premises in the City, the undersigned warrants (that he is the owner of the vehicle) (that he is the owner or occupant of the property where the vehicle is located), and hereby grants, bargains, sells, transfers and delivers unto the City of Dublin or its agents the following described abandoned, wrecked or junked vehicle or parts thereof: 
_____ _____ Location _____ Dated this _____ day of _______, 19___.  Witnesses: 
_____ Owner-Seller-Occupant 
Residence: _____ _____ 
Phone No.: _____ 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-93. - Authority of city manager to contract. 
The city manager is authorized to enter into a written agreement with a duly licensed junk dealer for the removal of abandoned, wrecked or junked vehicles or parts thereof under this article, wherein the consideration for the services of such junk dealer shall be the vehicle or parts thereof at no expense to the city. Such junk dealer, before entering into contract with the city or being appointed its agent or contractor in reference to sections 11-91 and 11-92 shall furnish evidence of public liability insurance to adequately protect such agent or contractor and the city, deemed reasonable in the opinion of the city manager. In the event a qualified and suitable junk dealer is not available to contract with or act as the city's agent or contractor, as provided herein, the city manager is authorized to contract with the lowest responsible bidder to provide for the removal from private property of abandoned, wrecked or junked vehicles or parts thereof under section 11-91. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-94. - Powers and duties of director of sanitation. 
The powers and duties of the director of sanitation shall be to enforce the provisions of this article and for such purpose the director shall have all the power of a police officer of the city. He or his designated representative may enter any building or upon any premises, private or public, for the purpose of making inspection, upon presentation of proper credentials in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Sec. 11-95. - Effect on other laws. 
This article shall not affect section 13-22 of this Code but shall be deemed to be in addition thereto. 
(Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
ARTICLE IV. - FEES 

Sec. 11-96. - Waiver and limitation for certain residential users. 
(a)  The sanitation use fee for residential premises shall be waived upon proper notification to the city clerk that all of the following conditions are existing: 
(1)  No type of business or service is provided at the residence. 
(2)  Head of household is aged sixty-two (62) years or more. 
(3)  Income of head of household from all sources is under five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) per year. 
(4)  Assets besides residence are under five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
(5)  No other resident is making any income. 
(6)  No tenants live in the residence. 
(7)  It is not a public housing or subsidized housing unit. 
(8)  Regulation garbage containers are used. 
(b)  The sanitation use fee for residential premises shall be five dollars ($5.00) per household upon proper notification to the city clerk that all of the following conditions are existing: 
(1)  No type of business or service is provided at the residence. 
(2)  Head of household is aged sixty-two (62) years or more. 
(3)  Only one person in household and income from all sources is more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) but less than eight thousand dollars ($8,000.00) per year, or only two (2) persons in household and income from all sources is more than six thousand dollars ($6,000.00) but less than twelve thousand dollars ($12,000.00) per year. 
(4)  Assets besides residence are under ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00). 
(5)  No tenants live in the residence. 
(6)  It is not a public housing or subsidized housing unit. 
(7)  Regulation garbage containers are used. 
(c)  It should be incumbent upon the city clerk to establish the means to certify the conditions set forth above. The city clerk shall reexamine the qualifications of each household for waiver of the sanitation fee from time to time as necessary. 
(Ord. No. 75-23, § 10-13; 1-7-75; Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83; Ord. No. 87-25, 9-3-87; Ord. No. 90-22, 11-15-90; Ord. No. 92-1, 2-20-92; Ord. No. 95-4, 2-16-95) 
Sec. 11-97. - Obligation for payment of fees. 
The failure of any person to accept or take advantage of the services of the sanitation department in removing garbage shall not relieve such person of the obligation to pay such fees unless authorized by the mayor and board of aldermen; provided however, no fees shall be assessed or charged by the city to a commercial establishment for commercial collection service from a franchisee of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 10-15; Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83; Ord. No. 84-15, 8-16-84) 
Sec. 11-98. - Due date of fees; penalties for nonpayment. 
All bills for garbage collection service shall be due and payable at the office of the city clerk on the first day of each month, and if said bills are not paid by the tenth of the month a ten (10) per cent delinquency penalty shall be added. If said bills are not paid by the twentieth of the month, garbage collection and water service shall be discontinued without further notice. Provided, however, that when the first, tenth, or twentieth of the month falls on a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday, said bills shall become due, said penalty shall attach or said service shall be discontinued on the next succeeding business day after the first, tenth or twentieth. 
(Code 1964, § 10-15; Ord. No. 83-1, 1-20-83) 
Chapter 11½ - IMPACT FEES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 11½-1—11½-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER AND WASTEWATER 

Sec. 11½-26. - Short title, authority and applicability. 
(a)  This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Dublin Water and Wastewater Impact Fee Ordinance". 
(b)  The city has the authority to adopt this article pursuant to the "Home Rule" provisions of the Constitution of the State of Georgia and Title 36, Chapter 71 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated (O.C.G.A.). This article is constructed in accordance the Georgia Development Impact Fee Act (DIFA); (O.C.G.A. § 36-71). 
(c)  This article shall apply to all land receiving water and/or wastewater treatment services from the city, incorporated and unincorporated land alike. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § 1, 9-16-2004) 
Sec. 11½-27. - Intent and purposes. 
(a)  This article is intended to implement and be consistent with the city's comprehensive land use plan adopted in accordance with O.C.G.A. Title 36, Chapter 70, and pursuant to the standards and procedures established by state agencies where applicable. 
(b)  The purpose of this article is to regulate the use and development of land so as to assure that new development bears a proportionate share of the cost of water and wastewater treatment system improvements necessary to provide water and wastewater treatment capacity needed to serve new development in Dublin and the surrounding areas. It is specifically acknowledged that this article has approached the problem of determining said proportionate share in a conservative and reasonable manner, in accordance with O.C.G.A. Title 36, Chapter 71. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § 2, 9-16-2004) 
Sec. 11½-28. - Rules of construction. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall be liberally construed so as to effectively carry out its purpose in the interest of the public's health, safety and welfare. 
(b)  For the purposes of administration and enforcement of this article, unless otherwise stated in this article, the following rules of construction shall apply to the text of this article: 
(1)  In case of any difference of meaning or implication between the text of this article and any caption, illustration, summary table, or illustrative table, the text of this article shall control. 
(2)  The word "shall" is mandatory and not discretionary; the word "may" is permissive. 
(3)  Words used in the present tense shall include the future; and words used in the singular shall include the plural, and the plural shall include the singular, unless the context clearly indicates the contrary. 
(4)  The phrase "used for" includes "arranged for", "designed for", "maintained for", or "occupied for". 
(5)  The word "person" includes an individual, a corporation, a partnership, an incorporated association, or any other similar entity. 
(6)  Unless the text clearly indicates the contrary, where a regulation involves two (2) or more items, conditions, provisions or events connected by the conjunction "and", "or", or "either…or", the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows: 
a.  "And" indicates that all connected terms, conditions, provisions or events shall apply. 
b.  "Or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or events may apply singly but not in combination. 
c.  "Either…or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or events shall apply singly but not in combination. 
(7)  The word "includes" shall not limit a term to the specific example but is intended to extend its meaning to all other instances or circumstances of like kind or character. 
(8)  Any water or wastewater facility, easement or right-of-way used to define water and wastewater impact fee district boundaries may be considered within any district it bounds for the purpose of the assessment and utilization of these fees. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § 3, 9-16-2004) 
Sec. 11½-29. - Definitions. 
Building permit means the document issued by the City of Dublin authorizing the construction, repair, alteration or addition to a structure, or authorizing the installation of a manufactured home or recreational vehicle. For the purpose of this article, a building permit also means a "change of use permit". 
Capital improvement means an improvement with a useful life of ten (10) years of more. 
Capital improvement program means that portion of the city comprehensive land use plan which sets out projected needs for system improvements during a planning horizon established that will meet the anticipated need for system improvements, and a description of anticipated funding sources for each required improvement. 
City means Dublin, Georgia, but may also be interchangeable with the city council, as the context requires. 
Comprehensive plan means the city comprehensive land use plan. 
Developer means any individual, corporation, partnership, association or any other similar entity who engages in development activity. 
Development activity means any construction or expansion of a building, structure, any change in the use of a building or structure, additional plumbing fixtures to a building, additional water and/or wastewater treatment services provided to a building, or any change in the use of land requiring the issuance of a building permit. 
Director means the city engineer and/or the officials designated to administer the various provisions of this article. 
Encumber means to legally obligate by contract, resolution or otherwise commit to use by appropriation by an official act of the city. 
Facility expansion fee district means a geographic area identified by the city in which a defined water and/or wastewater facility is provided. 
Fee payor means that person who pays an impact fee or his successor in interest with the right of entitlement to any refund of a previously paid impact fee which is required by this article and which has been expressly transferred or assigned to the successor in interest. In the absence of an expressed transfer or assignment of the right of entitlement to any refund of previously paid impact fees, the right of entitlement shall be deemed to "run with the land". 
Individual fee calculation study means a water and/or wastewater demand engineering and/or economic report or documentation prepared by a fee payor to allow determination of the impact fee other than by use of the fee schedule established by the city. 
Individual fee determination means the impact fee determined by the director on the basis of an individual fee calculation study. 
Level of service is a qualitative measure of water consumption and/or wastewater discharged that varies by meter size, land use, gallon, equivalent residential unit or fixture unit, but is based on the level of water and/or wastewater treatment facilities needed to accommodate the demand of all land uses consistent with state and federal regulations and prudent engineering practices. 
Methodology report means a report prepared which provides an analysis and methodology for the determination of the water and wastewater impact fee and the impact of development activity on the needs and cost of additional water and/or wastewater treatment facilities. 
Present value means the discounted cash flow of past, present, or future payments, contributions, or dedications of goods, services, materials, construction, or money; also may be stated as "current value". 
Project or development project means a particular development on an identified parcel of land. 
Project improvement means a site improvement and facilities that are planned and designed to provide service for a particular development project and that are necessary for the use and convenience of the occupants or users of the project and are not system improvements. The character of the improvement shall control the determination of whether an improvement is a project improvement or a system improvement and the physical location of the improvement on-site or off-site shall not be considered determinative of whether an improvement is a project improvement or a system improvement. If an improvement or facility provides or will provide more than incidental service or facility capacity to persons other than users or occupants of a particular project, the improvement or facility is a system improvement and shall not be considered a project improvement. 
Proportionate share means that portion of the cost of system improvements which is reasonably related to the demands and needs of a project. 
Public facilities means: 
(1)  Water production, treatment, and distribution facilities; 
(2)  Wastewater collection, treatment and disposal facilities; 
(3)  Roads, streets, bridges, including rights-of-way, traffic signals, landscaping, and any components of state or federal highways; 
(4)  Storm water collection, retention, detention, treatment, and disposal facilities, flood control facilities, and bank and shore protection and enhancement and improvements; 
(5)  Parks, open space, and recreation areas and related facilities; 
(6)  Public safety facilities, including police, fire, emergency medical, and rescue facilities; and 
(7)  Libraries and related facilities. 
Replacement value means the cost of replacing a water and/or wastewater treatment facility at current market prices. 
System improvement means water and/or wastewater treatment facilities which are designed to provide service to the community at large, in contrast to a project improvement. 
System improvement cost means cost incurred to provide additional water and/or wastewater treatment capacity needed to serve development or new connections within the service area of the city, including, but not limited to, the construction contract price, surveying and engineering fees, related land acquisition cost, court cost, attorney and expert witness fees, and expenses for qualified staff, engineer, planner, architect or financial consultant for preparing or updating the city's capital improvement program. System improvement cost shall also include interest charges and other finance costs related to the issuance of bonds, notes or other financial obligations incurred by the city to finance capital improvements. 
Water and/or wastewater treatment facility means any water production; transmission or distribution facility, any wastewater treatment, collection or transmission facility, and any other support facility required for water and/or wastewater systems operations. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § 4, 9-16-2004; Ord. No. 06-15, § 8, 10-19-2006) 
Sec. 11½-30. - Imposition of water and/or wastewater impact fees. 
(a)  Any person who after the effective date of this article engages in development activity generating water and/or wastewater treatment demand shall pay a water and/or wastewater impact fee in the manner set forth in this article. 
(b)  No building permit for any development activity generating water and/or wastewater treatment demand and thereby required to pay a water and/or wastewater impact fee pursuant to this article shall be issued by the city unless the required water and/or wastewater impact fee has been paid. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § 5, 9-16-2004) 
Sec. 11½-31. - Computation of water and/or wastewater impact fee. 
(a)  (1)  At the option of the developer, the amount of the water and/or wastewater impact fee may be determined from the fee schedule established by the city, and maintained in the office of the city clerk, or; 
(2)  If a building permit is requested for a building with mixed uses, the water and/or wastewater impact fee shall be determined according to the fee schedule established by the city by apportioning the space committed to uses specified on the water and/or wastewater impact fee schedule. If the type of development activity for which a building permit is applied for is not specified on the water and/or wastewater impact fee schedule, the director shall be guided in the selection of a comparable type of development activity by the reports and studies done by the United States Environmental Protection Agency and/or the State of Georgia, and/or the city department of public works, and/or professional organizations such as the American Water Works Association, the Water Environment Federation, or the American Society of Civil Engineers. If the director determines the fee by using water and/or wastewater demands/generation statistics from the above-named sources and applying the formula set fourth in subsection (b) below, the director shall be guided in this determination by the above-named sources. In cases of change of use, redevelopment or modification of an existing use that requires the issuance of a building permit, the water and/or wastewater impact fee shall be based on the net increase in the fee for the new use as compared to the previous use. 
(b)  If a developer shall elect not to have the water and/or wastewater impact fee determined according to subsection (a) above, then the developer may apply for an individual fee determination. A developer applying for an individual fee determination shall prepare and submit to the director an individual fee calculation study for the development activity for which the building permit is sought. The individual fee calculation study shall follow the prescribed methodologies and formats for the study established by the director, or, subject to the prior approval of the director, such other professionally accepted methodology that identifies the project's proportionate share. The developer shall attend a pre-application meeting with the director and no agreement or understanding in regard to data assumptions, or methodology shall be binding upon the city unless provided to the developer in writing. The water and/or wastewater treatment demand engineering documentation submitted shall show the basis upon which the individual fee calculation was made, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Water and/or wastewater treatment demand engineering studies including documentation of water and/or wastewater treatment demand rate appropriate for the development activity; 
(2)  Cost documentation studies including documentation of the cost per unit of impact for water and/or wastewater treatment construction and documentation credits attributable to the development activity which can be expected to be available to replace the portion of the service volume used by the water and/or wastewater treatment demand generated by the development activity. 
This documentation shall be prepared and presented by qualified professionals in their respective fields and shall follow best professional practices and methodologies. The following formula, as explained in the methodology report, shall be used by the director to determine the water and/or wastewater impact fee per unit of development based on the type of land use: 
{(Unit Cost × Demand) — Credit =  Proportionate Share} 
Whereby: 
Unit Cost = The average cost per gallon of capacity to provide water and/or wastewater treatment system facilities within the service district. 
Demand = The average volume/capacity of water and/or wastewater expected to be consumed by a given land use or development activity on a daily basis. 
Credit = The average present value of future payments by a land use towards the retirement of debt incurred to construct water and/or wastewater facilities. 
The director shall provide the developer with a written individual fee determination within thirty (30) days after the presentation of the individual fee calculation study. 
(c)  (1)  Upon application to the director, any person engaging in development activity requiring payment of a water and/or wastewater impact fee may apply for and shall receive from the director a certification of the application of the water and/or wastewater impact fee schedule to a particular development activity proposal or a certification of an individual fee determination for a particular development proposal. 
(2)  Applications for certification shall include the following informational items: 
a.  A full and complete description of the project; 
b.  A full and complete description of the proposed land use and the particular proposed development activity; 
c.  A statement as to whether the applicant seeks a certification of the water and/or wastewater impact fee schedule as applied to that particular development proposal of a certification of an individual fee determination; and 
d.  If the applicant seeks a certification of an individual fee determination, and individual fee calculation study complying with the requirements complying with the requirements of subsection (b). 
(3)  The director shall provide an applicant with a written certification of the application of the water and/or wastewater impact fee schedule to a particular proposed development activity within five (5) days after the director's receipt of a completed application. The written certification of the director shall establish the water and/or wastewater impact fee for a particular proposed development activity for a period of one hundred and eighty (180) days from the date of certification. The director shall provide the applicant with a written certification of an individual fee determination within thirty (30) days after receipt of a completed application. The individual fee determination certified by the director shall establish the water and/or wastewater impact fee for the one hundred eighty-day period immediately following the date of such certification. Notwithstanding the issuance of any such certification, any changes in or additions to the proposed development activity different from the particular proposed development activity identified in the original application shall be subject to increased or additional water and/or wastewater impact fees to the extent that such changes or additions require capital improvements or facility expansions. The additional water and/or wastewater impact fees shall be based upon the most current water and/or wastewater impact fee schedule in effect on the date of the issuance of a building permit. 
Prior to the completion of the project, and as a condition of final inspection, the developer shall re-certify in writing to the director the actual land use or uses of the project, and shall present an architect's certificate of the actual gross square footage attributable to each use. In the event that the actual use or uses and/or the actual gross square footage applicable to the actual use or uses differs from that originally certified, and in the event that the water and/or wastewater impact fee has been previously paid, the developer shall be required to pay the amount of the excess as a condition of final inspection. The amount of the excess shall be based upon the most current water and/or wastewater impact fee schedule in effect on the date of final inspection. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § 6, 9-16-2004) 
Sec. 11½-32. - Payment of water and/or wastewater impact fees. 
(a)  Any person required to pay a water and/or wastewater impact fee pursuant to this article shall pay such fees to the director prior to the issuance of a building permit. 
(b)  All funds collected pursuant to this article shall be identified by the water and/or wastewater impact fee district from which it was collected and promptly transferred for deposit into the appropriate water and/or wastewater impact fee account to be held and accounted for separately as provided in section 11½-38 of this article. Funds shall be used solely for the purposes specified in this article. 
(c)  In lieu of all or part of the water and/or wastewater impact fee, the city may accept an offer to provide the items and/or services specified in subsection 11½-34(2) of this article. Any such offer must comply with the requirements of section 11½-34 of this article. The portion of the fee represented by the water and/or wastewater treatment improvements shall be deemed paid when the construction is completed and accepted by the city for maintenance or when the person claiming such credit posts security for the cost of construction as provided in subsection 11½-34(2)e. of this article. That portion of the fee represented by land dedication shall be deemed paid when the title to said land has been accepted by the city. Notwithstanding subsection (a) above, the city may issue a building permit prior to accepting title to land if the refusal to issue the permit will result in an exceptional hardship to the developer and the city is otherwise reasonably assured that title will be conveyed and accepted within a reasonable thereafter. For the purposes of this subsection, an exceptional hardship shall not include a hardship solely created by the developer. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § 7, 9-16-2004) 
Sec. 11½-33. - Use of funds. 
(a)  Funds collected as water and/or wastewater impact fees shall be used for system improvements. No funds shall be used for periodic or routine maintenance or for any purpose not in accordance with the requirements of this article. 
(b)  Water and/or wastewater impact fees shall be used exclusively for system improvements in the water and/or wastewater impact fee district in which the project for which the fees were paid in located. 
(c)  Funds shall be construed as being expended in the order in which they were collected. 
(d)  Water and/or wastewater impact fees may be used for the payment of principal and interest on bonds, notes, or other financial obligations issued by or on behalf of the city to finance the expansion of water and/or wastewater treatment facilities. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § 8, 9-16-2004) 
Sec. 11½-34. - Credits. 
Credits against water and/or wastewater impact fees shall be given as follows: 
(1)  No credit shall be given for project improvements. 
(2)  Credit shall be given for the present value of the construction of improvements or contribution or dedication of land or money by a developer subsequent to the effective date of this article and required or accepted by the city from the developer or his/her predecessor in title for system improvements. 
a.  A person claiming credits shall submit to the director a project description in sufficient detail to allow the director to prepare an engineering and construction cost estimate. A person proposing credit for water and/or wastewater treatment improvements shall present cost estimates and property appraisals prepared by qualified professionals to be used by the director in determining the amount of credit. All construction must be carried out in accordance with applicable city or state development and design standards. A person proposing credits for land dedication shall present the director with property appraisals prepared by qualified professionals and a certified copy of the most recent assessment of the property for tax purposes to be used by the director in determining the amount of credit. However, the director retains the right to determine the amount to be credited by preparing engineering and construction cost estimates and/or property appraisals for those improvements and/or property dedications. 
b.  Credits must be claimed at the time of the application for a building permit. Any credit not so claimed shall be deemed invalid. 
c.  In the event a developer contracts with the city to construct, fund or contribute system improvements so that the amount of the credit created by such construction, funding, or contribution is in excess of the water and/or wastewater impact fee which would have been otherwise due and owing, the developer shall be reimbursed for such excess contribution, funding, or contribution from water and/or wastewater impact fees paid by the development projects located in the water and/or wastewater impact fee district which has benefited by such improvements. The terms and conditions for any such reimbursement agreement under this section shall be negotiated individually, on a case-by-case basis, when the execution of such agreement(s) are deemed in the best interest of the city to enter into such agreement(s). In no case shall the amount credited to the developer shall exceed the construction cost paid by the developer. 
d.  In the event a building permit is abandoned, credit shall be given for the present value of any water and/or wastewater impact fees for the same parcel of land paid upon issuance of such building permit. A building permit shall be deemed abandoned if no construction has commenced prior to the expiration of the building permit. 
e.  Security in the form of a performance bond, irrevocable letter of credit, or escrow agreement shall be posted with the city, made payable to the city in the amount approved by the director equal to one hundred ten (110) per cent of the full cost of the construction of such water and/or wastewater treatment improvements. If a water and/or wastewater treatment construction project will not be constructed within one (1) year of the acceptance of the offer by the city, the amount of the security shall be increased by ten (10) per cent compounded, for each year of the life of the security. The security shall be renewed and approved by the city attorney's office prior to the acceptance of the security by the city. 
(3)  Credits are transferable from one developer to another and from one project to another provided such credits may not be transferred to a project in a different water and/or wastewater impact fee district. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § 9, 9-16-2004) 
Sec. 11½-35. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The following shall be exempted from payment of water and/or wastewater impact fees: 
(1)  Alteration or expansion of an existing building or use of land where no additional living units are created, where the use is not changed, and whereby no additional water consumption and/or wastewater treatment capacity demands will be created over and above those demand produced by the existing use. 
(2)  The construction of accessory buildings or structures that will not produce additional water consumption and/or wastewater treatment capacity demands over and above those produced by the principal building or the current use of the land. 
(3)  The replacement of a building, manufactured home, or structure that was in place on the effective date of this ordinance, or the replacement of building, manufactured home, or structure that was constructed subsequent thereto and for which appropriated water and/or wastewater impact fee had been paid or otherwise provided for, with a new building, manufactured home, or structure of the same use, provided that no additional water consumption and/or wastewater treatment capacity demands will be produced over and above those produced by the original use of the land. 
(b)  A person claiming exemption(s) pursuant to subsections (a)(1), (a)(2) or (a)(3) above shall submit to the director information and documentation sufficient to permit the director to determine whether such exemption claimed is proper, and, if so, the extent of such exemption. 
(c)  Exemptions must be applied for at the time of the application for a building permit. Any exemptions not so applied for shall be deemed waived. 
(d)  The mayor and city council, by majority vote may wave any and all provisions of this article when the waiver of said provisions are deemed in the best interest of the city. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § 10, 9-16-2004; Ord. No. 06-15, § 9, 10-19-2006) 
Sec. 11½-36. - Refunds. 
(a)  Upon application to the director by the fee payor, the city shall refund ninety seven (97) per cent of the water and/or wastewater impact fee paid if capacity is available and the building permit is rescinded or in the event water and/or wastewater treatment service is denied. The city shall retain three (3) per cent of the fee paid as an administrative fee. 
(b)  (1)  Upon application to the director by the fee payor, the city shall refund ninety seven (97) per cent of the water and/or wastewater impact fee paid and not expended or encumbered if the city, if after collecting the fee when service is not available, has failed to encumber the fee or commence construction within six (6) years from the date the water and/or wastewater impact fee was paid. The city shall retain three (3) per cent of the fee paid as an administrative fee. In determining whether water and/or wastewater impact fees have been expended or encumbered, all fees shall be considered encumbered on a first-in, first-out (FIFO) basis. 
(2)  When the right to a refund exist due to the city's failure to encumber water and/or wastewater impact fees, the city shall provide written notice of entitlement of a refund to the fee payor who paid the water and/or wastewater impact fee at the address shown on the application for development approval, or to the fee payor's successor in interest who has given the city notice of the transfer or assignment of the right or entitlement to a refund and who has provided the city with a mailing address. The city shall publish notice within thirty (30) days after the expiration of the six-year period from the water and/or wastewater impact fee payment date. Such published notice shall contain the heading "Notice of Entitlement to Water and/or Wastewater Impact Fee Refund". 
(c)  A refund application shall be made to the director within one (1) year from the date such refund becomes payable under subsections (a) and (b) above or within one (1) year from the date of the publication of the notice of entitlement a refund under subsection (b) above, whichever is later. Any refund not applied for within said time period shall be deemed waived. 
(d)  A refund application shall include information and documentation sufficient to permit the director to determine whether the refund claimed is proper and, if so, the amount of such refund. 
(e)  A refund shall include a pro rata share of interest actually earned on the unused or excess water and/or wastewater impact fee. 
(f)  All refunds shall be paid within sixty (60) days after the director determines that such refund is due. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § 11, 9-16-2004) 
Sec. 11½-37. - Water and/or wastewater impact fee districts established. 
Within the effective date of this article there is hereby established an initial water and/or wastewater impact fee district which shall be conterminous with the present and future water and wastewater treatment service area of the city. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § 12, 9-16-2004) 
Sec. 11½-38. - Water and/or wastewater impact fee account established. 
(a)  With the effective date of this ordinance there is hereby established a water and/or wastewater impact fee account for the initial water and/or wastewater impact fee district established in section 11½-37. Such account shall be interest bearing. All water and/or wastewater impact fees collected shall be deposited into this account. 
(b)  Interest earned on funds shall be funds of the account on which it is earned and is subject to all restrictions imposed by section 11½-33 of this article. 
(c)  Funds withdrawn from these accounts must be in accordance with section 11½-33 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § 13, 9-16-2004) 
Sec. 11½-39. - Development impact fee advisory committee. 
Prior to the adoption of this ordinance, a development impact fee advisory committee shall be established. 
Such committee shall be comprised of not less than five (5) nor more than ten (10) members appointed by the mayor and city council. At least forty (40) per cent of the membership shall be representatives from the development, building, or real estate industries. 
The development impact fee advisory committee shall serve in an advisory capacity to assist the mayor and city council with the regard to the adoption of this development impact fee ordinance. In that this committee serves in an advisory capacity, no action of the committee shall be construed as binding or a prerequisite for action by the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § 14, 9-16-2004) 
Sec. 11½-40. - Review of fee schedule. 
The water and/or wastewater impact fee schedule shall be reviewed by the mayor and city council at least annually; provided, however, the failure to review such fee structure shall not invalidate this article. Following such review, if changes in the fee schedule are deemed necessary, said changes may be implemented administratively, without formal amendment to this article. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § 15, 9-16-2004) 
Sec. 11½-41. - Administrative appeals. 
(a)  Any person directly aggrieved by a decision of the director with respect to any of the following determinations shall have the right to appeal to the mayor and city council: 
(1)  The imposition of a water and/or wastewater impact fee; 
(2)  The amount of a water and/or wastewater impact fee; 
(3)  The entitlement to and/or the amount of credits to a water and/or wastewater impact fee; 
(4)  The entitlements to an exemption from a water and/or wastewater impact fee; 
(5)  The entitlement to and/or the amount of a refund of a water and/or wastewater impact fee. 
Prior to any appeal to the mayor and city council, the aggrieved party shall file a written request for reconsideration with the director, who shall act upon the request within fifteen (15) days following the receipt of said request. 
(b)  All appeals shall be taken within fifteen (15) days of the director's decision on the request for reconsideration by filing with the director a notice of appeal specifying the grounds therefore. The director shall forthwith transmit to the mayor and city council all papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed is taken. The mayor and city council shall thereafter establish a reasonable date and time for a hearing on the appeal, give notice thereof to the parties in interest, and decide the same within a reasonable period of time following the hearing. Any party taking an appeal shall have the right to appear at the hearing to present testimony and evidence and may be represented by legal council. Any person aggrieved by a decision of the mayor and city council may pursue the appeal to the Superior Court of Laurens County within thirty (30) days after the decision of the mayor and city council is rendered. 
(c)  A developer may pay a water and/or wastewater impact fee under protest in order to obtain a building permit, and by making such payment shall not be prohibited from: 
(1)  Exercising the right of appeal provided in this section, or 
(2)  Receiving a refund of any amount deemed to have been illegally collected. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § 16, 9-16-2004) 
Sec. 11½-42. - Penalty and enforcement provisions. 
A violation of this article shall be a misdemeanor punishable according to the laws of the State of Georgia; however, in addition to or in lieu of criminal prosecution, the city shall have the power to sue for relief in civil court to enforce the provisions of this article. Knowingly furnishing false information to the director on any matter relating to the administration of this article shall constitute a violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 04-22, § 17, 9-16-2004) 
Chapter 12 - LICENSES[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Application of chapter. 
Except as may be otherwise specifically provided, the provisions of this chapter shall be applicable to and shall govern the issuance of any license or permit required by any other chapter or provision of this Code of Ordinances or city ordinance. 
Sec. 12-2. - Businesses to be registered. 
From and after passage and adoption of this article, every person, firm, corporation or association that exercises or engages in or pursues within the corporate limits of the city and profession, trade, calling or business of any nature whatsoever, shall register in the books kept for that purpose by the clerk of the city council of the said city, their name, profession, trade, calling or business of any and every nature and the address of their place of business, if any, within said city. 
(Ord. No. 81-24, § 1, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 12-3. - Engaging in business without license declared unlawful. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or association to do or engage in either or any of the following described businesses, trades, professions or callings in the said city during the year without first procuring a license from the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 81-29, § 18, 12-17-81) 
Editor's note— The enumeration of licenses and fees, as referred to in the above section, has not been included herein, but a copy may be found on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 12-4. - Registration of new businesses. 
Any and all persons, firms, corporations or associations, commencing any business of any kind whatsoever in the said city after the first day of January shall register their name and business as provided herein and pay the license prescribed herein immediately upon commencing business, trade, profession or calling. 
(Ord. No. 81-29, § 2, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 12-5. - License required if business advertised. 
Any persons, firm, corporation or association advertising by signs, card, circulars, newspaper advertising, radio advertising or otherwise, that he or she or they are in business of any kind in said city shall be held liable for the license required of such business. 
(Ord. No. 81-29, § 4, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 12-6. - Responsibility of agents. 
If any person, firm, corporation or association engaged in business in said city by or through an agent or agents other than the agent or agents in charge of said business shall become liable for the license upon the business in which he or they are engaged and it shall be unlawful for any such agent or agents to engage in any business, vocation or occupation, or to do any act in this city for which a license is required, without first obtaining a license to engage in such business. By this section it is made the duty of the agent or agents to ensure that the principal pays the required license. 
(Ord. No. 81-29, § 16, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 12-7. - Tax on itinerant traders not otherwise mentioned. 
There shall be levied and imposed such license as the mayor and city council shall deem just and equitable upon all itinerant traders and/or agents not specifically mentioned elsewhere in the tax and license article. 
(Ord. No. 81-29, § 9, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 12-8. - Fee if no fixed place of business in city. 
Any person or persons having no fixed place of business within the corporate limits of said city, but exercising therein any business of a kind or nature requiring registration under this article, shall be subject to and shall pay, a like taxation or license fee as those following a similar business in said city and having a fixed place of business. 
(Ord. No. 81-29, § 3, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 12-9. - Oath required. 
Every person applying for a business license shall make oath that the business engaged in by the applicant falls within the class for the license applied for and to which the ordinance prescribing the license tax specifically applies. 
(Ord. No. 81-29, § 8, 12-17-81) 
Editor's note— The enumeration of licenses, as mentioned in the above section, has not been set out herein, but a copy may be found on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 12-10. - Business "in connection with other businesses." 
No license shall be issued or granted to any person, firm corporation, or association or agent to do or engage in any business of any kind or nature in the said city "in connection with other business," unless the amount of license for such other business shall be equal to or exceed the amount of license as applied for "in connection with other business." When the amount of any given or stated license is prescribed or fixed, and it is then provided that a lower license for the same business may be applicable when issued "in connection with other business" the lower amount of license is not and shall not be applicable, nor shall any person be entitled to the benefit of same, unless it is issued in connection with other business which required a license equal to or in excess of the higher license applicable; that is, the license for such business if the same were not in connection with other business. 
(Ord. No. 81-29, § 17, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 12-11. - Scope of licenses. 
The licenses hereinafter enumerated and levied and imposed upon each separate business and upon each separate place of business apply to only that particular business and that particular place of business, and do not include any other business or place of business for which a special license or tax is required. 
(Ord. No. 81-29, § 8, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 12-12. - Issuance; due date for payment of tax; expiration. 
All licenses issued by the city shall be in the name of the person, firm, corporation, association or agent to whom the same is issued, and each license tax levied by this article shall be registered, license tax due and payable not later than the first day of January, except as otherwise especially provided, and a license issued hereunder shall expire on the thirty-first day of December. 
(Ord. No. 81-29, § 5, 12-17-81) 
Cross reference— Due dates for full payment of special taxes, § 12-13. 
Sec. 12-13. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 92-6, adopted Aug. 3, 1992, repealed § 12-13. Formerly, § 12-13 pertained to due dates for payment of special taxes and derived from Ord. No. 81-29, § 10, adopted Dec. 17, 1981. For provisions re due dates for occupational and professional taxes, the user's attention is directed to § 21-50 herein. 
Sec. 12-14. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 92-6, adopted Aug. 3, 1992, repealed § 12-14. Formerly, § 12-14 pertained to penalty for late payment of license fees and derived from Ord. No. 81-29, § 1, adopted Dec. 17, 1981. For provisions re penalties and interest on delinquent occupational or professional taxes, the user's attention is directed to §§ 21-54 and 21-55 herein. 
Sec. 12-15. - Proration. 
No license herein provided for shall be prorated except by special permission of the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 81-29, § 13, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 12-16. - Posting required. 
Each license shall be posted conspicuously at or in the place of business of the person, firm, corporation or association to whom the same is issued. 
(Ord. No. 81-29, § 6, 12-17-81)

Editor's note— Ord. No. 92-6, adopted Aug. 3, 1992, repealed § 12-17. Formerly, § 12-17 pertained to transfer of licenses and derived from Ord. No. 81-29, §§ 11, 14, 15, adopted Dec. 17, 1981. For provisions re transfer of certificates of registration the user's attention is directed to § 21-49.5 herein. 
Sec. 12-18. - License inspector; duties. 
The chief of police or any other member of the police force of the said city, or other person, may be appointed or designated by the city manager as "license inspector," and it shall be his duty to personally visit every place of business within the said city and determine whether or not each such place has a properly posted license. It shall be the duty of the license inspector to make a case or cases against each and every person, firm, corporation or association having failed to obtain and post proper license within the time required by this article, or those having refused to register or pay the license required hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 81-29, § 12, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 12-19. - Failure to register and pay license fee. 
Upon the failure of any person, firm, corporation or association to register as herein required and pay the license fee herein prescribed, the city clerk shall, from the best information obtainable, register the same, and the chief of police is hereby required to report to the said city clerk any and all such failures to register which become known to him. 
(Ord. No. 81-29, § 7, 12-17-81) 
Sec. 12-20. - Responsibility of licensee. 
Every person obtaining a license under the provisions of this chapter shall be liable and held responsible for any act of commission or omission by his agents or employees. 
Sec. 12-21. - Suspension, revocation. 
Except as may be otherwise specifically provided, any license issued under the provisions of this chapter, any other provision of this Code, or city ordinance, may be suspended or revoked by the mayor and city council for the violation by the licensee, his agents or employees, of any applicable provision of this Code, city ordinance or state law, rule or regulation. 
Sec. 12-22. - Penalty for violation 
Any person, firm, or corporation or association violating this article or any part of the same shall, upon conviction, be punished as prescribed in section 1-10 of the Official Code of the City of Dublin, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 81-29, § 19, 12-17-81) 
Secs. 12-23—12-34. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - INSURANCE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 79-36, §§ 1—7, adopted Dec. 17, 1979, not specifically amendatory of the Code, has been codified as superseding former Art. II, which consisted of §§ 12-35—12-41 and was derived from Ord. No. 78-8, §§ 1—7, adopted March 20, 1978, and Ord. No. 78-24, §§ 1—7, adopted Oct. 3, 1978. 

Sec. 12-35. - Insurer license fees. 
(a)  There is hereby levied for the year 1984 and for each year thereafter an annual license fee upon each insurer doing business within the City of Dublin, Georgia, in the amount of seventy-five dollars ($75.00). For each separate business location in excess of one not covered by subsection (b), which is operating on behalf of insurers within the City of Dublin, there is hereby levied a license fee in the amount of seventy-five dollars ($75.00). For the purposes of this article, the term "insurer" means a company which is authorized to transact business in any of the classes of insurance designated in Official Code of Georgia Annotated Section 33-3-5. 
(b)  For each separate business location not otherwise subject to a license fee hereunder operated and maintained by a business organization which is engaged in the business of lending money or transacting sales involving term financing and in connection with such loans or sales, offers, solicits or takes application for insurance through a licensed agent of an insurer for insurance, said insurer shall pay an additional annual license fee of ten dollars ($10.00) or thirty-five (35) per cent of the fee as set forth in subsection (a) of this section, whichever amount is greater. 
(Ord. No. 79-36, § 1, 12-17-79; Ord. No. 83-19, §§ 1, 2, 11-3-83; Ord. No. 84-10, §§ 1, 2, 6-28-84; Ord. No. 96-4, 3-7-96) 
Sec. 12-36. - Agency license fees. 
There is hereby levied for the year 1984 and for each year thereafter an annual license fee upon independent agencies and brokers for each separate business location from which an insurance business is conducted and which is not subject to the company license fee imposed by subsection (a) hereof, in the amount of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for each such location within the City of Dublin, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 79-36, § 2, 12-17-79; Ord. No. 83-19, § 3, 11-3-83; Ord. No. 84-10, § 3, 6-28-84) 
Sec. 12-37. - Gross premiums tax. 
(a)  There is hereby levied for the year 1984 and for each year thereafter an annual tax based solely upon gross direct premiums upon each insurer writing life, accident and sickness insurance within the City of Dublin in the amount equal to one per cent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year in accordance with Official Code of Georgia Annotated Section 33-8-8.1. Gross direct premiums as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in Official Code of Georgia Annotated Section 33-8-4. The premium tax levied by this section is in addition to the license fees imposed by section 12-35. 
(b)  There is hereby levied for the year 1984 and for each year thereafter an annual tax upon each insurer, other than an insurer transacting business in the class of insurance designated in subsection 1 of Official Code of Georgia Annotated Section 33-3-5, doing business within the City of Dublin in an amount equal to two and one-half (2½) per cent of the gross direct premiums received during the calendar year, in accordance with Official Code of Georgia Annotated Section 33-8-8.2. Gross direct premiums as used in this section shall mean gross direct premiums as used in Official Code of Georgia Annotated Section 33-8-8.2(a). 
(Ord. No. 79-36, § 3, 12-17-79; Ord. No. 83-19, §§ 4, 5, 11-3-83) 
Sec. 12-38. - Due date and required reports. 
(a)  License fees imposed in sections 12-35 and 12-36 shall be due and payable by the tenth day of February, 1984, and by the tenth of February of each subsequent year. 
(b)  The gross direct premiums tax set and levied by section 12-37 shall be due and payable upon the effective date of this article and then on the first day of January in each calendar year. Payment shall be deemed delinquent if not received within ninety (90) days from the due date. 
(c)  Payment of the company license fee and gross direct premiums tax herein levied by sections 12-35 and 12-36 shall be made to City of Dublin and shall be accompanied by a report showing the name and home office address of the insurance company seeking the license; the location and person in charge of each and every business location within the city operated and maintained by such company; the names and addresses of the agents representing the insurance company in the city; the classes of insurance written and the premiums received for each class from policies insuring persons residing within the municipal corporate limits; and such other reasonable information as may be required. Such report shall be made on forms prescribed by the City of Dublin and filed over the affidavit of an officer of the company. 
(d)  Payment of the agency license fee herein levied by section 12-36 shall be made to the City of Dublin and shall be accompanied by a report showing the name and address of the person responsible for each business location subject to the license fee imposed; the address of each business location; the class or classes of insurance written at each business location; the names of the companies represented; and such other reasonable information as may be required. Such report shall be made on forms prescribed by the City of Dublin and filed over the affidavit of the person in charge of the agency seeking the license. 
(Ord. No. 79-36, § 4, 12-17-79; Ord. No. 81-29, § 12-17-81; Ord. No. 83-19, § 6, 11-3-83) 
Sec. 12-39. - False information. 
It is hereby declared to be a violation of this article for any person, firm, corporation or agent thereof knowingly to give false or incomplete information on any report herein required to be filed. 
(Ord. No. 79-36, § 5, 12-17-79) 
Sec. 12-40. - Confidentially of information. 
All reports required to be filed under the authority of this article shall be confidential and the information contained therein shall be used solely by the officers of the city responsible for the administration of this article. 
(Ord. No. 79-36, § 6, 12-17-79) 
Sec. 12-41. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Any person, firm or corporation who shall conduct business within the municipal corporate limits without having obtained a license therefor as required by this article, or who shall violate any other provision of this article, shall, upon conviction therefor, be punished in the manner provided for violations of other ordinances of the city. 
(b)  The gross direct premiums tax levied by this article may be enforced by execution in the same manner as other taxes of the city. 
(Ord. No. 79-36, § 7, 12-17-79) 
Secs. 12-42—12-50. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IV. - MASSAGE BUSINESSES 

Sec. 12-101. - Purpose. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to provide for local licensing and regulation of locations where massage is offered, pursuant to the authority of section 1.4 of the Charter of the City of Dublin, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(b)(17), and O.C.G.A. § 43-24A-1 et seq. as amended. 
(b)  A license issued pursuant to this article is a privilege, not a right. 
(Ord. No. 10-16, § 1, 10-21-2010) 
Sec. 12-102. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the following definitions apply: 
Act means the Georgia Massage Therapy Practice Act, enacted by and defined in O.C.G.A. § 43-24A-1 et seq. as amended. 
Board means the Georgia Board of Massage Therapy, enacted by the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 43-24A-4. 
For hire means a reasonable expectation that the person to whom the massage is provided, or some third person on his or her behalf, will pay money, give other consideration, or provide any gratuity therefore. 
Massage means the application of a system of structured touch, pressure, movement, and holding to the soft tissue of the body in which the primary intent is to enhance or restore health and well-being. The term includes complementary methods, including without limitation, the external application of water, superficial heat, superficial cold, lubricants, salt scrubs, or other topical preparations and the use of commercially available electromechanical devices which do not require the use of transcutaneous electrodes and which mimic or enhance the actions possible by the hands; the term also includes determining whether massage therapy is appropriate or contraindicated, or whether referral to another health care provider is appropriate. Massage therapy shall not include the use of ultrasound, fluidotherapy, laser, and other methods of deep thermal modalities. 
Massage business or massage parlor means a business with a location in the city at which any person engages in or offers massage, regardless of the name of the business or the words used to describe the business through signage or advertisement or in filings with the secretary of state. Massage parlors are subject to regulation by a local government, pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-9(b)(17) and O.C.G.A. § 43-24A-22(a) as amended. 
Massage therapist means: 
(1)  A person who holds a valid, current, unrevoked, and unsuspended state license in the practice of massage therapy issued by the board pursuant to the Georgia Massage Therapy Practice Act. 
(2)  A person who holds a valid, current, unrevoked, and unsuspended state provisional permit in the practice of massage therapy issued by the board pursuant to the Georgia Massage Therapy Practice Act, and working under the supervision of a licensed massage therapist. 
(3)  A person pursuing a course of study leading to a degree or certificate as a massage therapist in an educational program recognized by the board, if such person is designated by title indicating student status and is fulfilling uncompensated work experiences required for the attainment of the degree or certificate, and working under the supervision of a licensed massage therapist. 
(4)  A nonresident person rendering massage therapy up to sixty (60) days during a twelve-month period for treatment of a temporary sojourner only; provided that such nonresident massage therapist holds a license, registration or certification from another state, jurisdiction or country if the requirements as determined by the Georgia Board for Licensure are substantially equal to the requirements contained in this chapter; or provided that such nonresident massage therapist is currently nationally certified in therapeutic massage and bodywork. 
(5)  A person duly licensed, registered, or certified in another jurisdiction, state, territory, or a foreign country when incidentally in this state to provide service as part of an emergency response team working in conjunction with disaster relief officials or as part of a charity event with which he or she comes into the state. 
Masseuse, masseur, massage practitioner , or persons practicing massage means a person who performs or engages in the practice of massage. 
State license means a license to practice massage therapy issued by the board, pursuant to the Act. 
(Ord. No. 10-16, § 1, 10-21-2010) 
Sec. 12-103. - Requirements for licensure. 
(a)  State license. No person other than a massage therapist shall perform or offer to perform massage in the City of Dublin. 
(b)  City license. No person or entity shall operate a massage parlor without a valid, current, unrevoked, and unsuspended license from the city, pursuant to this article.
