(6)  Animals and birds: The keeping of any animal or bird which by frequent or continuous barking, chirping or other means of communication disturbs the comfort or repose of the residents of any residential neighborhood. 
(7)  Vehicle repair in residential areas: The repairing, rebuilding or testing of any motor vehicle between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. within any residential area in such a manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the residents of the area. 
(8)  Schools, courts, churches, hospitals: The creating of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school, institution of learning, church or court while the same are in use, or adjacent to any hospital, which unreasonably interferes with the workings of such institution or which disturbs or unduly annoys patients in the hospital, provided conspicuous signs are displayed in such streets indicating that the same is a school, hospital or court street. 
(9)  Hawkers and peddlers: The selling of anything by outcry within the residential areas of the city, except at licensed sporting events, parades, fairs, circuses and other similar licensed public entertainment events. 
(10)  Drums: The using of any drum or other instrument or device for the purpose of attracting attention by the creation of noise within the city, unless a permit for such use has been obtained from the city manager or chief of police. 
(Code 1964, § 17-21) 
Sec. 14-36. - Exemptions. 
The following uses and activities shall be exempt from the noise regulations set forth in this article: 
(1)  Noises of safety signals and warning devices. 
(2)  Noises resulting from any authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an emergency call or acting in time of emergency. 
(3)  Noises resulting from emergency work, to be construed as work made necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a public calamity, or work required to protect persons or property from an imminent exposure to danger. 
Sec. 14-37. - Injunctions. 
The operation or maintenance of any device, vehicle or machinery in violation of any provision of this article which causes discomfort or annoyance to reasonable persons of normal sensitiveness or which endangers the comfort, repose, health or peace of residents of this city shall be deemed, and is declared to be, a public nuisance and may be subject to abatements summarily by a restraining order or injunction issued by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
ARTICLE IV. - BAD CHECK CHARGES 

Sec. 14-38. - General prohibition. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to issue a bad check for payment of any obligation to the city. 
(Ord. No. 88-8, 2-18-88) 
ARTICLE V. - TREES 

Sec. 14-39. - Protective regulations. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicated a different meaning: 
Approved trees means those trees approved or planting within street rights-of-way consisting of the following: 
(1)  Cedar. 
(2)  Dogwood. 
(3)  Ginko. 
(4)  Holly. 
(5)  Live oak. 
(6)  Magnolia. 
(7)  Redbud. 
(8)  Cherry laurel. 
(9)  Crepe myrtle. 
(10)  Red maple. 
(11)  Other species of trees approved by the building inspector of the city. 
Plantings means any flower, bush, vegetable, grass, etc., other than a tree or shrubbery. 
Shrubbery means any perennial woody growth with branches at or near the ground. 
(b)  Intent. The city intends to promote the community health and welfare by protecting the trees and woodlands for the unique benefits they provide in enhancing community appearance and assisting in the control of solar heat and glare, soil conservation, air pollution, and noise abatement. In addition, trees and woodlands offer a haven for a manmade urban environment. Further, it is the intent of the city to enhance the community and its citizens, and not to be punitive or to cause a hardship to any individual, private or public company who use reasonable care and diligence to protect trees and woodlands within the city. 
(b)  Protected. Trees, regulated and protected herein, are declared to be a natural public resource and the city encourages planting, replacement and protection of trees, in the interest of the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city. To attain that end, it shall be unlawful to cut down, damage, poison or in any other manner destroy or cause to be destroyed any tree or woodlands located within street rights-of-way, parks, public places, and any other properties owned by the city and located within its corporate limits without the permission of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 97-4, 2-20-97; Ord. No. 03-13, 5-15-2003) 
Sec. 14-40. - Creation of tree board. 
(a)  There is hereby created and established a tree board for the City of Dublin, Georgia (hereinafter in this article referred as the to as "board"). 
(b)  The board shall consist of twelve (12) members who shall be appointed by the Mayor and City Council of the City of Dublin, Georgia, and who shall be residents of Laurens County, but need not be residents of the City of Dublin, Georgia. These members shall include a registered landscape architect, a registered forester, recreation authority representative, public works department representative, Keep Dublin Laurens Beautiful, Inc. representative, Dublin City Council Member, Georgia Power Company representative, a representative of a utility company providing service within the corporate limits of the city and four (4) interested lay persons or garden club members. The board shall choose its own officers and keep minutes of all proceedings. A majority of the members present shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. 
(c)  The term of the twelve (12) persons shall be three (3) years, except that the term of four (4) members appointed to the first term will be for one (1) year only, and the term of four (4) lay members of the first board shall be for two (2) years. 
(d)  The board shall be responsible for writing and implementing the annual community forestry work plan upon the approval of the Dublin City Council. 
(Ord. No. 00-3, 1-20-2000) 
ARTICLE VI. - ALARMS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 02-06, adopted Apr. 18, 2002, set out provisions regulating alarm systems. Said ordinance did not specify manner of codification; hence, inclusion herein as art. VI, §§ 14-41—14-44 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference— False alarms prohibited, § 10-5; Reward for arrest of persons making false alarms, § 10-6. 

Sec. 14-41. - Alarm requirements. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to install an alarm system in the City of Dublin without first obtaining an installation permit from the 911 center. If a person fails to obtain a permit prior to installation, the alarm system shall be disconnected until the proper registration is obtained. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to install an alarm system in the City of Dublin who does not possess the proper state licenses. 
(c)  All alarm systems shall be keyed to a private service which can notify the 911 center when an alarm has been activated. It shall be unlawful for any person to install an alarm system with an automatic calling device keyed to the 911 center. 
(d)  Any person in violation of the above requirements shall have the alarm system disconnected and fined one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Ord. No. 02-06, 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-42. - False alarms. 
Upon any false alarm being activated where public safety officers are dispatched to the premises, the resident of the premises shall pay the following penalties: 

 
(Ord. No. 02-06, 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-43. - Appeals. 
In the event a penalty is assessed as a result of a false alarm and the resident of the premises disagrees with the false alarm classification, he or she may appeal the ruling to the public safety committee by utilizing the following procedure: 
(1)  The person assessed a penalty shall request an appeal hearing in writing before the public safety committee. The request shall state the reasons for the appeal. 
The public safety committee is chaired by the council representative and also includes the chief of police and the fire chief. 
(2)  An appeal hearing will then be set up within thirty (30) days of receipt of the request for appeal. 
(3)  The decision of the public safety committee will be final. 
(Ord. No. 02-06, 4-18-2002) 
Sec. 14-44. - Exclusions. 
(a)  False alarms that are a result of an act of nature (power outage, storm, etc.) will not count as a false alarm against the residence or business. 
(b)  False alarms which occur within ten (10) days of installation shall not be counted against the residence or business. 
(Ord. No. 02-06, 4-18-2002) 
Chapter 15 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Authority to provide for parks, § 11(e); public parks, § 18 et seq. 
Cross reference— Planning and zoning, Ch. 17; zoning, App. A; subdivisions, App. B. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - Motor vehicles restricted. 
No motorized vehicles of any type shall be allowed on public parks, playgrounds, or school areas under the supervision of the department of parks and recreation unless the person operating such vehicle shall have first received written permission from the director of parks and recreation, with the exception of motorized vehicles entering such areas for the purpose of construction or routine maintenance. This section does not prohibit the use of motorized vehicles on established streets, roadways or parking areas, nor is the use of emergency vehicles prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 75-19, § 1, 6-2-75) 
Cross reference— Traffic generally, Ch. 23. 
Sec. 15-2. - Prohibited activities. 
No person shall use or occupy any public park, playground, picnic area, athletic field or other recreation facility under the supervision of the department of parks and recreation, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., unless such use or occupancy is in connection with a regularly scheduled activity or event of the department of parks and recreation, or unless written permission has been previously obtained from the director of parks and recreation or city manager, excluding members of the city council for the purpose of investigation. 
(Ord. No. 81-24, § 1, 10-1-81) 
Secs. 15-3—15-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RECREATION BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 15-16. - Created. 
There is hereby created a board to be known as the recreation board of the city, pursuant to the authority of chapter 69-6, Georgia Code Annotated, which board shall be for the purposes contemplated by said law and which board shall have the duties, powers and authority provided by said law. 
(Code 1964, § 18-1) 
Sec. 15-17. - Composition. 
The recreation board shall be composed of seven (7) members. 
(Ord. No. 73-2, § 18-2, 1-8-73) 
Sec. 15-18. - Appointment. 
Members of the recreation board shall be appointed by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 73-2, § 18-2, 1-8-73) 
Sec. 15-19. - Terms. 
Of the initial members appointed to the recreation board, four (4) members shall serve terms of three (3) years, and three (3) shall serve two (2) years. Thereafter, all members shall be appointed for terms of three (3) years or until their successors are appointed and qualified. Members may be appointed to more than one successive term of office. 
(Code 1964, §§ 18-2, 18-4—18-6; Ord. No. 73-2, § 18-2, 1-8-73) 
Sec. 15-20. - Filling vacancies. 
Vacancies on the recreation board shall be filled by appointment by the mayor for the unexpired term only. 
(Code 1964, § 18-3) 
Sec. 15-21. - Compensation. 
The members of the recreation board shall serve without any remuneration or financial benefit of any kind. 
(Code 1964, § 18-7) 
Sec. 15-22. - Officers. 
The recreation board shall elect one of its members as president and shall elect such other officers as the board may deem necessary. The terms of office of the officers of the board in such official capacity, as distinguished from the terms of members on the board, shall be determined by the board; except that the term of office of any officer of the board shall not be for a longer time than his term of office as a member of the board. 
(Code 1964, § 18-8) 
Sec. 15-23. - Meetings. 
The recreation board shall hold an organizational meeting in January of each year for the purpose of electing its president and other officers and for such other purposes as the board may deem appropriate. Thereafter, the board shall hold regular meetings at such time and place as it may determine. 
(Code 1964, § 18-12) 
Sec. 15-24. - Statutory duties. 
The duties, powers and authority of the recreation board provided and specified by this chapter shall be cumulative and in addition to all duties, powers and authority provided by Chapter 69-6, Georgia Code Annotated. 
(Code 1964, § 18-9) 
Sec. 15-25. - Authority over parks. 
While the board is named and to be known as recreation board of the city, it is intended and contemplated that such board shall have all of the powers, duties and obligations with respect to parks and all other matters contemplated by the aforementioned laws of the state concerning park and recreation boards, the word "park" being deleted from the name of the board established by this chapter only for the sake of brevity in name without any intention to thereby limit or restrict the powers, duties and authority of said board. 
(Code 1964, § 18-10) 
Sec. 15-26. - Regulatory authority. 
The recreation board shall make such rules and regulations governing the operation, organization and conduct of the board and of all facilities and activities operated by the board as the board shall see fit. 
(Code 1964, § 18-11) 
Sec. 15-27. - General powers, duties. 
The recreation board of the city shall operate and supervise the public parks, playgrounds, athletic fields, recreation centers and the other recreational facilities owned, leased or controlled by the city or owned, leased or controlled by the recreation board of the city. The board shall have supervision of the facilities and activities provided and conducted on, or in connection with, all of the parks, playgrounds, athletic fields, recreational centers, and all other facilities hereinbefore mentioned. The board shall have the power to conduct any form of recreational or cultural activity that they may deem proper or appropriate. The recreation board of the city may create policies for and shall have authority over and shall administer coordinated recreational services, and the board may cooperate with other similar local, state and federal authorities. 
(Code 1964, § 18-13) 
Sec. 15-28. - Funds. 
In carrying out the purpose of this chapter, the recreation board is authorized to receive and disburse for such purposes any funds appropriated to it by the city together with any other funds derived from gifts, grants, donations, bequests, devises, or from the board's operation and activities, subject only to the limitations and restrictions on such authority as may be specified in the laws of the state. 
All funds received by the recreation board shall be deposited with the board and withdrawn and disbursed by the board in the same manner as funds appropriated by the city for recreational purposes. 
(Code 1964, § 18-14) 
Sec. 15-29. - Employ personnel. 
The recreation board shall have power to employ a superintendent of recreation who shall be a person of proven executive and administrative ability with special or professional training in community recreation. Said board shall also have the power to employ such other persons as they deem necessary in the maintenance and operation of the recreational facilities and program on a permanent or part-time basis, and such persons shall be deemed employees of the board. 
(Code 1964, § 18-15) 
Sec. 15-30. - Budget. 
Not less than forty-five (45) days preceding the end of each fiscal year, or at such earlier date as may be fixed by the mayor and board of aldermen, the recreation board shall prepare a careful estimate in writing of the amounts of money required for the business and conduct of affairs of the board during the next fiscal year, which estimate shall specify in detail the object of the estimated amounts needed. Said estimate shall be submitted to the clerk of the city to be received by him for the information, consideration and benefit of the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Code 1964, § 18-16) 
Sec. 15-31. - Reports. 
The recreation board shall submit to the clerk of the city for the information, consideration and benefit of the mayor and board of aldermen a monthly and an annual report of the activities of the board and shall make and submit such other reports from time to time as may be required by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Code 1964, § 18-17) 
Sec. 15-32. - Form of reports. 
The form of all reports submitted by the recreation board shall be determined and established by the board unless the board is directed to the contrary by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Code 1964, § 18-18) 
Sec. 15-33. - Fiscal year. 
The fiscal year of the recreation board shall conform with that of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 18-19) 
Chapter 16 - PEDDLERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Revocation of permits, § 22. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Definition. 
The word "peddler" as used in this chapter shall mean any individual, whether a resident of this city or not, traveling by foot, wagon, automobile, motor truck or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, for the sale of, as well as the selling, offering for sale or taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, personal property of any nature whatsoever for future delivery, or for services to be furnished or performed in the future, whether or not such individual has, carries or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale or not or whether he is collecting advance payments on such sales or not; provided that such definition shall include any person who, for himself, or for another person, hires, leases, uses, or occupies any building, structure, tent, railroad boxcar, boat, hotel room, lodging house, apartment, shop or any other place within this city for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples and taking orders for future delivery. The word "peddler" shall include the terms "canvasser," "street vendor," "transient or itinerant merchant or vendor" or "transient or itinerant photographer." 
Sec. 16-2. - Exceptions to chapter. 
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the following: 
(a)  Sales made to dealers or permanent merchants by commercial travelers selling in the usual course of business; 
(b)  Sheriffs, constables, bona fide assignees, receivers or trustees in bankruptcy or other public officers selling goods, wares and merchandise according to law; 
(c)  Bona fide residents of the state selling fruits, vegetables, dressed meats, fowl or farm products which were produced on land within the state, owned or controlled by such vendor; 
(d)  Solicitations, sales or distributions made by charitable, educational or religious organizations which have their principal place of activity within this city. 
Sec. 16-3. - Selling near schools. 
It shall be unlawful for any peddler to sell, cause to be sold or give away any merchandise on any street, sidewalk, land, or alley in the city that is immediately contiguous to any of the public school grounds in the city; provided, nothing herein contained shall apply to sales or gifts to persons other than school children. 
(Code 1964, § 19-2) 
Sec. 16-4. - Blocking traffic. 
(a)  Every peddler selling wares on the streets from a cart, buggy, wagon, automobile, truck or stand of any description shall be prohibited from stopping or placing for a period of more than ten (10) minutes said cart, stand, buggy, wagon, automobile or truck on any street within the city. 
(b)  The chief of police or any other policeman shall have the power and authority at any time to require any peddler to move whenever in their judgment the facility and convenience of traffic demand it. 
(Code 1964, § 19-3) 
Sec. 16-5. - Entrance to premises restricted. 
It shall be unlawful for any peddler to enter upon any private premises when such premises are posted with a sign stating "No Peddlers Allowed" or "No Solicitations Allowed" or other words to such effect. 
Sec. 16-6. - Refusing to leave. 
Any peddler who enters upon premises owned, leased or rented by another and refuses to leave such premises after having been notified by the owner or occupant of such premises, or his agent, to leave the same and not return to such premises, shall be deemed guilty of an offense. 
Sec. 16-7. - Misrepresentation. 
It shall be unlawful for any peddler to make false or fraudulent statements concerning the quality of his goods, wares, merchandise or services for the purpose of inducing another to purchase the same. 
Sec. 16-8. - Hours of operation. 
It shall be unlawful for any peddler to engage in the business of peddling within the city between the hours of one-half hour before sunset and 9:00 a.m. the following morning, or at any time on Sundays, except by specific appointment with or invitation from the prospective customer. 
Secs. 16-9—16-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERMIT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Licenses generally, Ch. 12. 

Sec. 16-20. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business as a peddler within this city without first obtaining a permit to do so. 
(Code 1964, § 19-1) 
Sec. 16-21. - Application. 
Applicants for a permit under this article shall file with the city clerk a sworn application in writing, in duplicate, on a form to be furnished by the city clerk, which shall give the following information: 
(a)  The name and a description of the applicant; 
(b)  The permanent home address and full local address of the applicant; 
(c)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold; 
(d)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship; 
(e)  The length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
(f)  The place where the goods or property proposed to be sold, or orders taken for the sale thereof, are manufactured or produced, where such goods or products are located at the time the application is filed and the proposed method of delivery; 
(g)  A photograph of the applicant, taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of filing of the application, which picture shall be two (2) inches by two (2) inches showing the head and shoulders of the applicant in a clear and distinguishing manner; 
(h)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, offense or violation of any municipal ordinance, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor; 
(i)  Whether the applicant, upon any sale or order, shall demand, accept or receive payment or deposit of money in advance of final delivery; 
(j)  The last five (5) municipalities wherein the applicant has worked before coming to this city; and 
(k)  Such other relevant information as may be required by the investigation of the applicant. 
Sec. 16-22. - Driver's license. 
At the time of filing his application for a permit required by this article, the applicant shall present his driver's license, if he has one, to the city clerk. 
Sec. 16-23. - Application fee. 
At the time of filing the application, a fee of five dollars ($5.00) shall be paid to the city clerk to cover the cost of investigation of the facts stated therein. 
Sec. 16-24. - False information. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to give any false or misleading information in connection with his application for a permit required by this article. 
Sec. 16-25. - Fingerprints. 
At the time of making application for a permit required by this article, the applicant shall submit to fingerprinting by the chief of police. 
Sec. 16-26. - Fee. 
Before any permit shall be issued under the provisions of this article the applicant therefor shall pay a fee, based upon the duration he desires to engage in business in the city, as follows: 
Per day ..... $50.00 
Per week ..... 100.00 
Per month ..... 250.00 
Sec. 16-27. - Bond. 
(a)  Every applicant, not a resident of the city, or who is a resident of the city and represents a firm whose principal place of business is located outside the state, shall file with the city clerk a surety bond running to the city in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), with surety acceptable to and approved by the mayor, conditioned that the applicant shall comply fully with all the applicable provisions of this Code, the ordinances of the city and state law regulating and concerning the business of peddling and guaranteeing to any citizen of the city that all money paid as a down payment will be accounted for and applied according to the representations of the peddler, and further guaranteeing to any citizen of the city doing business with such peddler that the property purchased will be delivered according to the representations of such peddler. Action on such bond may be brought in the name of the city to the use or benefit of the aggrieved person. 
(b)  If the applicant is an agent, employee, canvasser or solicitor of a corporation authorized to do business in this state or registered under the fictitious name act of the state, such corporation or fictitious name business may furnish one bond in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for any and all of its agents, employees, canvassers or solicitors. 
Sec. 16-28. - Service of process. 
Before any permit shall issue under this article, there shall also be filed with the city clerk an instrument in writing, signed by the applicant under oath, nominating and appointing the city clerk his true and lawful agent, with full power and authority to acknowledge service of notice of process for and on the behalf of such applicant, and service of summons in any action brought upon the applicant's bond shall be deemed made when served on the city clerk. 
Sec. 16-28.1. - Investigation. 
Upon receipt of an application for a permit required by this article, the original shall be referred to the chief of police, who shall cause such investigation of the applicant's business and moral character to be made as he deems necessary for the protection of the public good. The chief of police shall complete his investigation within one week of receiving the application. 
Sec. 16-29. - Denial. 
If, as a result of investigation, the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on the application his disapproval and his reasons for the same, and return the application to the city clerk, who shall notify the applicant that his application is disapproved and that no permit shall be issued. 
Sec. 16-30. - Issuance. 
If, as a result of investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the chief of police shall endorse on the application his approval, execute a permit addressed to the applicant for the carrying on of the business applied for and return the permit along with the application to the city clerk, who shall, upon payment of the required fee, deliver the permit to the applicant. 
Sec. 16-31. - Contents. 
Each permit issued under this article shall contain the signature and seal of the issuing officer and shall show the name, address and photograph of the permittee, the class of permit issued and the kind of goods to be sold thereunder, the amount of fee paid, the date of issuance and the length of time and same shall be operative, as well as the permit number and other identifying description of any vehicle used in such business. 
Sec. 16-32. - Record. 
The city clerk shall keep a permanent record of all permits issued under this article. 
Sec. 16-33. - Display. 
Every peddler having a permit issued under the provisions of this article and doing business within the city shall display his permit upon request of any person, and failure to do so shall be deemed an offense. If a peddler uses a stand, vehicle or room in conducting his business, the permit shall be conspicuously posted so as to be easily visible to the public. 
Sec. 16-34. - Duration. 
Every permit issued under the provisions of this article shall be valid for the period of time stated therein, but in no event shall any such permit be issued for a period of time in excess of one month. 
Sec. 16-35. - Revocation. 
Any permit issued under the provisions of this article may be revoked by the board of commissioners for the violation by the permittee of any applicable provision of this Code, state law or city ordinance, rule or regulation. 
Chapter 17 - PLANNING AND ZONING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Zoning authority, § 1.4(15). 
Cross reference— Engineering standards and specifications adopted, § 2-3; building, Ch. 6; fire protection and prevention, Ch. 10; parks and recreation, Ch. 15; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 20; utilities, Ch. 24; zoning, App. A; subdivisions, App. B. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Liberal construction of chapter. 
This chapter shall be liberally construed so as to be consistent with all provisions of applicable state law upon the subject, particularly Chapter 69-12 of the Georgia Code, and further shall be liberally construed to accomplish the intended purpose. 
(Code 1964, § 20-1) 
Sec. 17-2. - Statute declared effective. 
Chapter 69-12 of the Georgia Code is hereby declared to be effective in the city, this declaration being made pursuant to the provisions of said chapter providing for and authorizing such declaration of effectiveness in the city. 
(Code 1964, § 20-2) 
Secs. 17-3—17-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference— Planning commission generally, Ga. Code Ann., Ch. 69-12. 

Sec. 17-16. - Created. 
There shall be and is hereby created and established a planning commission in and for the city. 
(Code 1964, § 20-4) 
Sec. 17-17. - Composition. 
The planning commission shall consist of seven (7) members. 
(Code 1964, § 20-6; Ord. No. 78-20, § 1, 7-3-78) 
Sec. 17-18. - Appointment. 
(a)  The members of the planning commission shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the consent of the board of aldermen. All members who have served on said commission shall be eligible for reappointment to succeed themselves. The term of any member of the commission in office on the effective date of this section, and the term of any member appointed to the commission prior to the first regular meeting of the mayor and council to be held in January, 1979, shall expire upon the appointment and qualification of a successor. 
(b)  At the first regular meeting of the mayor and council held in January, 1979, the seven (7) members of the planning commission shall be appointed or reappointed for terms as set forth in section 17-19. 
(Code 1964, § 20-7; Ord. No. 78-20, § 1, 7-3-78) 
Sec. 17-19. - Terms. 
At the first regular meeting of the mayor and council held in January, 1979, all seven (7) members of the planning commission shall be appointed or reappointed for initial terms of one, two (2) and three (3) years. At the time of appointment, at the first meeting of the mayor and council in January of 1979, two (2) members shall be appointed for one year; two (2) members shall be appointed for two (2) years; and three (3) members shall be appointed for three (3) years. Thereafter, the terms of all members shall be three (3) years. 
(Code 1964, § 20-7; Ord. No. 78-20, § 1, 7-3-78) 
Sec. 17-20. - Vacancies. 
Vacancies occurring in the membership of the planning commission shall be filled by appointments for unexpired terms only and in the same manner as for original appointments. 
Sec. 17-21. - Removal. 
Any member of the planning commission may be removed by the mayor or city council for cause after written notice and a public hearing. 
Sec. 17-22. - Compensation. 
All members of the municipal planning commission shall serve without compensation. 
Sec. 17-23. - Officers. 
The planning commission shall elect one of its members as chairperson who shall serve for one year or until such person is reelected or a successor is elected. A second appointive member shall be elected as vice-chairperson and shall serve for one year or until such person is reelected or a successor is elected. The commission shall appoint a secretary, who may be an officer or employee of the city or of the planning commission. 
Sec. 17-24. - Meetings. 
The planning commission shall meet at least once each month at the call of the chairperson and at such other times as the chairperson or commission shall determine. 
Sec. 17-25. - Rules and regulations. 
The rules, regulations, and provisions contained in Chapter 69-12 of the Georgia Code Annotated governing the creation, appointment, organization, powers, and duties of municipal and county planning commissions are hereby adopted as the rules, regulations, and provisions governing the planning commission of this municipality. 
Sec. 17-26. - Records. 
The planning commission shall keep a record of its proceedings, which record shall be open to public inspection. 
Sec. 17-27. - Employ personnel. 
Employees and staff may be appointed by the planning commission as necessary. 
Sec. 17-28. - Powers and duties. 
The municipal planning commission shall make careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of existing conditions and probable future developments and prepare plans for physical, social, and economic growth in an effort to promote the public health, safety, morals, convenience, prosperity, or general welfare of the municipality. In carrying out its objectives the planning commission shall have the following specific powers and duties: 
(a)  To prepare a master plan or parts thereof for the development of the city; 
(b)  To prepare and recommend for adoption a zoning ordinance and map for the city; 
(c)  To prepare and recommend for adoption regulations for the subdivision of land within the city limits and to administer the regulations that may be adopted; 
(d)  To prepare and recommend for adoption a plat or plats or an official map showing the exact location of the boundary lines of existing, proposed, extended, unlined or narrowed streets, public open spaces, or public building sites and provide for the regulation of construction of buildings or other structures within such lines; 
(e)  To cooperate with, contract with, or accept funds from federal, state, or local public or quasi-public agencies and to expend such funds; and 
(f)  To exercise all other powers and duties conferred upon municipal planning commissioners by Chapter 69-12 of the Georgia Code Annotated and by any other provisions of state law. 
(Code 1964, § 20-5) 
Chapter 17½ - PRECIOUS METALS, GEMS, PAWNSHOPS AND SCRAP METALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-05, § 1, adopted May 21, 2015, renamed Ch. 17½ and repealed the former Art. I, §§ 17½-1—17½-19, enacting a new Art. I as herein set out. The former chapter and article pertained to similar subject matter. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation. 
Cross reference— Licenses generally, Ch. 12; peddlers, Ch. 16. 

ARTICLE I. - PRECIOUS METALS, GEMS AND PAWNSHOPS 

Sec. 17½-1. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them as follows: 
Dealer in precious metals and gems means any person, whether as owner, agent or employee, who engages in the business of purchasing precious metals or gems or articles containing any precious metal or gems from members of the general public for resale to brokers, dealers or melters. 
Electronic reporting system means a computer based system as specified by the Chief of Police which is designed to record and transmit data and information electronically. 
Gems means any precious or semiprecious stone which is cut and polished. 
Goods means every species of tangible personal property. 
Pawnbroker means any person (with the exception of title pawnbrokers), whether as owner, agent or employee, engaged in whole or in part in the business of lending money on the security of pledged goods, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property on the condition that it may be redeemed or repurchased by the seller for a fixed price within a fixed period of time, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property from persons or sources other than manufacturers or licensed dealers as a part of or in conjunction with the business activities described in this section. 
Pawnshop means any person (with the exception of title pawnbrokers), whether as owner, agent or employee engaged in whole or in part in the business of lending money on the security of pledged goods, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property on the condition that it may be redeemed or repurchased by the seller for a fixed price within a fixed period of time, or in the business of purchasing tangible personal property from persons or sources other than manufacturers or licensed dealers as a part of or in conjunction with the business activities described in this section. 
Person means an individual, partnership, corporation, joint venture, trust, association, or other legal entity however organized. 
Precious metals means metals that are considered rare or having a high economic value including, but not limited to, silver, gold, platinum and similar metals and their alloys. 
(Ord. No. 81-3, § 1, 2-5-81; Ord. No. 15-05, § 1, 5-21-2015) 
Sec. 17½-2. - Violations and penalties. 
The performance of any act prohibited by any section or provision of this chapter, or the failure to perform any act required thereby, shall constitute a violation and an offense hereunder and any person found guilty in the city court of a violation of any section or provision of this chapter shall be punished as provided in section 1-10 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 81-3, § 2, 2-5-81; Ord. No. 15-05, § 1, 5-21-2015) 
Sec. 17½-3. - License required; application. 
(a)  No person shall engage in business as a dealer in precious metals and gems in the city except under a license granted by the city. 
(b)  A license for a dealer in precious metals and gems shall authorize the licensee to engage in the business of a dealer in precious metals and gems as defined herein. 
(c)  Application for a license shall be made to the city clerk. 
(d)  All applications for a license shall be accompanied by cash or a certified check in the amount of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). All applications shall be in writing upon a form supplied to all applicants by the clerk. The application shall be made by a person having at least a twenty-five (25) percent ownership interest in the business and shall set forth the names, addresses and ages of all persons having an ownership interest in the business and shall contain an accurate description of the premises upon which the business is to be conducted, along with the zoning classification therefor and such other information as may be required. 
(e)  All applicants shall swear or affirm that the information disclosed in the application is true and correct. 
(f)  The license application must be approved by the chief of police and accompanied by a report from the office of the chief of police indicating that the police department has made an investigation of all persons identified on the application as having an ownership interest in the business and that said investigation has not revealed any felony convictions or convictions for violation of any laws or ordinances involving larceny, burglary or theft of any description as defined in Title 26 of Georgia Code Annotated. A plea of guilty or nolo contendere or a bond forfeiture shall be considered a conviction for the purposes of this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 81-3, § 3, 2-5-81; Ord. No. 15-05, § 1, 5-21-2015) 
Sec. 17½-4. - Age requirements for owners, employees and sellers. 
(a)  Every person having an ownership interest in the business carried on by a dealer in precious metals and gems and all employees engaged in said business shall be at least eighteen (18) years of age. 
(b)  Persons engaged in the business of purchasing gems, precious metals or goods made from precious metals shall not purchase gems, precious metals or goods made from precious metals from any person who has not provided positive identification, including reliable proof that such person is at least eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Ord. No. 81-3, § 4, 2-5-81; Ord. No. 15-05, § 1, 5-21-2015) 
Sec. 17½-5. - Records required; inspection of records. 
Every person or business engaged as a pawnbroker, pawnshop, and dealer in precious metals and gems within the City of Dublin shall secure from every person from whom he receives any goods, whether by purchase or through pledge, trade, pawn or exchange, the following: 
(1)  Government-issued photo identification card, such as a driver's license, military identification card, state identification card or passport; 
(2)  The name, address, telephone number, race, sex, height, weight, date of birth, and a social security or driver's license number; 
(3)  A digital photograph clearly showing a frontal view of the subject's face for each transaction, and if multiple transactions are made at different times of the same day a separate photo shall be taken. Each digital image shall be labeled with the date and time of the transaction and stored in such a manner that they are safe from corruption; a video surveillance system that records and stores the information set forth above shall be deemed to comply with the requirements of this subsection; 
(4)  A complete and accurate description of the goods acquired, including the following information, if available: 
(a)  Brand name. 
(b)  Model number. 
(c)  Manufacturer's serial number. 
(d)  Color, as apparent to the untrained eye. 
(e)  Precious metal type, weight, and content if known. 
(f)  Gemstone description. 
(g)  In the case of firearms, the type of action, caliber or gauge. 
(h)  Any other unique identifying marks, numbers, or letters. 
(i)  The date and time of the transaction. 
(j)  For jewelry and gems, a digital photograph of the goods acquired. 
(5)  The pawnbroker, pawnshop and dealer in precious metals and gems shall maintain the above information and digital photographs for a period of three (3) years and make the same available to law enforcement personnel upon request. 
(6)  The pawnbroker, pawnshop and dealer in precious metals and gems shall require the seller to sign a statement verifying that the seller is the rightful owner of the goods or is entitled to sell, consign, or trade the goods. 
(Ord. No. 81-3, § 5, 2-5-81; Ord. No. 15-05, § 1, 5-21-2015; Ord. No. 15-09, § 1, 10-15-2015) 
Sec. 17½-5.5. - Required format. 
Every pawnbroker, pawnshop and dealer in precious metals and gems located within the City of Dublin shall make a computer-generated daily report, in such format as prescribed by the City of Dublin Police Department, of all transactions that occurred during the twenty-four-hour period ending at 9:00 p.m. on the date of the report. A report shall be made each day prior to 11:59 p.m. for each day the operator or dealer transacts business. Daily reports shall be filed electronically by posting to a law enforcement web site designated by the police department. Where technological problems prevent posting the daily report electronically, a printed, typed or legibly handwritten report shall be delivered to the police department in lieu thereof. 
(Ord. No. 15-05, § 1, 5-21-2015) 
Sec. 17½-6. - Holding period. 
(a)  Any pawnbroker, pawnshop or dealer in precious metals and gems who takes goods on pawn, taking full title thereto, shall hold the goods so taken in pawn for at least thirty (30) days before disposing of the goods by sale, transfer, shipment or otherwise. 
(b)  Any pawnbroker, pawnshop or dealer in precious metals and gems who buys goods, taking full title thereto shall hold the goods so taken in on purchase for at least ten (10) days before disposing of the goods by sale, transfer, shipment or otherwise, and shall not alter the original form, shape or condition of such metals during the ten-day holding period. 
(c)  The City of Dublin Police Department or any other law enforcement agency has the authority to place property that is the subject of a law enforcement investigation on law enforcement hold. In that event, the Dublin Police Department or other law enforcement agency shall notify the pawnbroker, pawnshop, secondhand dealer, or dealer in precious metals and gems of the need for a law enforcement hold and identify all property subject to the law enforcement hold. Upon notification, it shall be the responsibility of the pawnbroker, pawnshop or dealer in precious metals and gems to maintain the subject property until such time as the property is released from law enforcement hold status or the property is confiscated as evidence. 
(Ord. No. 81-3, § 6, 2-5-81; Ord. No. 15-05, § 1, 5-21-2015) 
Sec. 17½-7. - Suspension or revocation of license. 
Licenses issued pursuant to this chapter shall be subject to revocation or suspension by the mayor and council, after reasonable notice and an opportunity to be heard has been given to a licensee. If the city manager has determined that there is probably cause to believe that a licensee or an employee of a licensee has violated this chapter, the city manager may temporarily suspend said license for a period not to exceed fifteen (15) days. 
(Ord. No. 81-3, § 7, 2-5-81; Ord. No. 15-05, § 1, 5-21-2015) 
Sec. 17½-8. - Administrative inspection of goods and records. 
(a)  The City of Dublin finds that pawnbrokers, pawnshops and dealers in precious metals and gems are engaged in a business that is a pervasively regulated industry and that proper enforcement of this article requires the administrative inspection of the commercial property where these businesses are located. 
(b)  All goods pledged or sold to a pawnbroker, pawnshop and dealer in precious metals and gems as well as all records and documentation required to be kept by this article shall be subject to an administrative inspection by the Dublin Police Department as provided for in this article. 
(c)  As such, every pawnbroker, pawnshop and dealer in precious metals and gems shall admit to his premises, without a search warrant, any police officer, or designated civilian employee of the City of Dublin Police Department, whose duties include verifying compliance with the requirements of this article and locating goods that are missing or stolen. These administrative inspections shall occur during normal business hours unless consented to by the pawnbroker, pawnshop and dealer in precious metals and gems. 
(Ord. No. 15-05, § 1, 5-21-2015) 
Sec. 17½-9. - Responsibility for enforcement. 
The Dublin Police Department shall have the responsibility for the enforcement of this article. Sworn officers of the City of Dublin Police Department and civilian employees designated by the police department shall have the authority to inspect establishments licensed under this chapter during the hours in which the premises are open for business. 
These inspections shall be made for the purpose of verifying compliance with the requirements of this article and to locate goods that are missing or stolen. This article shall not limit the authority of any other Dublin Police Department officer or employee to conduct inspections authorized by other provisions of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Dublin, Georgia. 
(Ord. No. 15-05, § 1, 5-21-2015) 
Sec. 17½-10. - Compliance with state and federal law. 
Nothing in this article shall relieve a pawnbroker, pawnshop, and dealer in precious metals and gems from the necessity of complying with state and federal law. 
(Ord. No. 15-05, § 1, 5-21-2015) 
Secs. 17½-11—17½-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SCRAP METALS 

Sec. 17½-20. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, unless the context otherwise requires: 
Book or register means a written record of transactions kept by any scrap metal processor, owner, keeper, proprietor, collector, or dealer, including sequentially numbered receipts containing the information required by section 17½-21. 
Dealer means any person, business, or entity that buys, sells, or distributes, for the purpose of recycling, any scrap metal on a wholesale basis. 
Scrap metal means a metal containing brass, copper, copper alloy, aluminum, stainless steel, or magnesium or another metal traded on the scrap markets. 
Working day means Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, and Saturday, except for such days which are designated a legal holiday by the state. 
(Ord. No. 08-01, 1-3-2008) 
Sec. 17½-21. - Register required. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in section 17½-23, every scrap metal processor as defined by Georgia Law, and any owner, keeper, or proprietor of a junk shop, junk store, salvage yard, or vehicle used to collect scrap metals (including vehicles), shall keep a book or register detailing all transactions involving scrap metals or vehicles. 
(b)  The scrap metal processor owner, keeper, proprietor, collector, or dealer shall record the identification of a seller of scrap metals or vehicles in the book or register and the method by which the seller verified his or her identity. The seller shall verify his or her identity by one (1) of the following: 
(1)  A valid Georgia driver's license; 
(2)  An identification card issued in accordance with O.C.G.A 40-5-100; 
(3)  A valid driver's license from another state that contains picture identification; 
(4)  A military identification card; 
(5)  A valid United States passport; or 
(6)  An alien registration card; 
(c)  The scrap metal processor, owner, keeper, proprietor, collector, or dealer shall require the seller of a scrap metal to provide a signed affidavit, in a form approved by the City of Dublin Police Department, sworn and affirmed under penalty of law, that the seller is the owner of the scrap metal or is otherwise entitled to sell the scrap metal. The scrap metal processor, owner, keeper, proprietor, collector, or dealer shall provide the affidavit form to the seller. 
(d)  The scrap metal processor, owner, keeper, proprietor, collector, or dealer shall include the following in the book or register: 
(1)  The date of purchase; 
(2)  The name, birth date, sex, and address of the seller; 
(3)  The license plate number of the vehicle used to deliver the material; 
(4)  A description of the purchase including weight and type; and 
(5)  The amount paid for the purchase. 
(e)  The book or register shall be made available to any peace officer for inspection at any reasonable time. 
(Ord. No. 08-01, 1-3-2008) 
Sec. 17½-22. - Photographic identity of seller. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in section 17½-23, the scrap metal processor, owner, keeper, proprietor, collector, or dealer of any scrap metal shall hold the scrap metal purchased separate and apart from all other materials purchased for a period of not less than seven (7) working days after the date of purchase, during which period the scrap metal processor, owner, keeper, proprietor, collector, or dealer shall not change the form of the scrap metal and shall permit any law enforcement officer to make inspection of the scrap metal. 
(b)  However, any transaction for the purchase of a scrap metal wherein a digital photographic record, video record, or other record format is used to clearly identify the seller and the scrap metal that the seller is selling shall be exempt from this holding requirement. The digital photographic record, video record, or other record format shall be retained for ninety (90) days, and the owner shall permit a law enforcement officer to make inspections and or copies of the record. The seller and the scrap metal that he is selling shall appear together and both must be clearly identifiable. 
(Ord. No. 08-01, 1-3-2008) 
Sec. 17½-23. - Exemptions. 
The following transactions and materials are exempt from the requirements specified in sections 17½-21 and 17½-22: 
(1)  Any materials purchased from a regulated public utility; 
(2)  Any materials purchased from an original manufacturer of the material or industrially generated scrap; 
(3)  The purchase of recyclable food and beverage containers from any source; except that, for purposes of this exemption, a metal beer keg shall not be considered a recyclable beverage container; 
(4)  Any scrap that is involved in a transaction between dealers or governmental entities; 
(5)  This article shall not apply to a person or entity that does not provide remuneration for scrap metals collected in drop-off curbside containers or at materials recovery sites. 
(Ord. No. 08-01, 1-3-2008) 
Sec. 17½-24. - Records kept two years. 
The information entered in the book or register, as provided in section 17½-21 shall be kept for two (2) years after the date of purchase of the scrap metal, unless otherwise required by law. 
(Ord. No. 08-01, 1-3-2008) 
Sec. 17½-25. - Violations and penalties. 
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided for in section 1-10 of the Code of the City of Dublin. 
(Ord. No. 08-01, 1-3-2008) 
Sec. 17½-26. - Presumption. 
There is a rebuttable presumption that metal purchased for the purpose of recycling is a scrap metal. 
(Ord. No. 08-01, 1-3-2008) 
Sec. 17½-27. - Cumulative of other laws. 
This article is to be interpreted in conjunction with O.C.G.A Title 43, Ch. 43, as cumulative thereof. Nothing in this article shall supersede existing state or federal laws or relieve a scrap metal processor from the necessity of complying with them. The requirements of state or federal laws shall be construed as cumulative of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 08-01, 1-3-2008) 
Chapter 18 - RAILROADS 

Sec. 18-1. - Responsibility for violations. 
Any person in charge of any passenger or freight train or engine violating any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1964, § 23-1) 
Sec. 18-2. - Blocking crossings. 
It shall be unlawful for any street in the city to be blocked by any stopped passenger or freight train or engine for a longer period than five (5) minutes without authority from the city manager. 
(Code 1964, § 23-3) 
Sec. 18-3. - Maintenance of crossings, bridges, water conductors. 
It shall be the duty of all railroad companies to keep the street crossings over their tracks level with the tops of the rails by planks or otherwise, and in a safe and convenient condition for vehicles and pedestrians. When the railroad runs under any street so as to make a bridge necessary, it shall be the duty of said company to keep such bridge safe and in good repair at all times. They shall also keep their water conductors sound and large so as to carry off and leave no standing water. Upon failure of any railroad company to comply with this section the agent of said company shall be served with a notice of the defect and, upon the failure to comply herewith within five (5) days, the same shall be remedied by the city at the expense of the company and the costs collected by execution against the company as provided in case of a nuisance. Any company failing after notice to remedy such defect shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1964, § 23-5) 
Chapter 19 - SCHOOLS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19-1. - Name of system. 
The public school system of the city shall be known as "The Dublin Public Schools." 
(Code 1964, § 25-1) 
Secs. 19-2—19-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY BOARD OF EDUCATION[1]
