ARTICLE 14. - SOLAR INSTALLATIONS 

Section 14.1. - In general; all solar systems. 
(a)  Definitions: 
(1)  Solar collection system means a solar energy system that transforms solar energy into another form of energy or transfers heat from a collector to another medium using mechanical, electrical, or chemical means. 
(2)  Small scale solar collection system means a solar collection system that transforms solar energy into another form of energy or transfers heat from a collector to another medium using mechanical, electrical, or chemical means, principally for use on the same property. 
(3)  Solar farm means a solar collection system placed in an area for the purpose of generating photovoltaic electric power principally for use off-site, or where the solar collection system is the primary land use on the parcel where it is located, or where the total area of a ground based or free standing solar collection system occupies more than one (1) acre. This is also referred to as a "solar park," "solar power plant" or "solar photovoltaic farm." 
(b)  Solar collectors shall not emit unreasonable glare. Exterior surfaces of the collectors and related equipment shall have a non-reflective finish. Solar panels shall be placed and arranged such that reflected solar radiation or glare shall not be directed onto the habitable portion of adjacent buildings or properties, or onto roadways, in such manner as to cause a nuisance, impair the vision of a driver of any motor vehicle, or be detrimental to public health, safety, and welfare. 
(c)  Requirements for labeling and signage, installation, structural certification, roof covering must comply with applicable building codes. 
(d)  All systems must be clearly marked, including the: 
(1)  Main service disconnect; 
(2)  All conduit, raceways, enclosures, cable assemblies and junction boxes to alert the fire service to avoid cutting them, every ten (10) feet, at turns and at penetrations, and at all combiner and junction boxes. 
(e)  To insure emergency personnel access, in particular for fire departments, roof mounted systems shall provide access and spacing requirements in order to: 
(1)  Insure roof access and egress. 
(2)  Provide pathways throughout the roof area. 
(3)  Provide smoke ventilation opportunity are areas. 
(f)  No permit shall be issued without proof that any electrical utility with power to the property has been informed of applicant's intent to install a solar collection system. 
(g)  Solar installations in any historic district shall require a certificate of appropriateness pursuant to the City of Dublin Historic District Ordinance. 
(h)  Solar Easements—Property owners installing any solar energy collection system shall be responsible for negotiating with surrounding property owners any desired solar easement, and for properly recording and enforcing same. 
(i)  A ten (10) foot area clear of trees, bushes or brush is required surrounding all ground mounted photovoltaic arrays. Vegetation in the area must be kept trimmed to less than eighteen (18) inches. 
(Ord. No. 15-04, § 1, 3-19-2015) 
Section 14.2. - Small scale solar collection systems. 
Small scale solar collection systems shall be considered an accessory use in all zoning districts in accordance with the following requirements: 
(a)  Freestanding solar panels: 
1.  Shall only be permitted as an accessory use on the lot of a principal structure. 
2.  Shall only be permitted in the rear and side yard the lot of a principal structure, or on the roof of conforming structures. 
3.  When located on the ground or attached to a framework located on the ground shall not exceed twenty (20) feet in height above the ground. 
4.  Shall conform to all set back requirements as for other uses in the districts in which they are located. 
5.  The total coverage of a lot with freestanding solar panels cannot exceed fifty percent (50%) lot coverage or the maximum allowable coverage for the district in which they are located, whichever is less. 
6.  Small solar panel systems not connected to the electrical system of the structures on the property or to the electrical grid in any way, such as solar security or decorative yard lights, and where the solar panel area measures less than two (2) square feet, are exempt from permitting. 
(b)  Roof-mounted solar panels: 
1.  Shall not project vertically more than the height requirements for the district in which they are located. 
2.  Where visible from the ground, shall be color-coordinated to harmonize with roof materials and other dominant colors of the structure. 
3.  Owner shall provide proof of notification to the managing authority of any airport located within five (5) miles of the proposed location where the size of the installation exceeds one (1) acre. 
(Ord. No. 15-04, § 1, 3-19-2015) 
Section 14.3. - Solar farms. 
Solar farms shall be permitted only in the M-2 District, in accordance with the following regulations: 
(a)  Solar farms shall be enclosed by perimeter fencing to restrict unauthorized access at a minimum height of six (6) feet, which shall be maintained in good condition, and any gates shall be securely locked. 
(b)  The manufacturers' or installers' identification and appropriate warning signage shall be posted at the site in a clearly visible manner. At least one sign shall be posted at the entrance to the facility showing the owner's name, address and emergency contact information. 
(c)  On-site power lines shall, to the maximum extent practicable, be placed underground. 
(d)  Solar farms shall adhere to the requirements of the district in which they are located, including but not limited to setbacks, height, lot area coverage requirements and buffer requirements. 
(1)  Where a solar farm is located on a major street, solar plant structures must be located a minimum of one hundred (100) feet from the right-of-way. 
(2)  A solar farm with solar panels within one hundred (100) feet of any street must have sufficient barriers to prevent a passenger vehicle leaving that street at the maximum speed limit from entering the solar field. A "passenger vehicle" means every motor vehicle having a gross vehicle weight of ten thousand (10,000) pounds or less. 
(e)  The following requirements shall be met for permit applications: 
(1)  A descriptive plot plan including setbacks, panel sizes, locations of property lines, buildings, and road right-of-ways. 
(2)  The plan shall include a fire suppression system sufficient to prevent a fire from spreading off the site. 
(3)  No solar farm shall be installed until evidence has been given to the city that the electric utility company has been informed of the customer's intent to install an interconnected customer-owned generator. Off-grid systems shall be exempt from this requirement. 
(4)  An affidavit or evidence of agreement between lot owner and the facility's owner or operator confirming that the owner or operator has permission of the property owner to apply for necessary permits for construction and operation of the urban solar farm. 
(5)  Proof of notification to the managing authority of any airport located within five (5) miles of the proposed location. 
(6)  Any other relevant studies, reports, certificates and approvals as may be reasonably requested by the City of Dublin, including but not limited to design review. 
(f)  The following requirements shall be met for decommissioning solar farms: 
(1)  Each applicant for a permit must submit decommissioning plans that describe the anticipated life of the solar project, the party responsible for decommissioning, the estimated decommissioning costs in current dollars, and the method for ensuring by bond that funds will be available for decommissioning and restoration. 
(2)  Preferred bond instruments shall include cash or surety from a bonding company with authority to operate in the State of Georgia and approved by the city. The bond shall consist of three components for purposes of determining its amount. The first component will address environmental liabilities including hazardous materials liabilities, such as risks associated with hazardous waste and hazardous substances. The second component will address the decommissioning, removal, and proper disposal, as appropriate, of improvements and facilities. The third component will address reclamation, re-vegetation, restoration, and soil stabilization. There shall be a single instrument to cover all potential liabilities. The entire bond amount may be used to address a single risk event such as hazardous materials release or groundwater contamination regardless of the fact that in calculating the total bond amount other risks were also considered. If the bond is used to address a particular risk, the holder would then be required to increase the bond amount to compensate for this use. 
(3)  Solar farms which have not been in active and continuous service for a period of one (1) year shall be removed at the owners or operators expense. 
(4)  The site shall be restored to as natural condition as possible within six (6) months of the removal. 
(5)  A site will be considered decommissioned when, after inspection and approval by the city, all structures and equipment are removed and the site is re-vegetated. 
(Ord. No. 15-04, § 1, 3-19-2015) 
APPENDIX B - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
AN ORDINANCE REGULATING THE SUBDIVISION OF LAND IN THE CITY OF DUBLIN, GEORGIA. 
ORDINANCE NO. 81-12 
AN ORDINANCE ADOPTING AND ENACTING A NEW SET OF SUBDIVISION REGULATIONS OF THE CITY OF DUBLIN, GEORGIA: AND PROVIDING FOR THE EFFECTIVE DATE OF SUCH ORDINANCE AND A PENALTY FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF, 
BE IT ORDAINED BY the Mayor and Council of Dublin, Georgia that: 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 81-12, § 1, adopted May 14, 1981, amended the Code by deleting former App. B, which contained the subdivision regulations, as amended by Ord. No. 80-20, § 1, adopted July 17, 1980, which consisted of Arts. 1—12 and Paving Specifications, derived from Ord. No. 71-5, adopted Feb. 15, 1971. Ord. ARTICLE 1. - PURPOSES, OBJECTIVES AND INTENT 
Many investments are affected when new homes are built, therefore, reasonable control and management of land development is necessary in order to protect these investments. 
The first investment to consider is that of the subdivision owner or developer. These regulations require the developer to meet certain standards in designing his subdivision that will provide him with desirable, saleable lots. This, in turn, will give his investors a certain guarantee of economic return. 
A careful planned development can instill a certain neighborhood pride even before the first individual homeowners move in. The second investor, the homeowner, is protected by ensuring the installation of proper facilities and recreational areas. Further, if the natural beauty is retained and protective covenants are established on the development, the homeowner's property value should increase rather than decline as has been the case in too many neighborhoods in the past. 
Probably the greatest error in the past has been the lack of recognition of the long term responsibilities involved in subdividing land. This error has proven to be costly and affects a third investor, the Dublin city government. Representing the taxpayer and his family, the Dublin city government intends to protect his interest and other interests involved by the adoption and enforcement of these regulations. 
The intent of these regulations is to provide for the harmonious development of the city and to ensure coordinated growth with adequate provision for traffic, recreation, drainage, sewerage and other factors which affect higher density development. This control is necessary to ensure the maximum return on the private and public investment, and at the same time to ensure the homeowner's protection and the subdivider full consideration of his investment and responsibility. 
ARTICLE 2. - AUTHORITY 
The Dublin subdivision regulations are adopted under authority granted by the General Planning Enabling Legislation of the State of Georgia, 1957, as amended, (Georgia Code Annotated, Section 69-12 et seq.) The Dublin Planning Commission shall be the official platting authority. 
No subdivider shall sell or negotiate to sell any lot in a proposed subdivision by reference to or exhibition of or by any other use of a plat of such subdivision, until such plat has been given final approval by the Dublin Planning Commission, as certified thereon, and recorded in the office of the Superior Court of Laurens County. 
ARTICLE 3. - JURISDICTION, VIOLATION AND PENALTIES 
These regulations shall govern all subdivisions of land within the corporate limits of Dublin, Georgia, and shall govern all undeveloped units of existing subdivisions. 
Any person, firm, corporation or agent, servant, employee, officer or contractor for any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any provision, requirement, term, or condition of this ordinance shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and each day of such violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
ARTICLE 4. - LEGAL STATUS PROVISIONS 
Should any section provisions of this ordinance be declared by the courts to be unconstitutional or invalid, such declaration shall not affect the ordinance as a whole or any other part thereof other than the part so declared to be unconstitutional or invalid. 
This ordinance shall take effect and be enforced from and after its adoption. All ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict hereby are repealed. 
ARTICLE 5. - DEFINITIONS 
Except as otherwise specified herein, all words used herein shall have their customary dictionary definition. Words used in the present tense include the future; the singular number includes the plural and the plural includes the singular. The word "shall" is mandatory, not directory. 
Alley: A narrow service way dedicated for public use providing a secondary public means of access to abutting properties and not intended for general traffic circulation. 
Building setback line: A line on the plat generally parallel to the street right-of-way line, indicating the limit beyond which buildings or structures may not be erected. 
Comprehensive development plan: The various maps, charts, and descriptive and explanatory material and all textual matter approved by the Dublin Planning Commission and city council to guide and shape the growth of Dublin. 
Development: The act of building structures and/or installing site improvements. 
Easement: A grant by property owners of the use for a specific purpose (or purposes) of a piece of land by the general public, a corporation, or a person or persons. 
Lot or plat: Portion of a subdivision or other parcel of land, intended as a unit for transfer of ownership or for building development. 
Lot depth: The distance between the front and the rear lot lines. 
Lot frontage: The front of a lot shall be construed to be the portion nearest the street. On corner lots and through lots, all sides of a lot adjacent to streets shall be considered frontage. 
(a)  Corner lot means a lot at the intersection of at least two (2) streets. 
(b)  Interior lot means a lot other than a corner lot, which has front on only one street. 
(c)  Through lot means a lot, other than a corner lot, which has frontage on more than one street. 
Lot width: The distance between the side lot lines measured at the front of the building. 
Planning commission: The Dublin Planning Commission, as established by the city government in accordance with Georgia General Act. No. 358, 1957, as amended. 
Public way: A piece of land over which the general public has a right of usage whether acquired through prescription, by adverse use of the general public, or otherwise. 
Street: A public thoroughfare which affords the principal means of access to abutting property. This includes avenues, roads, lanes, drives, or other means of ingress or egress regardless of the terms used to designate them. The subdivider shall be concerned with the following types of street development: 
(a)  Local service street is one which is intended to provide direct access to abutting property. 
(b)  Marginal access street is generally parallel and adjacent to controlled access thoroughfares, arterials or connector streets, for the purposes of providing access to abutting properties and of separating high speed from local traffic. 
(c)  Cul-de-sac is a service street having one end open to traffic, with the other end permanently terminated by a turnaround. 
Subdivider: A person, firm, corporation or association undertaking the process of subdivision on a lot, tract or parcel of land for the purpose of transfer of ownership [or] building development whether immediate or future. 
Subdivision: Any division or redivision of a lot, tract or parcel of land, regardless of its prospective use. Said subdivision may be accomplished by platting or a description by metes and bounds or otherwise, into two (2) or more lots or other division for sale or improvement. The term "subdivision" as used herein shall mean the act of subdivision and shall not be construed in a literal or restricted sense. However, where appropriate to the context the term "subdivision" shall mean the aggregate of all parcels held by one owner or combination of owners and designated to be developed or sold as parcels related to each other or interdependent through the use of streets, easements or other right-of-way or public facility. The following properties, however, shall not, for the purpose of this ordinance, be deemed subdivisions: 
(a)  The combination or recombination of portions of previously platted lots where the total number of lots is not increased and the resultant lots are in accord with the zoning ordinance as amended. 
(b)  Division of land into parcels having five (5) or more acres where no new street or roadway is involved. 
(c)  Division of land into two (2) or fewer lots, provided: 
(1)  Each lot abuts an existing public street, and is in accord with these regulations and with the zoning ordinance as amended. 
(2)  No alteration of existing utility installation is involved. 
(3)  That the planning commission is notified of such division of land through a plat and executes a formal release of the property for recording and development purposes. 
ARTICLE 6. - PROCEDURES FOR SUBDIVISION PLAT APPROVAL 

Section 6.1. - General application. 
Any person proposing to subdivide land shall submit to the Dublin Planning Commission plats of the proposed subdivision which shall conform to all the requirements set forth in these regulations: 
Section 6.1.1. Preliminary plat approval required prior to clearing and grading streets. No clearing or grading of proposed streets shall begin prior to approval of the preliminary plat by the Dublin Planning Commission as certified thereon. This prohibition shall extend to any other improvement related to the development of the proposed subdivision. 
Section 6.1.2. Development plans approval required prior to construction of improvements. No required subdivision improvement contained herein shall commence prior to the approval of development plans by the planning commission, except that clearing and grading of streets may commence after preliminary plat approval. 
Section 6.1.3. Recording of final plat required prior to sale of lot. No subdivider shall sell or negotiate to sell any lot in the proposed subdivision by reference to or exhibition of or by any other use of plat of such subdivision until such plat has been given final approval by the planning commission, as certified thereon, and recorded in the office of the clerk of the Superior Court of Laurens County. 
Section 6.1.4. Subdivision of "as built" plans prior to final acceptance by governing body. Final acceptance of any subdivision improvements which vary substantially from the approved development plans shall not be given by the city prior to the submission and approval of "as built" plans and any other technical information which may be required. 
Section 6.1.5. Legal status of public street required. No land dedicated as a public street shall be accepted, opened, or improved, nor shall any utilities or other facilities be installed therein unless such street corresponds in its location and lines with a street shown on a plat approved by the planning commission. Streets which shall have been accepted or opened as, or otherwise shall have received legal status of a public street, prior to the adoption of these regulations may be improved, or utilities or other facilities may be installed therein. The city council, however, may locate and construct or may accept any other street if the ordinance or other measure for such approval is first submitted to the planning commission for its review and comment. 
Section 6.1.6. Access to public street required. No building permit shall be issued and no building or other structures shall be erected on any lot unless such lot has access to a street which shall have been accepted or opened as, or otherwise shall have received the legal status of a public street; provided, however, that private streets and other private accessways may be approved under the terms of these regulations in PUD developments, condominium projects, townhouses, commercial developments, shopping centers, apartment projects or other developments. 
Section 6.2. - Discretionary preapplication review. 
Whenever the subdivision of a tract of land within the jurisdiction of the planning commission is proposed, the subdivider may, at his discretion, consult early and informally with the city's engineer for advice and assistance. However, in no instance shall the discretionary preapplication review be made or accepted in lieu of the required plats and specifications contained herein. 
Section 6.3. - Procedure of preliminary plat approval. 
Prior to the cutting or grading of any street or the making of any street improvements or the installation of utilities, the subdivider shall submit to the planning commission, and receive approval of, a preliminary plat of the proposed subdivision in accordance with the following procedure: 
Section 6.3.1. Application for preliminary plat approval. Following discretionary preapplication review, if any, the subdivider shall submit formal application for preliminary plat approval. The application shall be received not less than thirty (30) days prior to the next regular meeting of the planning commission. Four (4) copies of the preliminary plat shall be submitted along with any other documents required in Section 6.4. 
Section 6.3.2. Review of preliminary plat. The city engineer and the designated platting officer shall check the plat for conformance to the regulations set forth in this document and ensure that the findings of the reviewing department are noted and forwarded to the planning commission. In such instances where public sewer and/or public water is not available, the review of the health department, along with any conditions or modifications required by that agency, shall be on file prior to preliminary plat approval. 
Section 6.3.3. Hearing on preliminary plat. The planning commission shall hold a hearing on the preliminary plat at the first regular meeting following the review of the various departments. 
Section 6.3.4. Preliminary plat approval. Following the preliminary plat hearing, the planning commission shall: 
(a)  Issue a certificate of preliminary plat approval; or 
(b)  Issue a certificate of conditional preliminary plat approval; the conditions shall be indicated on the preliminary plat or attached in writing; or 
(c)  Disapprove the preliminary plat or any portion, in which case the planning commission shall notify the subdivider in writing, with a statement on the reasons for disapproval. 
Section 6.3.5. Action of the planning commission. The planning commission's decision shall be noted on four (4) copies of the preliminary plat with one copy being returned to the subdivider, one copy to the county health department, one copy to the city's engineer and one copy being added to the records of the planning commission. Approval of preliminary plat does not constitute approval of any required improvements, development plans, or a final plat. It indicated only approval of the subdivision layout and no work may proceed beyond the clearing and grading of lots and proposed streets. 
Section 6.3.6. Expiration time. Preliminary plat approval shall expire and be of no further effect twelve (12) months from the dates of the preliminary plat approval unless the time is extended by the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 06-21, § 1, 11-2-2006) 
Section 6.4. - Preliminary plat specifications. 
Section 6.4.1. Preparation and specifications. The preliminary plat shall be prepared by a registered Georgia land surveyor and all of the following specifications shall be shown. No plat shall be filed or accepted for review which does not meet the minimum specifications contained in these regulations and in the Georgia State Plat Act, as amended. 
Section 6.4.2. Scale. The preliminary plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn at a scale not less than one hundred (100) feet to one inch. The plat shall have a closure precision of one foot in five thousand (5,000) feet. 
Section 6.4.3. Sheet size. The preliminary plat shall be drawn in ink on suitable permanent reproducible material, on sheets seventeen (17) by twenty-four (24) inches. If the complete plat cannot be shown on one sheet, it may be shown in sections of more than one sheet with an index map drawn at a reduced scale. 
Section 6.4.4. Ground elevations. The preliminary plat may show ground elevation based on the datum plane of the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey. At least one bench mark shall be tied to the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey. 
Section 6.4.5. Existing conditions to be provided on preliminary plat. 
(a)  Title ("Preliminary"), numerical scale; north arrow, indicating both magnetic and true north; date; inscription stating "Not For Final Recording." 
(b)  A vicinity map showing the location of the tract with approximate distance to obvious geographical locations. 
(c)  Present tract designation according to official records, title under which proposed subdivision is to be recorded with names and addresses of owners of the property to be subdivided, name and address of subdivision designer, notation stating acreage to be subdivided, bench marks, certification of registered Georgia land surveyor, and date of survey. 
(d)  Deed record names of adjoining property owners or subdivisions with deed plat book referenced. 
(e)  Other conditions on adjacent land character and location of buildings, railroads, power lines, towers, and other nearby nonresidential land uses or adverse influences within one hundred (100) feet. 
(f)  Boundary lines, bearing and distances of perimeter boundaries. 
(g)  Existing easements; location, width, and purpose. 
(h)  Contour lines on sea level data. These shall be drawn at intervals of not more than five (5) feet. Contour lines shall be based on field surveys or photogrammetric methods from aerial photographs. The basis for the topographic contour shown shall be specified. 
(i)  Existing streets on, abutting, and adjacent to the tract; name, right-of-way width, roadway width. 
(j)  Utilities on, abutting, and adjacent to the tract; location, size, and invert elevation of existing sanitary and storm sewer; location and size of water mains; location of gas lines, fire hydrants, and electric and telephone lines. 
(k)  Other conditions on the tract; wooded areas, tree masses, major rock outcroppings, houses, barns, shacks, all watercourses, marshes, swamps, and land subject to flooding as determined from past history of flooding, and other significant features. 
(l)  In case of resubdivision, a copy of the existing plat with proposed changes superimposed thereon. 
Section 6.4.6. Proposed conditions to be provided on preliminary plat. 
(a)  Layout of streets showing right-of-way width and roadway widths. 
(b)  Proposed layout including lot lines with rough dimensions, lot numbers, block letters, street and alley lines with letter designations for proposed street names, sites reserved through covenants, easements, dedication or otherwise for public uses, for nonpublic or community uses exclusive of single-family dwellings, for nonresidential uses, and for multifamily dwellings. 
(c)  Designation of land to be reserved or dedicated for public use, together with their purposes and limitations or conditions of such reservations or dedications, if any. 
(d)  Sites, if any, for multiple family dwellings if located within the proposed subdivision, or adjacent to, or abutting thoroughfare needed as a result of the proposed subdivision. 
Section 6.4.7. Certificate of preliminary approval. A certificate of preliminary approval of the preliminary plat by the planning commission shall be inscribed on the plat as follows: 
"In that all the requirements of the Preliminary Plat have been fulfilled (and with consideration to any conditions noted below), this subdivision plat was given Preliminary Approval by the City of Dublin Planning Commission on _______, 19_______. The Preliminary Approval does not constitute approval of the Development Plans or the Final Plat. This Certificate of Preliminary Plat Approval shall expire in twelve (12) months and be null and void on _______, 19_______. 
_____ Date 
_____ Chairperson, City of Dublin Planning Commission" 
"NOT FOR FINAL RECORDING" 
Section 6.4.8. Installation of site improvements. After receiving a certificate of preliminary approval by the commission, the subdivider is limited to clearing and grading the streets and lots. 
Section 6.5. - Procedure for development plan approval. 
Prior to the installation of any required improvements or utilities, other than the clearing or grading of streets and lots, the subdivider shall submit to the planning commission and receive approval of development plans in accordance with the following procedures: 
Section 6.5.1. Application for development plan approval. Application for development plan approval may be concurrent with preliminary plat approval or subsequently as a separate review. In either instance the application shall be received not less than thirty (30) days prior to the next regular meeting of the planning commission. Two (2) copies of the development plans shall be submitted along with any other documents required in Section 6.6. 
Section 6.5.2. Review of development plans. The city engineer and other city and county officials he deems necessary, shall review the development plans for conformance to the regulations set forth in this document and ensure that the findings of the reviewing departments are noted and forwarded to the planning commission. 
Section 6.5.3. Hearing on development plans. The planning commission shall hold a hearing on the development plans at its next regular meeting following the review of the various departments. The hearing for the approval of the development plans may be held concurrently with or separate from the review of the preliminary plat. 
Section 6.5.4. Development plan approval. Following the hearing on the development plans and other related materials, the planning commission shall: 
(1)  Issue a certificate of development plan approval, noting the conditions of such approval on the plans or attached in writing; or 
(2)  Disapprove the development plans or any portion, in which case, the planning commission shall notify the subdivider in writing with a statement on the reasons for disapproval. 
Approval of the development plan does not constitute approval of the final plat. It authorizes that work may begin on the construction and installation of all improvements for the proposed layout shown on the preliminary plat and subject to the inspection by the city engineer. 
Section 6.5.5. Action of the planning commission. The planning commission's decision shall be noted on two (2) copies of the development plan with one copy being returned to the subdivider, and one being added to the records of the planning commission. 
Section 6.5.6. Expiration time. Development plan approval shall expire and be of no further effect twelve (12) months from the date of approval unless the time is extended by the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 06-21, § 2, 11-2-2006) 
Section 6.6. - Development plan specifications. 
Section 6.6.1. Preparation and specifications. The development plans shall be drawn according to the preliminary plat specifications prescribed in Sections 6.4.1 through 6.4.3. 
Section 6.6.2. Proposed conditions to be provided on development plans. 
(a)  Plans of any sanitary sewer with service grades, pipe sizes, and points of discharge, together with certified copy of all load design factors and computations, and sufficient dimensions to locate same on ground. 
(b)  Location and size of all proposed drainage structures, including catch basins, grates, headwalls, and any extensions. 
(c)  Acreage of drainage area are [or] constant used in determining the size of the structures by a formula approved by the city engineer. 
(d)  Location of land subject to flooding, indicated by flood crescent contour, as provided by city, county or other source. 
(e)  Plans for storm drainage system with grade, pipe size, and location of outlet, together with certified copy of all drainage areas, design factors, and computations. 
(f)  Plans for water supply system with pipe sizes and location of hydrants, valves and all appurtenances. 
(g)  Existing and finished grades including the clear identification of areas in which substantial grade changes and filling will occur. 
(h)  Engineering data as listed below: 
(1)  Three-line profile of proposed streets, showing center line elevations along right-of-way lines on either side of street, exposed rock to be indicated, drawn on standard plan and profile sheet with plan section, showing street layout, width, curvature and drainage required. 
(2)  Where sanitary or storm sewers are to be installed the grade, size of pipe, location of manholes shall be indicated on the road profile. 
(3)  Profiles covering roadways that are extensions of existing roadways shall include elevations at fifty-foot intervals for a minimum distance of three hundred (300) feet back to the beginning point and forward to the ending point or such additional distance as may be required by the city engineer. 
(4)  All elevations shall be coordinated and tied to the U.S.G.S. bench marks, where feasible. 
(5)  The above submittals shall be drawn to a scale no less than as follows: 
Horizontal scale       1:100 feet 
Vertical scale       1:10 feet 
(i)  Where a proposed road abuts the plat boundary, a properly executed slope easement shall be submitted. A slope easement shall be also submitted under such conditions as may be required by the city engineer. 
Section 6.6.3. Certificate of development plan approval. A certificate of approval of the development plans by the planning commission shall be inscribed on the plans as follows: 
"In that all the requirements of Development Plans have been fulfilled (and with consideration to any conditions noted below), this subdivision plan was given approval by the City of Dublin Planning Commission on _______, 19_______. This approval does not constitute approval of the Final Plat or acceptance of improvements. This Certificate of Approval shall expire in twelve (12) months and be null and void on _______, 19_______. 
_____ Date 
_____ Chairperson, City of Dublin Planning Commission" 
"NOT FOR FINAL RECORDING" 
Section 6.6.4. Installation of site improvements. After receiving a certificate of approval for the development plans by the planning commission, the subdivider may then provide to install [for installation of] any and all improvements required under these regulations and any other applicable regulations of the city. In lieu of the completion of all improvements prior to submission of the final plat, the subdivider shall post a performance bond or cashier's check approved by the city in accordance with section 6.9. In addition to the subdivider's estimate of improvement costs, it shall be necessary for the city engineer to solicit a cost estimate for same from a bondable contractor. It shall also be necessary that final estimate of improvement cost be mutually agreed upon by the city engineer, the planning commission, and the subdivider. 
Section 6.7. - Final plat procedure. 
After completion of physical development of the subdivision or the posting of a performance bond guaranteeing any unfinished or any unacceptable portion of the same, the subdivider shall submit to the planning commission a final plat in accordance with the following procedures: 
Section 6.7.1. Application for final plat approval. Within twelve (12) months or (within such additional time as may be granted by the planning commission) after approval of the development plans, the subdivider shall submit to the planning commission a formal application for final plat approval. Four (4) copies of the final plat shall be submitted along with any other documents in Section 6.8. 
Section 6.7.2. Review of the final plat. The final plat shall be reviewed for conformance with the approved preliminary plat, the approved development plans, the requirements of those regulations, and any special conditions or restrictions imposed by the planning commission. 
Section 6.7.3. Hearing on the final plat. The planning commission shall provide a hearing of the final plat at the first regular meeting of the planning commission following submission of the final plat. The city engineer shall present at the planning commission hearing on the final plat, his written findings and recommendations. 
Section 6.7.4. Planning commission approval. The planning commission may give final approval provided the final plat and approved development plans and that all conditions specified by the planning commission and specified herein have been met; and shall sign a certificate of approval of all plats. Recording of the final plat shall be done in accordance with Section 6.9. 
Section 6.8. - Final plat specifications. 
Section 6.8.1. Conformance with the preliminary plat and development plans. The final plat shall conform to the conditions of the approved preliminary plat and development plans. 
Section 6.8.2. Original tracing specifications. The final plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn on suitable permanent reproducible material. The scale shall be one hundred (100) feet to one inch on a sheet seventeen (17) inches by twenty-four (24) inches. If the complete plat cannot be shown on one sheet of such size, it may be shown as written in sections on more than one sheet with an index map at a reduced scale. The final plat shall be in compliance with the Georgia State Plat Act, as amended. 
Section 6.8.3. Additional specifications. The final plat shall contain the following information: 
(a)  Primary control points with necessary descriptions and locations of such angles, bearings and similar data necessary for locating on ground. 
(b)  Tract boundary lines and property lines of residential lots and other sites with sufficient data to determine readily and to produce on the ground the location, bearing and length of every street line, lot line, boundary line, setback line whether curved or straight. This shall include but not be limited to the radius; length of arc; internal angles, and bearings of the tangents and tangent distances for the center line of curved streets and curved property lines that are not the boundary or curved streets. All dimensions shall be given to the nearest one-hundredth ( 1/100 ) of a foot and all angles shall be given to the nearest minute. 
(c)  Name and right-of-way width of each street or other right-of-way width of each street or other right-of-way. 
(d)  Location, dimensions, and purpose of any easement. 
(e)  Number of letter of identity of each lot and block. 
(f)  Purpose for which sites, other than residential lots are dedicated or reserved. 
(g)  Minimum building setback lines on all lots and other sites. 
(h)  Location and description of monuments and markers. 
(i)  Reference to recorded plats of adjoining land by record and name. 
(j)  Title, numerical scale, north arrow, and date. 
(k)  A statement of the private covenants, if they are brief enough to be put directly on the plat; otherwise, a statement as follows: "This plat is subject to the covenants set forth in the separate document(s) attached hereto dated _______, which hereby become a part of this plat," recorded on _______ and signed by the owner. 
(l)  Notation of the necessary certification shall be placed on the final plat as specified below in Sections 6.8.4 through 6.8.8 as applicable. 
Section 6.8.4. Surveyor's certification. A signed certification by a registered Georgia land surveyor certifying to the accuracy of the survey and the plat shall be placed on the final plat as follows: 
"In my opinion this plat is a correct representation of the land platted and has been prepared in conformity with the minimum standards and requirements of law and has been calculated for closures by latitudes and departments and is found to be accurate within foot in five thousand (5,000) feet. 
BY: _____ 
Registered Georgia Professional Land Surveyor No.: _____ 
Date: _______" 
Section 6.8.5. Owner's certification. A signed certification of ownership shall be placed on the final plat as follows: 
"Owner's Certification;  State of Georgia, County of Laurens 
The undersigned certifies that he is the owner of the land shown on this plat and acknowledges that plat and allotment to be his free act and deed and dedicated to public use forever all shown or indicated on this plat as streets, alleys, easements or parks. 
_____
_____ Owner's Name" 
Section 6.8.6. Reserved. 
Section 6.8.7. Certificate of approval by the city engineer. A signed certification of the city engineer shall be placed on the final plat as follows: 
"I certify that the owner, or his agent, has completed the construction and installation of the street drainage, utilities, and other improvements in accordance with the regulations of the City of Dublin, Georgia; or has posted a performance bond or cashier's check in lieu thereof. 
_____ Date 
_____ City Engineer" 
Section 6.8.8. Certificate of final approval by the commission. Certification of final plat approval by the planning commission shall be made only after every item of these regulations has been complied with and shall state the following: 
"I certify that all the requirements for Final Approval of this Plat have been fulfilled in accordance with the regulations of the City of Dublin, Georgia, and the requirements of the Dublin Planning Commission. 
Name  _____ Chairperson,  Dublin Planning Commission 
Date: _____ 
Section 6.8.9. City council acceptance of public streets. Once approved by the planning commission, the final plat and other supplementary material required shall be transmitted to the city council for final action. The approval of the final plat by the city council shall deem acceptance of the dedication of the streets and other public land as shown on the final plat on behalf of the public. 
Section 6.8.10. Certification of improvements prior to acceptance by the governing body. The planning commission and the city engineer shall not recommend that any subdivision improvements be accepted for maintenance by the city unless they have been installed in accordance with approved development plans or approved "as built" plans and other technical information which may be required. 
Section 6.9. - Recording of final plat. 
Upon the approval of the final plat by the city council, the owner or his agent shall have the final plat recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court for the sale of any lot in the subdivision. 
Upon recording of the approved final plat the original tracing or other permanent material, a reproducible print of the final plat at the original scale, with all certificates endorsed, shall be provided by the subdivider and shall be returned to the city for its files. 
Section 6.9.1. Approval. Approval of the final plat shall be effective and binding upon the planning commission and the City of Dublin, Georgia, for a period not to exceed five (5) years from final approval and recording of said plat and thereafter said approval shall expire and be null and void except to the extent that work on the subdivision has progressed, unless a request for an extension of time has been submitted to and is subsequently approved by the planning commission. This provision shall apply to all subdivision approvals including past, present, or future subdivisions. 
In the event past, present, or future subdivisions are not completed within five (5) years from the final approval and recording of the final subdivision plat and no extension has been granted and approved by the planning commission, plans must be renewed under the subdivision ordinance in existence at the time of request for renewal. 
Section 6.9.2. Requirement for "as built" plans and other technical information. Upon completion of the installation of the improvements required by these rules and regulations, the subdivider shall present to the city engineer one complete set of the construction plans and drawings showing the subdivision and its improvements. This set of plans and drawings shall include: 
(a)  "As built" plans of all streets and alleys showing the planned and actual location of all utility lines. 
(b)  "As built" centerline profiles of all streets. 
(c)  Profiles and inverted elevations of all storm and sanitary sewer lines as such improvements shall have actually been installed by the subdivider. 
(d)  A letter submitted by a registered surveyor certifying that all sewers, storm drains, curbing and paving, have been placed according to grade stakes set by him or his representatives to conform with construction plans submitted to and approved by the city engineer. 
ARTICLE 7. - GENERAL PRINCIPLES OF DESIGN 

Section 7.1. - Suitability of land. 
Land subject to flooding, improper drainage and erosion, as determined by the city engineer and any land deemed by the planning commission to be unsuitable for development shall not be platted for any uses as may continue such conditions or increase danger to health, safety, life or property unless steps are taken to eliminate the above-mentioned hazards. 
Section 7.2. - Access. 
When land is subdivided into larger parcels than ordinary building lots, such parcels shall be arranged and designed so as to allow for the opening of future streets and to provide access to those areas not presently served by streets. No subdivision shall be arranged and designed so as to allow for the opening of future streets and to provide access to those areas not presently served by streets. No subdivision shall be designed so as to completely eliminate street access to adjoining parcels of land. 
Section 7.3. - Conformance to comprehensive development plan. 
All subdivisions shall conform to the comprehensive development plan, zoning and subdivision regulations, and development policies of the City of Dublin in effect at the time of submission to the planning commission. 
Section 7.3.1. Where features of the comprehensive development plan such as school sites, parks, arterial streets, and other public spaces are located in a subdivision, or when features have not been anticipated by planning policy, but are considered essential by the planning commission, such features shall be dedicated or in lieu of dedication be reserved by the subdivider. Whenever such reserved land, or any portion, is not acquired, optioned, [or] condemned by the appropriate public agency within a one-year period from the date of recording the subdivision, the subdivider may claim the original reservation, or portion, and cause it to be subdivided in a manner suitable to the subdivider according to the subdivision regulations. 
Section 7.3.2. The planning commission may waive the abovementioned platting and reservation requirements, whenever the public body responsible for land acquisition executes a written release stating that such planned feature is not being acquired. 
Section 7.3.3. Whenever the plat proposes the dedication of land for public use and the planning commission or the appropriate agency finds that such land is not suitable for public use the planning commission may either refuse to approve the plat or it may require the rearrangement of lots to include such land. 
Section 7.4. - Zoning and other regulations. 
Whenever there is a discrepancy between the minimum standards and dimensions noted within these regulations and those contained in other regulations of the city, the more restrictive shall apply. 
Section 7.5. - Planned unit development. 
The standards and requirements of these regulations may be modified in the case of a planned unit development which is not divided into the customary lots, blocks and streets which, in the judgment of the planning commission provided adequate public spaces and improvement for the general well-being of the residents, provided zoning density standards are not exceeded, and which also provided such covenants and other legal procedures as will ensure achievement of the plan. Plans for such development shall be submitted to and approved by the planning commission whether or not such plat is to be recorded and no building permits shall be issued until such approval has been given. 
Section 7.5.1. No plans for a planned unit development (PUD) shall be reviewed or approved by the planning commission before the developer's site has been zoned to allow for such use. 
Section 7.6. - Modification of subdivision principles and standards of design. 
Section 7.6.1. Modifications of these regulations may be made where the subdivision shows that a provision of the regulations would cause unnecessary hardship if strictly adhered to, and/or where because of topography and other conditions particular to the site, and/or where, in the opinion of the planning commission, a modification may be made without otherwise nullifying the standard design specifications of the city and intent of these regulations or the Dublin Zoning Ordinance. Any modification thus authorized shall be noted on the final plat before approval of the plat. 
Section 7.6.2. Modifications of these regulations will be considered in order to ensure that the City remains competitive with other development markets. Innovative proposals which may not comply with the Subdivision Principals And Standards of Design will be considered in order to allow developers the flexibility of meeting consumer demands. Each proposal which deviates from the Subdivision Principals And Standards in this Ordinance, will be evaluated on its own merit; and, consideration will be based on the overall benefit to the citizens of Dublin. 
Section 7.6.3. Proposals which deviate from Subdivision Principals And Standards of Design must be submitted in writing to the City Engineer's office, with the necessary supporting documents, including the justification for the portions of the proposal which deviate from standards written in the Ordinance. After review of the proposal, the City Engineer will submit a written response to the developer. In accordance with established procedure, the Planning And Zoning Board will hold a hearing on the development plans. The Board's acceptance of proposals, which deviate from the Subdivision Principals And Standards Of Design in this Ordinance, will be based on the City Engineer's recommendation of the proposal's overall benefit. Proposals which necessitate City of Dublin capital expenditures, must also be approved by the City Council. 
ARTICLE 8. - REQUIRED DESIGN STANDARDS 

Section 8.1. - Required design standards. 
The design standards set forth in this article shall be observed in all plats which are required to be approved by the planning commission, except that standards for street improvements shall be applicable only to those plats for which street improvements are required as a condition of plat approval. 
Section 8.2. - Streets. 
Section 8.2.1. Existing streets shall be continued at the same or greater width but in no case less than the required width. 
Section 8.2.2. Street jogs with center line offsets of less than two hundred (200) feet shall not be permitted. 
Section 8.2.3. Except where topography or other conditions make it impractical, culs-de-sac or the dead-end streets shall not be greater than six hundred (600) feet in length. They shall be provided with a turnaround having a forty-foot radius to face a curb and a right-of-way radius of fifty (50) feet. 
Section 8.2.4. Reserve strips controlling access to streets, alleys and public grounds shall not be permitted. 
Section 8.2.5. Where a subdivision borders on or contains a railroad right-of-way, or limited access highway right-of-way, the planning commission may require a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such right-of-way, at a distance suitable for the appropriate use of the intervening land, as for parks in residential districts, or industrial purposes in appropriate districts. Such distances shall also be determined with due regard for the requirements of approach grades and future grade separations. 
Section 8.2.6. Street intersections shall be as nearly at right angles as possible and no intersection shall be at an angle less than sixty (60) degrees. Detailed designs of intersections may be required. 
Section 8.2.7. Curbline radius at street intersections shall be at least fifteen (15) feet and where the angle of street intersection is less than ninety (90) degrees, the planning commission may require a greater radius. 
Section 8.2.8. Right-of-way radius at street intersections shall parallel the curbline radius. 
Section 8.2.9. Alleys or service drives may be required on any lots to be used for multiple-family, commercial or industrial developments, but shall not be provided in residential blocks except where the subdivider produces evidence satisfactory to the planning commission of the need for alleys or service drives. 
Section 8.2.10. Half-streets shall be prohibited. 
Section 8.2.11. Easements shall be required having a minimum width of twenty (20) feet and located along the side and rear lot lines for utility. These easements shall, through deed covenants, be maintained clear of dense shrubbery, trees or fences. 
Section 8.3. - Street rights-of-way and paving widths. 
Section 8.3.1. Minimum street right-of-way widths shall be as follows: 
(a)  Marginal access street ..... 50 feet 
(b)  Local service street, curb and guttering ..... 50 feet 
(c)  Cul-de-sac ..... 50 feet 
(d)  Cul-de-sac (diameter) ..... 100 feet 
(e)  Alleys, service drives or private drives ..... 30 feet 
(f)  Streets of greater traffic capacity shall conform to the requirements of the Georgia Highway Department. 
Section 8.3.2. Street paving widths shall be no less than as follows: 
(a)  Marginal access streets ..... 28 feet 
(b)  Local service streets with curb and guttering ..... 28 feet 
(c)  Cul-de-sac streets ..... 28 feet 
(d)  Cul-de-sac turnarounds: 
(1)  Residential, outside pavement radius ..... 40 feet 
Residential, inside pavement radius ..... 20 feet 
(2)  Commercial and industrial, outside pavement radius ..... 60 feet 
Inside pavement radius ..... 30 feet 
(e)  Alleys, service drives or private drives ..... 20 feet 
(f)  (See Section 8.3.1 above). 
Section 8.3.3. Maximum and minimum grades for all streets shall not be in excess of fourteen (14) percent and not less than four-tenths (.4) percent. 
Section 8.3.4. Maximum radii of center line curvature for all residential streets shall be two hundred (200) feet. 
Section 8.4. - Block and lot design. 
Section 8.4.1. Block length and widths. 
(a)  Blocks shall be not greater than one thousand eight hundred (1,800) feet, measured along the center line of the block. When a block exceeds six hundred (600) feet in length the planning commission may require a fifteen-foot easement for a crosswalk through the block. If provided the crosswalk shall be four (4) feet paved walk. 
(b)  Blocks shall be wide enough to provide two (2) tiers of lots of minimum depth, except where abutting upon major thoroughfares, limited access highways, or railroads or where other situations make this requirement impracticable. 
Section 8.4.2. Lot size, shape and arrangement. 
(a)  The size, shape and orientation of every lot shall be subject to approval of the planning commission for the type of development and use contemplated. No lot shall be more than six (6) times as deep as it is wide at the building setback line, unless approved by the planning commission. 
(b)  Every residential lot shall conform to the minimum dimension and area requirements of the zoning ordinance, provided that every lot not served by a public sewer or community sanitary sewage system and/or public water shall meet the dimension and area requirements of the health department. 
(c)  Double frontage, unless required by the planning commission, shall be prohibited except where essential to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography, orientation and property size. A planting screen reservation of at least ten (10) feet, and across which there shall be no right access, may be required along the line of lots abutting such traffic artery or other disadvantageous use. 
(d)  Lot remnants (lots below minimum area or width left over after subdividing tracts of land) shall be prohibited. Such remnant areas shall be added to adjacent lots, rather than remain as unusable parcels. 
(e)  The subdividing of land adjacent to or surrounding an existing or proposed lake, shall be such that lots abutting the lake shall be drawn to the center line of the lake. Such requirement may be waived upon submittal to the planning commission of an acceptable method for the maintenance of the lake and any recreational operations to be provided thereon. 
ARTICLE 9. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS 
Every subdivider at his own expense shall be required to install or at his own expense have installed by the appropriate public utility the following utilities: 

Section 9.1. - Monuments. 
Right-of-way and property line monuments shall be placed in each subdivision in accordance with the following: 
Section 9.1.1. Right-of-way monuments. Reinforced concrete monuments four (4) inches in diameter or square, thirty (30) inches long, and a flat top, shall be set at street corners, at points where the street lines intersect the exterior boundaries of the subdivision, and at angle points and points of curve in a street. The top of the monument shall have an indented cross to identify properly the location, and shall be extended no less than six (6) inches above the finished grade. 
Section 9.1.2. Property line monuments. An iron pin imbedded at least two (2) feet into the ground shall be required at each lot corner and each point where the property line changes direction. Such iron pin shall be at least one-half (½) inch in diameter and shall extend no less than one inch above the finished grade. 
Section 9.2. - Street grading. 
All streets, roads, and alleys shall be graded to provide the necessary paving, roadway, drainage, and safety requirements. The preparation of the right-of-way before grading is started and the construction cuts and fills shall be in accordance with the Standard Design Specifications of the City. 
Section 9.3. - Storm drainage. 
An adequate system based upon at least a ten-year storm frequency shall be provided for the proper drainage of all surface water originating in or affecting the subdivision. The subdivider shall also provide adequate drainage for springs and other groundwater drainage. The drainage system shall conform to Standard Design Specifications of the City; and shall include necessary curbing, pipes, culverts, headwall, drop inlets, bridge ditches, or any other type of drainage facility needed to control the flow of water in, around, or through the subdivision. 
Section 9.4. - Installation of utilities. 
After grading is completed and approved before any base is applied, all of the underground utilities, water mains, sewer mains, and all service connections related thereto shall be installed completely and approved throughout the length of the street, according to the Standard Design Specifications of the City. All driveways for houses to be built by the subdivider shall be cut and drained. Where the utility mains are off the pavements, the subdivider may elect to omit the installation of service connections, providing that such time as these service connections are needed, they may be jacked across the street without breaking or weakening the existing pavement. 
Section 9.5. - Slopes and shoulder improvements. 
The minimum ratio for all filled or cut slopes (including drainage ditches) shall be three to one and the minimum width for all shoulders from the back edge of the curb, if installed, shall be nine (9) feet. All shoulders shall slope one-half (½) inch to the foot. When all construction is completed, all slopes and shoulders shall be cleared of all rubbish and shall have a stand of grass to prevent undue erosion, either by sprigging or seeding. 
Section 9.6. - Street paving. 
Street base and paving shall be installed according to the Standard Design Specifications of the City. Street paving widths shall be in conformance with standards set forth in Section 8.3.2. 
Section 9.7. - Curb and guttering. 
Curb and guttering shall be installed on all streets according to the Standard Design Specifications of the City. 
Section 9.8. - Sidewalks. 
Sidewalks shall be provided in subdivisions located within one mile from an existing or proposed school. Sidewalks shall have the minimum width of four (4) feet in paving and shall meet the Standard Design Specifications of the City. 
Section 9.9. - Water supply. 
The waterlines shall be installed in conformance with the Standard Design Specifications of the City. 
Section 9.10. - Sanitary sewer. 
All sewer facilities shall be installed in accordance with the standards of the Environmental Protection Division of the State of Georgia Department of Natural Resources and the Standard Design Specifications of the City. 
Section 9.11. - Gas. 
When gas mains are connected with the gas distribution system, the lines shall be installed in such a manner as to serve adequately all lots shown on the subdivision plats. The gas lines shall be constructed in conformance with the Standard Design Specifications of the City. 
Section 9.12. - Fire hydrants. 
Standard fire hydrants as specified by the Standard Design Specifications shall be installed as a part of the water distribution system. Fire hydrants shall be located at all entrances to subdivision developments (both residential and commercial), at every street intersection inside the subdivision, and at any other locations required, so that no distance between fire hydrants exceeds five hundred (500) feet. 
Fire hydrants shall be installed so that there is a minimum of eighteen (18) inches and a maximum of twenty-four (24) inches of clearance from the bottom of the steamer (4½") outlet to the finished grade when the final grading is completed. The steamer (4½") outlet shall be turned toward the street. 
Fire hydrants shall be placed so that no other above ground utility (gas meters or sub-station, power poles or transformer boxes, telephone or cable junction boxes, or fence) is within five (5) feet. The planting of flowers and shrubbery shall take into consideration the mature growth size and not be planted with five (5) feet and kept maintained (trimmed or manicured) so that the foliage will not encroach on this five-foot area and hinder the fire department with locating fire hydrants. 
(Ord. No. 93-15, 12-9-93) 
Section 9.13. - Street lighting. 
The general standard of residential street lighting for the city is as follows: 
(a)  Underground electrical distribution. For the provisions of street lighting at intersections, dead ends or courts, luminaries are to be mounted on twenty-five-foot bronze fiber-glass poles and of an approved type eight thousand five hundred-fifty (8,550) lumen HPS unit, unless otherwise specified by the City. Maximum spacing shall not exceed four hundred (400) feet for straight streets; and for curved streets, irregular contours and intersections, this spacing shall be altered as conditions indicate so as to provide adequate lighting. 
(b)  Aboveground electrical distribution. For the provisions of street lighting at intersections, dead ends or courts, luminaries are to be mounted where practical on electrical distribution poles and shall be provided by the city. Spacing shall be determined by the city. 
(Ord. No. 88-10, § 1, 3-3-88) 
Section 9.14. - Administrative procedures. 
The administrative procedures for installing the subdivision improvements required herein shall be as follows: 
(a)  When construction may begin. Construction and installation of any required public improvement shall not begin until the planning commission has given preliminary plat and development plan approval for the new subdivision. The subdivider shall then confer with the city engineer to determine the method and estimated cost of construction and installation of the required improvements. 
(b)  Inspections and approval. During the construction and installation of the required public improvements, the city engineer shall from time to time make field inspections and supervise said work as predetermined and agreed upon by the city engineer and the subdivider. After completion of all the construction and installation of the required public improvements and if the said work has met the city's specifications as determined by the city engineer, the city engineer shall notify the subdivider in writing of the approval of said work. 
(c)  Official acceptance by the city. The city may officially accept the completed work on the construction and installation of the written acceptance by the city engineer but not before approval by the planning commission of the final plat and/or "as built" plans which may be required. 
(d)  Cashier's checks. If the subdivider does not wish to construct any or all the required public improvements prior to submitting the subdivision plat to the planning commission for final approval, and a performance bond is not submitted, a cashier's check shall be required, such check being equal to the estimated cost of construction. When the work has been completed satisfactorily, the city shall release ninety (90) per cent of the funds with a letter of approval to the subdivider. The remaining ten (10) per cent shall apply toward the subdivider's required maintenance bond. The cost of any correct work required shall be deducted from these funds. 
(e)  Maintenance of completed work. The subdivider shall maintain his completed work until the approval by the city engineer for one year. A maintenance bond, except to the extent where a portion of such bond has been provided for under Section 9.14(d) is to be posted by the subdivider in an amount equal to ten (10) per cent of the construction cost. During the maintenance period, the city engineer shall make periodic inspections and notify the subdivider of necessary corrections. At the end of the maintenance period, the city engineer shall make a final inspection and report his findings to the city. Necessary corrections not made by the subdivider will be completed by the city. The cost of such corrections shall be deducted from the maintenance funds and/or collected from the subdivider and the bonding company. If the work is acceptable at the end of the maintenance period, the maintenance bond shall expire and/or any remaining funds shall be released to the subdivider. Said corrections shall not include vandalism and other damage beyond the control of the developer. 
Section 9.15. - Subdivider's responsibility. 
The subdivider shall incur the cost of construction and installation of all required public improvements according to the following: 
(a)  Streets. Incur the cost for the construction of all street grading, paving, curb and gutters and storm drainage, which are required by these subdivision regulations. 
(b)  Utility system. Incur the cost for the installation of the utility distribution systems which is required to serve the new subdivisions and to tie with the existing utility system based on the Standard Design Specifications of the City. 
(c)  Sidewalks. Entire cost, if provided. 
(d)  Monuments. Entire cost. 
(e)  Street lighting. For an underground electrical distribution system, the developer shall pay one hundred (100) per cent of the cost of installation. For the installation of street lights and poles, the developer shall pay all costs above fifty (50) per cent of the cost of a twenty-five-foot bronze fiberglass pole with eight thousand five hundred fifty (8,550) lumen HPS light. 
(Ord. No. 83-16, § 1, 10-20-83; Ord. No. 88-10, § 1, 3-3-88) 
Section 9.16. - City's responsibility. 
The city shall participate in sharing the cost of construction and installation of the required public improvements for the following conditions: 
(a)  Streets. The cost for any additional pavement which may be required in excess of the minimum paving requirements to serve the new subdivision. 
(b)  Utility system. Incur the cost for any difference in cost of oversized lines which may be needed in excess of the required utility facilities needed to exclusively serve the new subdivision as determined by the city engineer. 
Section 9.17. - Property owner's responsibility. 
Whenever the city is petitioned by the property owners to upgrade the street to higher construction standards (as prescribed by Article V, Improvements, of Chapter 20 of the City Code), the property owner shall be assessed as follows: 
(a)  For street paving alone: Two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the total cost of said improvements, one-third ( 1/3 ) to be assessed against the abutting property owner on one side of the street and one-third ( 1/3 ) against the owner on the opposite side of the street. 
(b)  For paving, curb and gutter: One-half (½) of the total cost of said improvements, one-fourth (¼) to be assessed against the abutting property owner on one side of the street and one-fourth (¼) against the owner on the opposite side of the street. 
Section 9.18. - Estimated cost for construction and installation. 
The current unit prices in effect at the time of submission of plans plus ten (10) per cent shall be used in determining the total estimated cost for construction and installation of required public improvements in new subdivisions. 
ARTICLE 10. - ENFORCEMENT PROVISIONS 

Section 10.1. - Enforcing officer(s). 
The provisions of this ordinance shall be administered and enforced for the city by the platting officer and the planning commission who shall promptly notify the city in writing of all violations of these provisions. 
Section 10.2. - Approval required prior to sale or transfer of property. 
The owner or agent of the owner of any land to be subdivided within the City of Dublin who transfers or sells, or agrees to sell or negotiates to sell such land by reference to or exhibition of, or by other use of a plat to subdivide such land before such plat has been approved by the planning commission and recorded in the office of the clerk of the Superior Court of Laurens County shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided by Section 69.9905, Code of Georgia Annotated. The description by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document used in the process of selling or transfer shall not exempt the transaction from such penalties. The city, through its attorney or other official designated by the city council, may enjoin such transfer or sale or agreement by appropriate action. 
THE EFFECTIVE DATE of this ordinance shall be the 14th day of May, 1981, and all ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are hereby expressly repealed. 
SO ORDAINED this 14th day of May, 1981, by a vote of 5 FOR and 0 AGAINST and approved by the Mayor. 
/s/ Robert E. Cochran,  Mayor 
ATTEST: 
/s/ William B. Tarpley,  City Clerk 
First Reading: May 7, 1981 
Second Reading: May 14, 1981
